This game is actually okay. It not bad but it’s not good. It has a mediocre storyline with nice graphics to look at.


The Good
It has a linear storyline. Even though it’s not good, at least it is something. Also, the voice acting is pretty bad.

The graphics are good.


The Bad
The game uses high CPU!

There is a randomized card system for parts. Even though I think the gameplay aspects to this is good, I personally just want to buy parts and get a better vehicle. I can only expect that the cards play a bigger part later in the game when doing higher leveled missions, which I am not going to do. I just wanted a good story involving fast cars.

Looking for the main quest on the map was hard for me to do. There were so many icons and none of them said that they were the story mission. One was locked off until you did something else. There are recommended levels for missions and that makes me feel like the game is grindy.

The mission that I had to do, had requirements to progress the story. I hate that crap. Time limit, high points, or whatever, just leave it out for main missions…

There was no way to turn off the vibration on the controller. 

The game and ea apps obviously want to collect data.


Conclusion
It’s not a bad game and I was having an okay time with it. It’s just, I was watching a person play La noire yesterday, and while playing need for speed payback, I kept thinking how I would rather play la noire than this. Something with a clear and linear story with no bs.
It's mediocre NFS games with the usual type of story, but we are here for the cars, right?

So, unfortunately:
- open world hard limited
- tuning options mediocre
- story seems half assed
- no real progress, it just feels like doing homework with those missions...

sorry.. i love nfs but i do not recommend this.

Well, i finished the game, here are the stuff i like and don't like about the game:

Main game (story mode):
The game has great graphics for 2017, the police car crash camera is very cool and i really like it, the cars have awesome customization, the story is really well made and i enjoy it the game also is full of action.

Multiplayer (online):
In 2024 the online servers are almost dead and you will find a session very hard, i only ever played online once and the people there are very chill and you can enjoy it whit friends.
Some additional stuff i like: The game can run on a pretty bad computer, you can run it on 8 GB of ram just fine if you disable some programs in your system.
Even if you finish the game you can go around and relax while driving across the map.
You can play this game whit out a mouse.

Things i don't like:
The voice lines feel a bit weird like they are made by AI.
I don't like that the only way to get vanities is by getting it whit a shipment pack because you will never know what you might get.
The multiplayer is a complete joke, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR MULTIPLAYER, multiplayer just feels like a bonus to the game not an actual game mode. The main problem is that you can't find people to race whit anymore since as i mentioned earlier the game is kind of dead, if you really wanna race you might want to get some friends to play whit.
EA Launcher is very, very bad, i hate it and i wish you would not need it to be able to run the game.
The controls are really really weird so please just change them.

Whit all of this being said i enjoy this game and i like it so i rate it a 8.5/10.

The game in 2024 is worth it just if it is on sale, i bought it for 2.99 Euro, full price is not worth it anymore.

This is a racing game that has Drifting as an afterthought, the cars have no weight to them and don't slide and don't have enough inertia to make drifting actually feel fun enough. NFS 2015 has better drifting heck any other nfs has better drifting. Turning Sensitivity can be changed on Race Builds but Drift Builds can't change the turning sensitivity which is stupid because the speed at how sharply you can turn directly affects how quick and smooth you can initiate a drift its funny because this feature you could change in NFS 2015 with the Differential and Weight balance of the car actually had more impact on how drifty your car is and you can't actually get good parts out of the shops. You need part tokens later in the game to actually make your cars acceleration and speed stats go up. Because the game will skimp you on those and when you trade in parts that are useless you only get 1/3 needed to actually get 1 roll so you either buy all the useless parts in the shop and trade them in if you buy all 10 or so it'll be 200,000+ maybe which you grinded for and could've saved for buying a new car instead you need to roll and gamble for the "right parts" And the Free drops they give you you'll maybe have like 70-80 part tokens giving you 30+ rolls but eventually you'll need different cars for every different 6 styles of event and you'll lose all of them trying to get your cars to a decent level anyway it's just too fucking grindy and a waste of time and money why even bother just play the old need for speeds that don't need to hold you by the wallet to progress. It's not an openended progression system its a grindy loot-box buy in if you want to get all your cars leveled with minimal grind its just boring. And the Road design or the physics themselves feels like you're driving a toy car sometimes.

I was very disappointed to find the game doesn't support a steering wheel (at least not my Thrustmaster).  I mean, how can you have a driving game that doesn't allow steering wheels?  Makes no sense.
Regardless, I gave it a whirl with an xbox controller and (unlike rivals) found it quite fun.  I think it's the story element and not having to either purposely crash into other cars, or be evading the police.
It means my ineptitude of driving with a controller isn't punished so hard.
I'm also liking the progression and the mini sub games - like collecting the tokens and billboards.  Having said that, I had to look up what the hell the billboards were all about cos the game didn't tell me I had to crash through them.  Also discovered the trick of engaging random racers on the street quite by driving alongside and trying just about every button until I beeped the horn and something happened.  Dunno why this stuff can't be explained in game cos it certainly isn't intuitive - especially as a newbie to xbox controllers.  I mean, I was alt tabbing out and ending process to stop the game until I accidentally found the menu button :)
In my opinion, one of the best need for speed games.

As a die-hard Need for Speed fan, Payback exceeded all expectations! The adrenaline-fueled races, jaw-dropping visuals, and the nostalgic nod to classic NFS elements create a thrilling experience. The open-world setting adds a new layer of freedom, letting you explore and dominate diverse terrains. The car customization options are a dream come true for any gearhead, providing endless ways to make your ride unique. Payback successfully captures the essence of the Need for Speed franchise, delivering high-octane excitement and a love letter to fans who have been with the series from the beginning. It's a must-play for NFS enthusiasts craving speed, style, and that unmistakable rush of arcade racing.

My second Need for Speed title that reintroduced me to the series, this game has it's ups and downs. There are aspects to this game that make you scratch your head such as the main complaint to seemingly everyone, the slot machine style performance upgrade system. Though this system is heavily flawed and makes upgrading RNG dependent, I would be lying if I said it doesn't make maxing out your car a little more satisfying. Another common complaint is the race class system which basically forces you to buy a separate car for each event type; race, offroad, drag, drift, and runner. Annoying? A little. But not a deal breaker to me. Outside of this, the main story line was pretty solid for a racing game. Corny here and there as you'd expect but likable characters that don't make it unbearable. Customization was great just like most NFS titles. The soundtrack is great and features a lot of good songs. I genuinely enjoyed the game despite it's flaws and think it was severely over hated.

Pretty good modern NFS game with a few flaws that don't ruin anything.

Good:
-Wide variety of different race types which lets you drop a certain type of race if you get bored with it and go try another type for a while.
-Drifting is amazing, I wish they had doubled the drifting events in the game.
-Story is alright, the characters try too hard to be unique but overall it works.
-The "gambling" theme that everything has is cute
-You gamble for parts which fits into the theme which has obviously not gone over well, but a lot of people don't understand that basically individual parts don't matter, when you gamble you are guaranteed to get something better than what you have currently.  Also, they give you shipments which gives you over 100 rolls to get parts.  I'm not defending this but it does fit into the theme and they removed this in future titles.
-Police pursuits are fun and challenging, they have a bunch of tricks you have to watch out for.  The police are aggressive in this game but not as much as NFS Heat.

Bad:
-The offroad physics are garbage and are quite literally unplayable with a few tracks late in the game as the entire track is much too thin and you will slide into rocks and lose the race instantly as there is no catch-up so offroad is tiptoeing over eggshells and very very much not fun.  Plus this game is literally obsessed with them.  The last entire offroad league is trash for this reason and they should have gone with another drift league instead.  I put an hour into one race  on restart attempts before I decided to stop wasting my time and turn the game down to easy just for that race.
-The Outlaw's Rush (the big final race the game teases you about the entire game) is absolutely not special at all
-The story events are much too cinematic and feel like slightly interactive set pieces
-While the city is well thought out and has lots of jumps and shortcuts, the offroad sections feel like a whole lot of nothing, real empty world.
-The fact that you have to make "builds" for each race type even though nothing about the car is unique to it is stupid, but they do give you more than enough parts, and I understand if they didn't do this then you'd just grind your starter car and not ever experience 99% of the cars they bothered to put in the game

This game is absolutely worth a few bucks though, it goes on sale all the time now.

[h3]One of Ghost Games' Better Need for Speed Titles.[/h3]

A much improved racing game compared to 2015's effort in pretty much all aspects. Loading is much faster, characters are at least [i]somewhat[/i] likable now, there's a huge variety in main events and side activities, and overall it's simply far more polished. Yes it does have some blemishes here and there and it's also very by-the-numbers, taking a page out of Burnout Paradise's book that popularized this approach to open-world racers, but otherwise  [i]Payback[/i] is a surpisingly robust entry in the franchise. 

For an arcade title the handling model is very competent and further expressed in how the different styles of cars control. This offers a distinct feeling of racing from event to event. Whether you're doing off-road, drag racing, drifting, speed runs or escaping from the cops they all have their own category of eligible cars and make it so there's a high variety in gameplay which forces you to play with multiple vehicles (as opposed to cruising through the campaign with just one that you've tuned up for everything). The only annoyance being that when you are trying to snag up some collectibles on certain terrain your car doesn't handle well you're better off going back to the garage to swap out your ride.  

Speaking of variety, the open-world itself also holds up in this regard what with its sprawling off-road terrain that ranges from lush green backwoods to dusty canyons. There's a city center that's full of casinos and high rises and on the outskirts you've got smaller towns dotted around that evoke pure Americana; all complete with landmarks and places to explore. It's all really well done and give the game an identity and personalty, something that was missing from the 2015 title. That said, there's also vast stretches of desert between all of the main hubs that basically has no points of interest whatsoever so don't go expecting Burnout Paradise or Forza Horizon levels of activity density in that respect. 
 
As far as downsides go is that despite the story and characters being a step up from the previous game (which isn't saying much, admittedly) the voice acting can be [i]very[/i] hit and miss. The same goes for the music choices that feature some of the most milquetoast Indie Blues/Rock imaginable. The type you'd hear in commercials or sizzle reels that aim to be as inoffensive as possible and evoke no feeling whatsoever. You'd argue this is subjective but the entire soundtrack almost sounds like a royalty free affair. Pure background noise. And in a racing game you'd ideally get some blood pumping tracks across all genres but [i]Payback[/i] is extremely lacking here. If EA wanted to cheap out on song licensing then it definitely shows (ironically in the previous game I couldn't actually hear the soundtrack due to a bug but in this one I turned it off myself).  

Another issue I have is that the upgrading system is kind of awkward. Instead of outright buying the parts you want for each category you instead have to contend with a card system that has a certain factor of randomness thrown in as well. It's akin to something like FIFA Ultimate Team and makes actual upgrading an unnecessary hassle. Upon receiving a part (or "speed card") you can then either equip it, send it to your garage, sell it for cash or trade it in and while this does offer some choice I just found it cumbersome at the best of times.  

Otherwise though Payback is a step in the right direction. Yes it's all rather formulaic so your mileage may vary depending on whether or not you have the stomach for yet another open-world racer of this ilk (with a heavy emphasis on story). But for me it's been one of the more enjoyable racing games I've played in the series. The visuals are great, the driving feels good for the most part, and along with the surprisingly solid technical performance it's also been a mostly bug free experience for me as well. 

Considering the fact that this deluxe edition regularly goes on sale for a criminally low 3 Euro (Activision take note) it's been incredible value for money and thus an easy recommend.

No idea why this game is so poorly reviewed by the playerbase. Everything I heard about this game from players before finally pulling the trigger and buying it myself were entirely negative and I can't really put my finger on why. Sure the story makes no sense and the characters aren't terribly likable, but they're a lot more likable than the "people" in Unbound, but are you really playing Need For Speed for the story or characters in the first place?

The visuals are fantastic even on low settings, as are the cutscenes. The car roster is really good and the visual customization is plentiful. The driving physics themselves leave a lot to be desired, it's extremely difficult, even with maxed steering sensitivity tuning, to just take a corner without hitting either wall or both. It's got better drifting physics than Unbound but it's far worse than a proper drift build on NFS Heat. The upgrade system is interesting and doesn't just revolve around grinding for money to afford the next part you unlocked, however it's not exactly a realistic system. The map is bigger than Heat and quite varied. The visual mods are unlocked through various things that happen naturally by just playing the game in freeroam, not a level up system or per-race like the other modern NFS games. It's not a live service (though some features require a brief connection to the internet which is a downside), so far I haven't been bombarded with MTX advertisements and I haven't been presented with content the base game didn't include like NFS Most Wanted 2012 did CONSTANTLY.

A minor nag I have is that the Nissan R35 GTR's exhaust note is terrible. It sounds like the trumpety VQ engines Nissan used in the 350z, 370z, G35 and G37 and those cars are memes in the car world for having an annoying exhaust note. The R35's VR38 engine sounds nothing like these, and this annoying sound makes the GTR unpleasant to drive. Annoyingly, the 350z doesn't use this exhaust note either, making the cars sound like their engines are swapped with one another. The Infiniti Q60 doesn't sound like the GTR either despite using variations on the same VR engine. The G35/G37 is only a pedestrian car, but it doesn't sound like this either.

The only issues I've had with this game so far was controller support issues caused by owning the game on Origin instead of Steam, and since buying the game on Steam, my PS4 controller works perfect, even has pressure sensitive triggers and dynamic joysticks despite saying it wouldn't unless I had an XBOX controller. Let that be a lesson to all; if you buy a game on Origin/EA App, it's not guaranteed to have full controller support, but if buy that same game on Steam, you can force the controller to work with very minimal effort.

The other issue I've encountered is that the game isn't very well optimized. I have to sit somewhere between Low and Medium despite having an RTX 2070 Super and that's just not okay.

Otherwise the game is fantastic! Personally I'd wait for a sale, it's not quite worth $30,

How people have fun with modern NFS games is beyond me.
The handling sucks. I know it's arcade handling, but I feel racing games should at least retain some realism in the handling, or at the very least you should be able to get the car to where you want it to go. This is just an understeering, perma brake fading, handbrake engine stalling simulator.
The story is boring and has really weird pacing, right from the get-go. And the voice acting is fucking terrible. I feel bad being this brunt but DAMN, is it bad. I've seen low-to-no budget parody videos on youtube with better voice acting than this.
The graphics may look decent for 2017. I don't remember many games from that era, but I can at least tell you that they haven't aged very well. Running at max settings still renders stuff like decals extremely blurred. Not to mention that everything looks like it's made of shiny play dough. Won't comment more than this on the graphics because of what I said at the start on this topic, though I'm sure I could find a similarly scaled game without these problems.

At risk of sounding like another 2005-era NFS fan: EA, please just remaster Most Wanted 2005 and Carbon. Or yet, don't! I'm sure you'd probably manage to fuck that up too.

If you, the reader, are debating getting this for 3€ on sale like I did, maybe check some other games first and buy this if you find nothing else. At any higher of a price, just skip it.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Review:

Need for Speed Payback delivers an adrenaline-fueled experience that will leave racing enthusiasts on the edge of their seats. As a longtime fan of the Need for Speed franchise, I was eagerly anticipating this latest installment, and I can confidently say that it did not disappoint.

One of the standout features of Payback is its captivating storyline. Set in the fictional Fortune Valley, players are immersed in a world of underground racing, betrayal, and revenge. The narrative is engaging, filled with unexpected twists and turns that kept me hooked from start to finish. The characters are well-developed, each with their own motivations and personalities, adding depth to the overall experience.

The gameplay itself is nothing short of exhilarating. Whether tearing through the streets in high-speed pursuits or competing in intense races, every moment behind the wheel is filled with excitement. The controls are responsive and intuitive, allowing for precise maneuvers and hair-raising stunts. Customization options are also extensive, allowing players to personalize their vehicles to suit their style and preferences.

Visually, Need for Speed Payback is stunning. The sprawling open world of Fortune Valley is beautifully rendered, with detailed environments and breathtaking vistas. From neon-lit cityscapes to sun-drenched deserts, each location feels distinct and immersive.

Multiplayer mode adds another layer of excitement to the experience, allowing players to compete against friends and rivals from around the world. Whether collaborating in cooperative races or going head-to-head in intense showdowns, there's never a dull moment online.

Overall, Need for Speed Payback is a triumphant addition to the franchise, delivering heart-pounding action, gripping storytelling, and breathtaking visuals. With its compelling gameplay and extensive customization options, it's a must-have for any racing fan. Strap in, rev your engines, and get ready for the ride of a lifetime.

This Need for Speed has some serious problems that need to be addressed: mainly, the over-use of loot boxes (and microtransactions) and a broken progression system that relies too much on randomness and grinding. The story is cringe-worthy, full of bi-dimensional characters and annoying catch-phrases. All that being said, the arcade driving model is accessible and fun as always but sometime it feels like driving on ice. The open world is pretty big and full of activities that can keep the player engaged for a long while. Oh, and you're going to spend plenty of time in the garage pimping your ride.

Great NFS entry for the casual gamer, who wants to play an odd hour when the kids have gone to bed. Each car is widely customizable, including decals (and text) of your own choosing. Freeroaming environment GTA style, with different kinds of racing represented and a single player campaign to keep you occupied. Racing is fun, and challenging when it needs to be. 

Despite me being a gamer for over 20 years, this ended up the very first game I completed 100%. Turning a 1960s pick-up truck into a 1200+ BHP Drift monster has never felt so rewarding.

car

During the time of this review, I have already played NFS - UG, UG2, Most Wanted, Carbon, MW 2013, Undercover, Pro-Street, Shift 1. Here are my thoughts on Payback.

[hr][/hr]
[b][u]Story[/u]:[/b] It has a plot that feels pretty generic however like NFS games, its story is just the moving factor to keep us engaged. But I am still impressed with the work they did with this generic plot.

[b][u]Graphic and Presentation[/u]:[/b] Definitely there is improvement in visual and open world is largely fun to run with. I did have certain problem with the off road object placements where the feel of speed is obstructed by some objects around the corner breaking the feel of simulated action scene.

[b][u]Events[/u]:[/b]  Has regular events for Race and Off-road - Sprint, Circuit, Drag and Drift. DLC has SpeedCrossx which is StreetX from Underground 2 but done with more action and speed. Additionally there is Non race events which is more mission/task oriented. I like the wager system to boost the pocket in each race when completing a random objective in an event. I tried multiplayer for the sake of achievements only hence cannot comment on it much.

[b][u]Activities[/u]:[/b] Additional solo activities include Speed run, Speed trap, Drift Zones and Jumps. There are rival activities like roaming racer similar to NFS UG2 but with aggression levelled up after beating a racer resulting in better reward. Crates mission are fun since its simply a trigger that initiates a pursuit.

[b][u]Collectables[/u]:[/b] Like Most wanted 2013, we have Billboards to smash and There are around 100 gambles chips scattered around the map. I hated the placements for most part as our ride has to go through specific speed to reach it i.e. if over-speed, will miss it which is a bad design for a game focused on speed.

[b][u]Soundtrack[/u]:[/b] I think people who complain about NFS soundtracks are from my generation as our childhood and teenage years were filled with experience of those wonderful OSTs that we keep comparing every NFS games with those. I think Payback has decent Soundtrack and the way they play-out depending on the type of event is a good design although i still think there could have been improvement in deciding the OSTs.

[b][u]Cars and Customisation[/u]:[/b] Collection of cars are impressive and different types based on event like Prostreet are brought back. Parts customisation is bit short in terms of options as compared to prior NFS but still not bad. Visual customs are highlight where I would spend a lot of time. I like the feature of sharing our custom design with the community and using the ones that was shared by other. Although it is disappointing that certain customisation like tyre smoke, neon are loot boxes.

[b][u]Pursuit[/u]:[/b] Pursuit is not as interesting as MW but is still fun to play. Think of Marked man event from Burnout paradise. You just have to get from point A to B. That's it, pursuit ends around 80% of the event completion. Also, Pursuit is limited to events only which is ok considering open world activity in this game.

[hr][/hr]
[b][u]Overall experience[/u]:[/b] I think this is a good NFS game that gives great sense of speed. Although the story and chapters are short, the activities will keep us engages in it for better part of the playtime. There is a huge margin for improvement like objectives in race must not hinder with speed but rather encourage to go flying. Definitely a good game from NFS series as I had a sense of satisfaction  playing this game.

[h1] Racing To Win Against All Odds [/h1]
Set in the underworld of Fortune Valley, you and your crew are reunited by a search for vengeance against The House, a nefarious cartel that rules the city’s casinos, criminals, and cops. In this corrupt gambler’s paradise, the stakes are high and The House always wins. Play a variety of events as Tyler, Mac, and Jess. Earn the respect of the Valley’s underground and compete in the ultimate race to finally take down The House.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]In terms of visuals, this game is really beautiful and still holds up well today. The image is really sharp and I'd go so far to say that it even looks sharper than Need For Speed: Heat! Not saying the graphics are better, but the image sharpness is superior. The UI is minimal and really clean and the car models look incredible! The character models also don’t look bad at all. The character’s don’t look next gen, but they still hold up pretty well. The texture and lighting are really impressive and still look superb, which is great to see.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]The car physics are pretty decent, not great but decent. The driving physics/handling work well with the map design (unlike NFS 2015) so no complaints there. The car customization is still as impressive as ever, but with some minor flaws. The stancing system had seen a downgrade. You can’t space your tires out anymore so many widebody or widened fenders will have bad fitment. Besides that the car customization is pretty good and I like that you unlock parts by doing some challenges. I prefer this over the NFS 2015 leveling system because it’s much faster to unlock these parts and feels rewarding. The tuning system is not in the game anymore because they decided to make you focus on different race types with different cars. Now you need to have a street car, drift car, offroad car, drag car, etc. I did not like this system at first because I prefered to have one personal car (or two). Having to micro-manage 6-7 cars was annoying right off the bat, but it got easier when you started making more money and it was cool to see many focused car builds in the garage. The upgrading system is horrible. The only way to upgrade your car is by buying or earning cards. You can go to the tune shop and create your own upgrades by a slot machine type system, it’s a bit shady and a dumb upgrade mechanic that taints the game. The good thing is that it’s been fixed to make it less annoying. Luckily the game offers shortcuts to preinstalled tunes but you need to get further into the game to unlock these. There are microtransactions to make this easier, but not worth it since it’s not too grindy in my opinion. The races are really fun and feel all unique. The offroad races are actually my favorite (and the street races). It’s cool to see Need for Speed for some off-roading, and they did a pretty good job at it. The car roster is insane with so many amazing cars to drive and the map is so perfect for these types of races and fast cars. This is my favorite map in the Modern Need for Speed games (talking about NFS 2015, Heat, and unbound). It’s so well balanced and offers many great styles of racing. Also the AI are actually challenging and put up a good fight which was great to see and had a blast racing against them![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story was actually really fun. It’s not incredible by any means, but it was engaging and enjoyed that there were antagonists and a worthwhile plot. The characters are forgettable and uninteresting, but the story was a good switch up compared to Need For Speed 2015. The story did drag a bit too long in the later stages but overall it was pretty fun and a good improvement from the previous game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]The story is about 20+ of playtime but if you plan on exploring and getting everything completed it’s around 40+ hours. If you don’t plan on exploring the map or doing collectables then the replayability may be little to none here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The vehicles sound absolutely incredible. Every car sounds unique from each other and is a joy to drive. I swear Need for Speed never disappoints with sound design. Sadly Need for Speed never mastered getting good voice actors because some of the acting is physically painful. The main protagonist was absolutely horrible and had one of the worst voice acting performances I ever heard in a video game. Also the music was kinda meh. Some soundtracks were decent, but most of them were just horrible.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really seen any serious bugs in this game. The physics can act a bit buggy if you are sliding and hit a cop or wall. The textures may take a little bit to fully load up at times (I’m not on an SSD so that may be the culprit). Besides that I never haven't seen anything that stood out to me that was a bug.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance for the most part was actually pretty solid. Max settings and had a solid 60 fps. I rarely had any frame drops. I did have stutters at times but those were pretty rare. The stutters may have been from me streaming so take that into consideration.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Amazing graphics
[*]Incredible map
[*]Huge car variety
[*]Different car builds
[*]Clean/simple UI
[*]Challenging AI
[*]Superb sound design
[*]Many activities/collectable
[*]Good car customization
[*]Offroading feels pretty good
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Microtransactions
[*]Requires EA App
[*]Story drags on too long
[*]No cops in free roam
[*]Fine tuning is removed
[*]Some stance options removed
[*]Terrible/tedious upgrading system
[*]Horrible protagonist (voice acting nearly killed me)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]7/10
Buy this game on sale for around 25-50% off.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Need for Speed Payback was a great improvement from the previous game released. Sadly they removed some great customization options and made some questionable gameplay changes. Despite that, the game was actually fun and I had a good time with it. The story was a joy and kept me engaged, the driving was fun and the map is amazing. Finally great to see a Need for Speed game come back with challenging AI, fantastic map, great customization, and more! I would have rated this higher but some changes they made did not benefit this game at all. It’s not as good as Need for Speed: Heat, but a great improvement from Need for Speed 2015. Give this game a try if you are looking for the fun arcade racer![/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

1) you get to the offroad races. I hate them. They are really frustrating. One time you go straight and the other you just drift and can't control it. I can't really explain it, but it was painful.
2) You have to turn. When you race, and you have to take a sharp turn. I played on the hard mode so that mind be the reason. But when that happens you just need to restart the race. You won't win cuz you just ain't fast enough.

So this is my review. Buy it, but not at the full price. I'll for sure be coming back to get the 100%. But till then, have fun.

Need for Speed Payback was the EA attempt to reinvent the game mechanics with a different approach for the plot and game systems. The map is large enough( maybe the biggest of the series) to host different landmarks or landscapes,from 
deserts to mountains and large valleys. 

The graphics are muddy but still looks good at maximum settings,the cars look good and especially at night everything looks better. 

Payback features a day and night cycle ,beautiful roads and a decent car amount to drive . The story is told through separate chapters from the perspective of three characters each with his own perks and discipline. 
The plot is focused on a revenge motif to take down the House ( the organization that controls casinos,cops and the underground racing in Fortune Valley) . 

In terms of story,i don't expect a lot from a racing game but i was surprised they actually tried to deliver a decent story. And for the most part they did. But unfortunately also felt linear and annoying.
I don't want to talk about the game ending or Lina Navarro,i'll let you discover.

At first glance the cops are annoying but in a good way( they do their job as intended). This provides a tense racing experience but i wish you could escape like in previous games.. now if you reach a checkpoint towards the end of the race they stop following you and the chase ends.. That alone is a major downside for the fun factor and gameplay experience.

On a closer look the game doesn't feel polish and original enough. Some elements and activities like drift zones or derelict cars are borrowed from other games . The car stealing and some cutscenes made me feel i was playing as Dominic Toretto  at times. 

I really liked how drifting experience felt in this game,with proper tweaks and car setup it's a pleasure to maintain the drifting line through difficult corners. 

Pros:
-simple driving mechanics
-very good drifting 
-the revving sounds amazing 
-the story is bad but when you search what racing genre has to offer ,you come back and give this another chance

Cons:
-Police chase ends when you reach a checkpoint
-missions/activities felt repetitive 

My review score:
Story   - 7
Gameplay-8

Sound  - 9

Overall - 7.75

Writing this review as of now (January 15th, 2024). 
I have played this game back in 2017 when it first came out. My review back then? Horrible, terrible even!
This is, in my personal opinion, the 2nd worse entry in the entirety of the Need for Speed Franchise. Everything this game offers it does so half baked or poorly executed. The open world it's not really open at all, the handling, whilst a improvement from it's predecessor (2015) it's still bad, the upgrade system and progression it's basically a slot machine, etc...
You might be wondering, why is the review positive then? What's changed since? Well...
THE MODDING COMMUNITY / SCENE!!!
One in specifically, UNITE Payback, truely makes this game worth a play.
UNITE Payback get's rid of everything wrong, bad, or incomplete in the game, adds upon, and offers even more content for the player to tackle.
If you got the game on a huge sale discount, or as part of the Need for Speed franchise bundle and have been hesitant on playing it, but wanted to get some value out of it - this is it.

3 years ago, a friend of mine recommended this game to me and, even though I was reluctant at first, I downloaded it on Playstation plus and played with it.
   When I entered, I went through the tutorial and entered multiplayer and saw his Beetle, which was so fast that it beat me backwards (I was with the first car in the game), from that moment on, I decided that I was going to dedicate myself to this game and try to surpass my friend.
    I was never that interested in cars, but for some reason the Mazda Rx-7 always enchanted me, so when I saw it in the game, I bought it and started improving it as much as possible.
    After a while I finally managed to go head to head with the Beetle and in some moments even win. Until my friend lost his Playstation Plus and we couldn't play anymore.
    A few years passed and I felt like remembering this game and the experience I had. When I went to open the game, I realized that my data had been corrupted, I was very shaken, but over time I accepted the loss and started to have only good memories in my head.
    After a while, I see that this same game, which marked my life, was on sale, I couldn't contain myself and bought it. My friend unfortunately can't play with me anymore, but the experience and nostalgia are incredible! This game has one of the best racing game gameplays I've ever seen. I thank my friend who showed me this wonderful game that will always be in my heart.

THIS GAME IS NOT OPEN WORLD.

Open world means the world is...you guessed it. Open.
This is a pseudo-open world racer. You are confined to whatever the game has determined to be terrain. This restriction is present even in free roam.

Example: 
1. You see a winding mountain road and decide take a short cut through the bushes to a part of the track below. Access denied...reset.
2. Want to have some fun and air time off the mountain onto a clearly visible road below? Nope...reset.
3. Searching for collectibles and are one inch off your perfect landing...you guessed it. Reset.

I tend to experience this more outside the city. Hopefully a mod comes out that fixes this.

The characters are all forgettable along with the story. The only consolation for me was Mac.
Add the insane rubber banding, poor handling, weird customization and scripted chases and you have another expensive attempt at insanity.

Underneath all the issues there are fragments of fun to be found. Like derelict hunting, vehicle tuning and just cruising around. Race difficulty is tied to your vehicle level, and by the time you max out everything you'll be leaving the ai in the dust...except for the scripted races.

EA needs to stop trying to recreate one-trick ponies and instead understand what made previous games like Underground 2, Most Wanted 2005 and Hot Pursuit 2010 great. It was not the characters or the live action cut-scenes. it was the gameplay, game modes, vehicle handling, soundtrack and the overall experience.

I miss Black Box and old Criterion team.

[i][b]Need for Speed™ Payback[/b][/i] is a very solid game in the franchise, let down primarily through its egregious upgrade system. All other systems at play are great though, and it's definitely worth a play!

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
It's... well, it's definitely a game in the franchise, that's for sure. It's a racing game, and its variety of race types is very satisfying. The location of the game, Las Vegas, also opens up many avenues for excitement and fun, with winding canyon roads and desert dunes to take on with a slew of different rides.

The core gameplay is tight and fun, moving you from one race to the next with little hesitation. The driving model is [i]good[/i] but not the best in the franchise, and races feel fine overall. Cars handle and sound different, and the events are all fun and challenging without ever being burdensome.

The upgrade system, however, is its fatal flaw. [i]EA[/i] decided to push their monetization as far as they could with this title. Upgrades are via a "card" system, which essentially boils down to a lootbox system. It doesn't take much time to run out of free in-game resources, leaving you with a subpar car and lackluster upgrades. It's frustrating, but the moment you're at your limit, the game is ready to tell you that you can skip this by spending real money.

It's gross, and the worst part of the game. Luckily, it can be ignored, as the upgrades are not essential to completing the game.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
Story-wise, the game is nothing special, but the franchise never has been. It has a cast of characters whose personalities are all... kinda "we know what the kids like" in nature, but it was never too much for me to listen to. It feels like an even more campy version of [i][b]Fast & Furious[/b][/i] at times, but that's not all that bad.

[h1][b]Performance[/b][/h1]
Performance-wise, the game runs... great, actually! Fantastic visuals, good performance, just about every graphical feature you'd like to have here, and I never had any performance issues. It's not perfect, but performance was never on my mind while playing.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Overall, [i][b]Need for Speed™ Payback[/b][/i] is a good racing game let down by egregious monetization in its upgrade system. It's still worth a play, it's just disappointing that it's let down only by a single, core aspect that could have easily been changed for something better.

Other than that there is lot's to enjoy in the different race categories (off road, drift, drag, speedcross, etc) and secrets to find pretty naturally in gameplay.

This game actually feels good to play. The driving and drifting is fun (NFS-like movements possible) and it doesn't feel like 6 years old at all. The story is well made and doesn't get boring. You can easily achieve multiple dream cars as there are many cars to choose from, and a lot of customisation is possible.
The time to complete the story is about [b]20-25 hours[/b]. The time needed for a 100% play-through is about [b]37 hours[/b].
[b]Recommened price[/b] for NFS-Fans: Full Price (30€)
[b]Recommened price[/b] for everybody: 20€

[u]Pro (+)[/u]
-Map is huge and the diversity of the different areas/biomes is very good
-Fast travel to 33 different locations
-Optic tuning very nice and a lot to choose from
-Good amount of cars
-You get money kinda fast, so you can have multiple dream cars without grinding too much for it
-The driving and drifting feels really nice, you can do actually real NFS like driving and drifting which I enjoyed a lot
-Story is good and because of 6 different racing types it doesn't get boring
-There are no poorly made police chases outside the story, so you can just relax doing your races and activities
-The main missions of the story are replayable (and they are worth to replay!)
-Street racers and open world bosses, which are challenging to beat
-Car sounds are very nice

[u]Neutral (~)[/u]
-You need to buy the car for a certain type (like race/drag/drift), so if you want the same car for every type, you will need to buy it more than once
-The performance upgrade is partly made with a "loot machine" where you need coins to spin (you get coins easily), but it feels just wrong to have gambling for performance parts

[u]Contra (-)[/u]
-Multiplayer is dead, very hard to find an online lobby, mostly only if communicated over the steam forum beforehand
-You can buy coins for the "loot machine" to upgrade your performance faster
-If you want to add specific colors of nitro, tire-smoke or air suspension you need to open those lootboxes, to have a chance to get a random reward

Really good game. I think it would be better if the dialogue was a bit better in terms of being original, because people tend to say the same things over and over with every boss. I think Jess could play a larger role in the effort to bring down the house. Racing 10/10. Drifting 8/10. Drag 4/10... could be so much more potential here... Runner 8/10. Xcross 6/10... pretty boring ngl... now with off-road, I usually don't like in many games, but this was pretty enjoyable. I think if drifting was initiated less in offroad because holy fucking shit all I was doing was sliding around, jesus christ. But anyway, I went full play through on medium difficulty and still enjoyed the game with some difficulty. One big critique would be making the world less restrictive. If I want to fucking full blast across the desert without slamming into indestructible rocks every 1/4 mile, I should be able to. Other than that, great game. A classic nfs feel.

[h1] 🕘          IMPRESSION:[/h1]
* 2017: Game released and I start observing
* 2019: Finally brought it from Origin store
* 2020: Still satisfied after 43 hours
* 2021: Very much better than NFS Heat
* 2022: Still loving it after 59 hours
* 63 hours later: Buy again on Steam account
* 0.1 hours later: Earned 36 steam achievements in 1 min because sync to my EA progress, steam people assume that I cheated

[h1]  🔊         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* Require a CPU that's ok to use Steam + EA play at the same time
* Many improvement from previous NFS
* The cop only appear in Runner race
* Higher Risk Higher Reward in the career mode
* NPC racer will do mistake like human being
* Hangout = Free roam in Open World + Customize Race Route
* Speedcross = Mixture of Score Attack
* Vanity Item = Nitrous Color, Tire Smoke Color, Underglow & etc
* Common "esc" button for in-game menu is replaced by "tab" button
* Auto sync with EA account progress, if we buy on Steam

[h1] 💎         COMPARE TO OTHER NFS:[/h1]
* Route Setup in multiplayer
* A better world map
* More fast travel location
* Many options to upgrade a car
* Larger garage capacity
* More offroad racing
* Day and night cycle
* Vanity rewards available
* Better speedwall (friend leaderboard)
🎯 Compare to NFS Unbound & Heat ➜ [u][url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/expectationchecklist/discussions/2/4042609814927677500/]Show Me[/url][/u]

[h1] ⭐️         SAME GENRE COMPARISON:[/h1]
* Arcade handling
* Drag racing available, but just a few
* Diverse character respond base on player behavior
* Diverse visual customization on car
* Downloadable community car livery design

[h1]  ⚠️        RUMOR CHECKING:[/h1]
* Cannot play because no activation code ➜ There is no cd-key if we purchase on Steam
* Downgraded graphic from nfs 2015 ➜ nfs payback may look not photo-realistic but still high quality visual provided, and it performance faster than 2015
* No buy, it is pay to win ➜ That is optional, still win without any extra payment
* Repetitive grinding ➜ Not happening in 2019
* The cop is easy to escape ➜ Player have optional to changed to weaker car to challenge the cops

[h1]Very good[/h1]

For a somewhat modern entry in an increasingly dying and progressively mediocre franchise, Payback does quite a lot of things right, even though it bears hallmarks of modern games like useless DLCs. The story is appropriate to this kind of game, with minimal amounts of forced cringe (like in heat) and somewhat likable characters. 

The side content is plentiful and the questing system is really cool. The game has some rpg elements, where you can exchange your parts if you don't want them and gain bonuses for upgrading the car accordingly. The game doesn't feel like an empty shell of mediocre that is supposed to be enriched with multiplayer, and the end product is a fun singleplayer experience

All in all, one of the best entries in the rebooted NFS era 2015-2023

The need for speed series what to say  I grew up with the good old times when NFS was still good  with NFS underground and the Original Most wanted being still the best NFS game till today

Now from all of the modern NFS I think payback was the one that looked the best and has the best reviews so I  grabbed   it now on sale for 2.99 and lets see  

The car handling is just again what the hell    do you even know how car physics work EA  driving with 300 kp/h in a hairpin turn  and just hit space and you slide around it  your car is basically glued to the track you can take every turn with with full speed just hit space . You car can also break from 300kp/h to 0  or make a full U turn on full speed in like 1-2 sec mean EVEN GTA5  which is not even a racing game has WAYYYYY better car physics

They even put Microtransactions into this game too to pay 5 $ to reveal all points of interest on the map  yes how low can you sink please    that,s more than I have payed for the hole game 


Oh and did I mentioned the graphic settings  they consists ONLY of the following
Motion Blur  On/Off
Screen Resolution
Vsync  On/Off
And a Preset general graphics quality low/medium/high/ultra   not modifiable further
That,s all you can set in the graphics options no advanced or customisation options nothing

I don,t know if I will ever buy another need for speed maybe when there,s a new developer and not freaking EA  then ill give it a try no wonder all NFS are trash they push out a new game every year of course it,s not good when you only have like 1 year to develop it good games take  YEARS to develop maybe you should start from scratch give the NFS series a break and reboot it with a good game in a few years 

If you want a good racing game forget NFS  get yourself wreckfest / GRID / forza horizon/ or if you more into very realistic racing games Dirt 2.0  maybe EA  can learn from those on how to make a good game again 

The only good thing I can mention is yeah the graphics look pretty good on ultra  and there is some sort of story in the game but that,s it for the Positive 

Result : Refunded  Not even worth 2.99$ for me  better get yourself 3 or 4 beers

All the physics bugs are still there. Still has that awful steering that seems mostly random. Winning races is more luck than skill especially with the kamikaze AI on every corner. And the 30fps cutscenes look awful in contrast to the 4k/120fps in-game.

Despite the shortcomings it's still fun. It has a ridiculous plot, lots of side quests, hidden derelicts to find, lots of police chases, it's all there as you'd expect in an NFS title. It's a 6/10 which is good enough for a thumbs up. But if you're time poor or cash strapped, there are better games to play.

Locate the savegame

Save game location at My Documents, the folder name Need for Speed(TM) Payback. Delete it.

Deactivate the Auto-Sync

1. Start steam online and launch your origin launcher.
2. Disconnect your internet or use airplane mode.
3. Start the game.
4. Steam will say they failed to loaded the save because your internet off and ask you wanna play anyway, click yes.
5. The game will launch and you can see it will show the prologue again.
6. In here you already can connect your internet again, the game will automatically replace the old save with new save after you quit the game

[h2]Review:[/h2]
Need for Speed: Payback is a good arcade game with a decent story. While I do recommend picking the game up if not played already, the story tends to get repetitive/boring after a couple of hours and I'd just like to get on and race instead of listen to adults act like kids for the 13 hours I spent playing the story. Personally, I've noticed some issues with the story, decisions that make no sense, and a lack of player personality connection to the narrative.

[h3]Character Impressions:[/h3]
Having "100%"ed the story, my feelings towards the characters have solidified. Unfortunately, I find myself disliking all the characters except for Mac. Big shout-out to my man Mac for standing out amidst the rest. His character brings a unique and enjoyable element to the game (he's British).

[h3]Future Updates:[/h3]
While it has issues, I'm committed to "100%"ing the game. I'll probably update this review as I progress further.

Rating: ★★★☆☆

"Need for Speed Payback" is the latest installment in the long-running racing game series, and it attempts to blend the adrenaline-pumping thrills of high-speed chases with a Hollywood-inspired storyline. After spending five hours with the game, it's clear that Ghost Games has made some strides, but there are also a few speed bumps along the way.

Graphics and Sound (★★★★☆):
One area where "NFS Payback" truly shines is in its visuals and sound design. The game boasts stunning graphics, especially when cruising through the diverse landscapes of Fortune Valley. The cars are meticulously detailed, and the lighting effects during night races add an extra layer of immersion. The sound of roaring engines and screeching tires enhances the overall experience, contributing to the game's sense of speed.

Gameplay (★★★☆☆):
The gameplay in "NFS Payback" offers a mix of traditional arcade-style racing and a heavy emphasis on story-driven missions. While the racing mechanics are solid, the introduction of a progression system tied to vehicle classes and a card-based upgrade system feels somewhat forced. The need to grind for performance upgrades can be a bit tiresome, and the reliance on loot boxes to acquire parts might leave some players frustrated.

The game introduces three playable characters, each with their unique skills and storylines. However, the narrative is predictable and occasionally cringe-worthy, resembling a B-movie script rather than a gripping plot. The inclusion of cinematic sequences during races is a nice touch, but they often disrupt the flow of the gameplay.

Open World and Exploration (★★☆☆☆):
Fortune Valley is an expansive open world, but it lacks the depth and variety found in other open-world racing games. The map feels underutilized, and the lack of meaningful activities or side missions can make exploration feel like a chore. The absence of a day-night cycle limits the visual diversity, making the environment feel static over time.

Multiplayer (★★★☆☆):
Multiplayer in "NFS Payback" offers a mix of races and events, providing a decent extension of the single-player experience. However, the progression system's influence on multiplayer can lead to unbalanced matchups, with players who have invested more time in grinding for better parts having a significant advantage.

talia fico

Fun and varied driving in beautiful landscapes! The game provides a well-sized open-world populated with multiple racing disciplines, collectables and minor activities. Enjoyers of Burnout Paradise may find themselves right at home in Fortune Valley. Car-customization is also good, and the livery editor in particular is quite freeing!

The story is typical action-movie fare with archetypal characters presented in a feelgood manner. Getting to play three different characters who all cooperate and communicate throughout the game made me feel more invested than I'd typically feel with the nameless self-insert found in other racing games. The story set-pieces are spectacular and provide some thrilling drives (although some cutscenes might have worked better as gameplay).

Payback does not have free-roaming cops like you'd expect from Heat or Most Wanted(2005). Instead, cop chases are limited to specific events and story missions. I think this works well for the game, as it allows the player to explore and complete activities to their heart's content. I think abruptly being forced into a chase would quickly become annoying if all I wanted to do was play around with a few drift zones or hunt down the last piece for my derelict car.

While I agree that the slot-machine upgrade system is a bit shit, it hasn't actually been a hindrance to my progression in practice. In my experience, the game provides enough resources to let you upgrade what you want when you want to.

[h1] Need for Speed Payback: An Underrated Classic in the NFS Series [/h1]

"Need for Speed Payback" often finds itself under the shadow of its predecessors, but I believe it's a game that has unfairly received its share of criticism. Despite its arcade-style physics, a hallmark of the NFS series, Payback manages to deliver an enjoyable racing experience that outshines its more recent counterparts.

The arcade-style physics, while not groundbreaking, stay true to the series' roots and offer a familiar and fun driving experience. In my opinion, Payback surpasses the two most recent NFS titles, and I find myself consistently returning to it whenever the need for high-speed thrills arises.

Is the game worth it? Yes, but the price tag of €29.99 for a title that's over 5 years old might be a bit steep. I would argue that a more reasonable price, around €20, would make it a much more attractive proposition. At that point, I'd wholeheartedly recommend it to racing enthusiasts looking for a classic NFS experience.

The story in Payback is engaging enough, providing a solid backdrop for the adrenaline-fueled races. The gameplay itself is a highlight, delivering the fast-paced, intense racing action that fans of the series have come to expect. While online play can be enjoyable, finding a lobby may be a slight challenge, but the overall experience remains positive when you do.

In conclusion, "Need for Speed Payback" deserves a second look. Its arcade physics, engaging story, and enjoyable gameplay make it a hidden gem in the NFS series. While a price adjustment would make it an even more attractive option, it's a game that's worth considering for fans of high-octane racing adventures.

The game is pretty good and underrated. The menus look good, easy and a bit weird to navigate.

Graphics are good but they could have been better, especially the character models and there is a day and night cycle, however the weather is simple with only sunny days while nothing else happens, which is pretty disappointing. The world could have used some extra work to make it feel more alive, especially in the city and some other specific areas.

Sound is great, loud and burning with excitement. Music is just great, there is a good variety and it just goes well with the racing and i never really got bored of the songs.

Story is nice but nothing interesting happens while it tries to make it seem that way. The dialogue is fine, it can be a bit funny or a bit overused and distracting sometimes. Ending is average and somewhat rushed.

Game play is quite fun and i played it on medium difficulty. The map is great, it's big, diverse and the races can be very long but enjoyable. There is a good amount of racing options and while some are not that great they do fill the map in a very nice way and going through the different areas is a pleasure. It is nice and easy to progress until you are required to upgrade your cars a lot since you need five of them for the main types of races as each car is chosen by you for the type of event it will be used for the entire game. It can take a while to finish and you can get stuck due to the upgrade system being based on RNG and your car not being able to keep up later on, however i didn't really had a problem with it since i had enough upgrade cards and combinations to progress nicely or i would just buy from the shop whatever card helped more for each car. You get one card per each race as well. The AI can be challenging and pretty aggressive which sometimes makes it very hard to catch up, but i never had a car properly upgraded for the number the event recommended. Customisation is nice and cool but most of the parts need to be unlocked by doing the tasks required which can be a bit annoying. The speed feels good especially later on and it is boosted a lot by NOS which sounds like a plane taking off and it's just amazing. There is a nice amount of cars to choose from and as always more cars could have been added but the upgrade system would just make it even more annoying to upgrade them all if you chose to do so.

Single player and Multiplayer are combined which is very good here in particular, again, due to the upgrade system.

Minor issues i have that affected my experience a bit:
 - the cards that you get with one car can never be used for another.
 - Having to buy a car for each event is one thing but to have to upgrade it again even if it's the same car for all of them is just stupid and since you cannot share cards makes it even worse.
 - dialogue during racing is fine but eventually becomes a bit annoying and it would have been nice to have an option to turn it off.
 - a lot of cut-scenes cannot be skipped which is stupid even more so after you've seen them once and there isn't an option for this as well.
 - events during racing are fine but they could have been done during actual game play by the player instead of showing what happens.

Biggest issue i had is that there is an actual slot machine that can get you the cards with the upgrades that you need and it uses the extra cards that you sold for it as currency. Terrible idea to add such a thing in the game.

Overall i did enjoy the game a lot even though some of the design choices are just bad.

[h1]The House always wins…[/h1]
In a world where racing games weren’t striving hard enough to one-up cheesy blockbusters, one franchise steps to the plate, and most notably replaces the word “family” with “crew.” [b][i]Need for Speed: Payback[/i][/b] touts quite the adventurous story, and an expansive scope, but how much of that is any good?

Have to say, Frostbite 3 might not be the smoothest game engine around, but it sure is pretty... sometimes. Garage close-ups of cars and vibrantly lit downtown areas are some of the best views you’ll get in this title, with great shading and model qualities. Compromises are apparent when you look closer to your usually shiny car: reflections are toned down or even absent, no matter if you’ve wrapped your ride in chrome. Daytime looks visually flat despite its vibrant colours. Human animation is a weird mix of bad and good, with nice details but poor posing and timing.

Just one notch below the highest graphical settings, my [i]Ryzen 9 3900X, 64GB RAM, 1070 Ti, Windows 10 Pro[/i] system runs the game at 60fps and 1440p resolution, with occasional dips to the 50s when passing through dark tunnels. Gamepad controls are unrebindable and you have to make do with just two presets… This is how I also realized keyboard controls are rebindable, and not actually bad.

[h3]Air Mac![/h3]
Oh boy, the dialog is just awful. It might’ve banked on the cheesy presentation of mid-2000’s street racing movies, but… come on now. Poor delivery, repetitive self-congratulatory statements from the main characters, forced lines and a generally obnoxious feel to it. Trust me, you’re hardly missing out if you mute it entirely.

Sound design is a little better, thankfully. Aside from being on the quiet side for some reason, even with all sliders at the maximum, you have decent car noises and environmental effects. Finally, music is mostly harmless: a few really good tracks are buried in a sea of generic rap, country and rock. Some standouts are the composed pursuit soundtrack and the Speedcross-exclusive songs. There’s an attempt to reduce repetition by “theming” the score based on time of day and location, but in practice it achieved the opposite.

[h3]-Not bad, Tyler, but you’re still gonna lose.
-I already won. You just don’t know it yet.[/h3]
After a disastrous heist attempt on a high-tech hypercar and the subsequent splitting of his gang, resident boy-racer and self-proclaimed best driver in faux-Las Vegas Tyler Morgan re-assembles his crew with overly-happy British™ person Mac and straight-faced Jess. Helped by a group of slightly less insane characters, one of which being the victim of the prologue’s attempted heist, the protagonists seek out vengeance against the one who sabotaged their heist, and save Fortune Valley from a tyrannical cartel by beating a bunch of gangs at street racing.

A totally ridiculous premise where any genuine tension is broken when racers trash-talk with weak lines such as “gonna CRUSH you”, and totally shattered because the leagues are pretentious butts who are “mistreated and outcast” for literally performing illegal activities.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2869512682
[h3]I see myself… winning it all.[/h3]
At its core, [b][i]Need for Speed: Payback[/i][/b] is a thoroughly arcade-like racer, where the best lines are taken by drifting through corners rather than holding on the edge of grip. This, in itself, is fine. What’s less fine is the handling model’s specific details that undermine this. Instead of throwing your car’s back end out, the handbrake sooner makes you [i]understeer[/i] for a good while. Drifting response, stability and turning circles are, at best, vaguely communicated, and you won’t know if a car is a boat to drive until you invest some good time and money into upgrading and tweaking it. The worst part about this is that the cars generally drive the same, though some weird choices remain dominant over all others – as the likes of 911 RSRs can attest in online play.

Being a modern entry into the franchise, customization and player expression are a big deal. Thankfully you can bet that most every car on display has at least some body parts to pick through. Wider fenders, different rims, a different front and rear end, and a couple generic rear wings with the occasional unique spoiler – not a bad showing. I must give particular praise to the livery editor, which is not only powerful and host to some high-quality wraps, but all can be applied to any car at will. Add some vanity tyre smokes, a lower stance and neon lights, and you can really stand out
[h3]The cards are coming down.[/h3]
Yet while [i]visual[/i] customization is fine, [i]performance[/i] customization is terrible. You have performance cards with specific brands and bonuses attached to them. Buying from in-game stores yields only higher-level cards with barely any bonuses. The ways to get good cards are by either repeatedly grinding out events, or rolling a literal slot machine to get the right combo of stats boosted. Live Tuning, independent of performance cards, makes too little difference towards a better-performing or -driving car.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2869511017
You’ll cover a sprawling map, open for exploration after the prologue with perilous serpentines, wide highways and grid urban layouts. Its size is on the larger side, but you don’t really need even more boring desert to offroad through. Events are split across six different disciplines, which means you’ll have to upgrade at least six different cars, independently of each other. Some discipline-specific gripes include Drag events also including straight-up races and [i]time attacks[/i], in cars that pop wheelies even when stock; and offroad cars are very eager to go airborne and still have an awkward speed limit off the pavement.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2869511562
Meanwhile, another series staple – police pursuits – are sadly locked away in either linear-course events or as part of open-world “bait crates”, where you drive to a nearby destination without getting busted. Their lack of escalation and predictability are a huge shame when considering how solid the pursuit gameplay itself can be. Dodging oncoming Rhinos and shunting cops out of range of their ECMs are a right rush.
[h3]An artist can turn any scrap into a supercar.[/h3]
The main story takes about 20 hours at a leisurely pace, taking you through five chapters and several blockbuster-caliber heists along the way. Past that, exploration is incentivized via collectibles and score-attack sections on the map, which reward cash and rep, and unlock visual customization categories. Rep grants you shipments, from where you unlock vanity customization and get a massive influx of cash and card parts – the Deluxe edition’s free shipments can actually turn the atrocious upgrade system into mere tedium. Meanwhile, beating street leagues gives clues on finding derelicts scattered around the world. Catch ‘em all from generally obvious map indications, and you’ll have another set of free cars to customize and upgrade to your liking. Roaming racers are but a momentary distraction, and finally, multiplayer is actually still alive, if quite limited. Open-world activities generally revolve around simple impromptu drag races with no one bothering to do much else; Speedlists with PvP racing work fine and you can stand a chance to win even against overpowered cars.
[h1]…Well, not tonight, it didn’t.[/h1]
[i]Peak cinematic flair with minimum substance, charm and consistency makes [b]Need for Speed: Payback[/b] difficult to recommend in general; due to its upgrade system, it’s better to avoid entirely.[/i]

This game unquestionably takes the crown as the worst in the franchise, and it's not even close. The cars feel really strange, and locking the customization of the cars behind "challenges" is such a foolish idea.

1. The card system is the most ridiculous thing Need for Speed has ever done in the series.

2. Every time you want to upgrade a car, you have to fast-travel to garage, enter garage, select desired car, fast-travel again to tune shop, enter tune shop and see that the cards you need are missing!

3. The story of the game is interesting at the beginning, but after a while it becomes boring to death! The game races at the end of story are very long for no reason!

4. You have to make pointless jumps in different corners of the map to make derelict cars!

5. Police cars in this game are destroyed by looking at them, their presence or absence has no effect at all!

Overall this game is good for relaxing if you buy at the lowest possible price, but it will never be a good Need for Speed.

'm a huge fan of the NFS series and I've been playing them actively since Hot Pursuit in -98. Not one of these games has ever had an exceptional storyline. They've always been cheesy at best.

I see some of the comments being about how the story should be the core of the game, and these people have clearly not been playing this franchise very much. The core of the game is to show off luxury cars and emulate the feeling of driving them in beautiful surroundings. This is simply not a storyline franchise, and that's ok.

I haven't played it yet, but it does sound like a progression system that encourages grinding could be an ok addition to this game. I know there are lots of maps in some of the previous games that I like to drive just because it's really fun to do that.

Valid criticism for an NFS franchise is definitely the upgrade systems. That's always been one of the aspects of the franchise that has bothered me the most; NFS is exceedingly bad at it and this should be a high priority in making the games more fun.

Conclusion:

For full price - Not recommended

Need for Speed Payback is an exhilarating thrill ride in the gaming world! As an avid player, I was blown away by the intense, high-octane racing experience it offers. Here's why I think it deserves a solid 5-star rating:

Immersive Storyline: The game delivers a compelling narrative that keeps you engaged throughout. The characters are well-developed, and the storyline is gripping, adding a new dimension to the racing genre.

Stunning Visuals: From the sprawling landscapes to the intricate car designs, the visuals are nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in every aspect, be it the cars or the environment, is commendable.

Diverse Gameplay: Need for Speed Payback doesn’t just focus on racing. It offers a variety of gameplay styles, including thrilling heist missions and heart-pounding escape sequences, providing a well-rounded and engaging experience.

Customization Galore: The level of car customization available is mind-blowing. From tweaking performance to the minutest aesthetic details, it's a gearhead's dream come true. The sense of ownership over your vehicle is unparalleled.

Multiplayer Excitement: The multiplayer modes amp up the adrenaline even more. Racing against friends or strangers online adds an extra layer of challenge and excitement, ensuring endless hours of fun.

Overall, Need for Speed Payback is a masterpiece that caters to both casual gamers and hardcore racing enthusiasts. Its combination of gripping storytelling, stunning visuals, diverse gameplay, extensive customization, and multiplayer options makes it a must-have for anyone seeking an electrifying gaming experience.

If this game were shipped without "Need For Speed" branding, it may have better acceptance, but what happend back then especially MTX controversy is what makes this game really pales short and NFS Undercover-y based storyline.

I do not have any expectation when I played as I treated it as "Single player NFS Undercover-copy" game, overall it was decent although some of stuff are inconsistent (looking at you Ghost Game physics).

Story and game progression reminds me NFS Undercover and I think some fanbase really did hate it I think considering previous entry are more felt like Underground as Ghost games back to Tuner roots (which definitely everyone back then expect a "Sequel" in sense of something like "2015 but 2"). I kind of enjoy the whole but during the ending, felt like something is missing post-game.

Gameplay... my only comment for this one is the physics. How come something like Rally homologation cars have worse handling in Off-road compared to something out of 50's Americana heavy car which jerry rigged by your local mechanics. I cannot tell about meta cars since I did not even bother continuously playing online on this game.

Tuning Progression is the most controversial thing on this game for me, for some reason you have to equip cards and you cannot jump straight to highest tier of performance card (the one that randomly available from shop).

If I wanted to give it rating, I'd give Payback 6/10 as a racing game, 4/10 as NFS game.

I am Speed!!!

This is an ambitious attempt to blend high-octane racing with a cinematic narrative. Set in the fictional Fortune City, this game aims to capture the adrenaline-fuelled spirit of fast paced racing. But does it succeed? 

You fight against Street Leagues, Street Leagues are racing crews, each with a distinct style and boss, each one of them race in their turf in and around the city. Defeating these leagues to get to the top spot and contest in the top league and payback for they did to you, and thus the name!

There are several types of race events in the game, that requires each their type of cars and you will drive as one of the three racing driver of your crew based on the type of event.

Race:
• Standard circuit races on paved roads.
• Compete against opponents in a lap-based or sprint format.
 
Drift Race:

• Slide your car sideways through corners to accumulate points.
• Drift events emphasize style and control.

Off-Road Race:

• Off-road events require sturdy vehicles to take the action off the beaten path.
• Race through dirt trails, forests, and rocky terrain, Rally-style races through dirt and mud provide a refreshing change

Drag Race:

• Short, intense sprints on straight roads where timing and precision are crucial.
• Master gear shifts and nitrous boosts.

Runner Events:

• High-speed escapes and pursuits to evade the cops usually in time-bound getaway.
• Also there are time-bound delivery missions 

Speedcross Events (DLC):

• Introduced as DLC, Speedcross mode adds a fresh twist to the original game by combining traditional racing with obstacle-filled in huge man made arenas.
• Perform stunts, jumps, and drifts to earn points.

Roaming Racers:
• Roaming Racers are members of street leagues who drive predefined routes across Fortune Valley. Challenge them at 3 different tier to lure out their boss and win the league.

Review: 

The Best:

Heist Missions:

• Some missions involve heists, where you steal high-value cars and escape with very intense chase. These missions are very good and feels super satisfying with great cinematics in between, these missions inject excitement and and a sense of urgency into the story.

The Good:

Visuals and World Design:

• Fortune City is a vibrant, open-world environment with diverse landscapes, from deserts to urban streets.
• The lighting effects during day and night races are stunning.
• Car models and customisation options are visually appealing.

Car Customisation:

• Payback continues the franchise’s tradition of turning ordinary road cars into wide-body beasts.
• The customisation options are extensive, allowing you to tweak every aspect of your ride.

Arcade Racing Mechanics:

• The handling model is straightforward and easy to learn.
• Drifting around corners and pulling off jumps feels very satisfying.

The Okay:

Story and Characters:

• Unfortunately, the story lacks depth and emotional engagement.
• The characters do not connect with you. Even the protagonist feels artificial.
• The cut-scenes often interrupt gameplay flow and fail to deliver the cinematic impact they aim for.

Linear Cop Chases:

• The police chases lack the dynamic intensity seen in earlier NFS titles, especially old school title such as NFS Most Wanted (2006).
• They follow a predictable pattern, making them feel repetitive, not much of a challenge and easy to evade.

The Bad:

Upgrade System and Grinding:

• This upgrade system is the worst, it's like a mix of lottery and loot-bag, and the parts you get randomly applies for only the car you drive that moment.
• To unlock better performance parts, you’ll need to grind races and events.
• The upgrade system feels tedious and slows down progression.
• Improper use of cash system for upgrade, by the end you'll end up with too much cash.

Dialogue and Voice Acting:

• The dialogue is cringe-worthy at times.
• Voice acting struggles to make characters relatable, feels very artificial.

Overall Need for Speed Payback is a mixed bag. It offers a diverse range of race types, from high-speed circuits to off-road adventures. Roaming racers add an extra layer of challenge, and the Speedcross DLC injects even more excitement into the mix. While it nails the arcade racing mechanics and car customisation, its weak story, grinding mechanics, and lacklustre dialogue hold it back. If you can overlook these flaws, you’ll find an enjoyable racing experience. I’d rate it 7 out of 10. I am a long time player of need for speed franchise from its inception. Played every single title so far, so the rating is slightly favoured.

In the end, Payback doesn’t quite reach the bar it has set. However, if you’re a fan of arcade racers and love tinkering with car mods, it’s worth a spin. Buckle up, hit the gas, and chase those super cars across Fortune City!

Played on Steam Deck, here my optimized settings:

• CryoByte's CryoUtilities: installed and set to recommended settings, frame buffer set to 4 GB
• Compatibility layer: GE Proton 8-11
• Refresh rate / frame rate lock: 50 hz
• Graphics settings in game: Low
• Controller layout: Specter NFS Payback Steam Deck (disables gyro controls which are enabled with default layout)

The game takes a pretty long time to launch, at first you might think it doesn't work but just let it load for a while and it will launch eventually.
