Don't recommend because the cars handle like absolute shit. There is no ability to manage controller settings or input in order to try and mitigate how shitty they all handle, which I believe is a massive design oversight. Every car in this game feels sluggish and unresponsive right up until you tip the thumbstick over an invisible line, and then it starts oversteering you into a wall. If you barely even touch the stick to aim your car slightly in one direction then let go, it does the real-world equivalent of jerking the wheel abruptly, which, thanks to the semi-realistic physics in the game, upsets the car and ruins your ability to maintain a steady line. The best way I could describe the problem is that it feels like, instead of turning a steering wheel with a thumbstick, you are relaying instructions to the digital guy driving the car. He barely turns it until you SCREAM at him to start steering, and then, startled, he turns it all the way, causing you to oversteer...then you tell him he's steering too much, and he twists it all the way back to neutral causing an overcorrect, just like a real-life amateur driver. It's absolutely infuriating to drive a supposedly two-million-dollar car that handles like a shopping cart you're pushing backwards.

Every NFS game from Porsche Unleashed to Carbon has great controller steering with cars that feel responsive and linear. In those games, if you take your finger off the thumbstick it doesn't YANK the car back to neutral steering position abruptly. I was thinking about digging out the steering wheel to hopefully salvage this game, but frankly, if you only have a controller, don't even bother with this game.

How to make cupcakes in 9 easy steps!

(Make sure to do all the steps)

Ingredients
⅓ cup butter
½ cup sugar
1 tsp. vanilla extract
2 eggs
1¼ cups all-purpose flour
1¼ teaspoon baking soda
¼ cup milk

Step 1
Cream together the butter with the sugar until light and moist.

Step 2
Add the vanilla extract and mix it in.

Step 3
Add the eggs to the batter. (Put the eggs in one at a time, and make sure to mix well)

Step 4
Add the flour with the baking soda and milk. (Mix well until all bits of flour disappear)

Step 5
5
Preheat oven to 350 °F

Step 6
Line your cupcake pan with cupcake liners.

Step 7
Add the batter into the cupcake liners. Fill them half up.

Step 8
Bake the cupcakes for 15-20 minutes. 

Step 9
Let them cool for a little bit

Need for Speed Payback, as with any recent Need for Speed game, has [b] extremely cringe [/b] writing, delivery, and moments, making you wish for any interactions to just not happen so you can go straight to racing. Speaking of, racing in this game is fun, there's different types of races (regular, drag, offroad) and they are all fun to play in their own way, and this makes the game worth a play, if you can get through all the obnoxious writing choices. The police chases in the game are practically non existent apart from a few events in the game, and they are all pretty lame, so if you are looking for a Need for Speed game with good police chases, this is not it.

According to me and my Gaming experience, i recommend more NFS PAYBACK type racing games..the story line was just perfect only that i wish i would have more of such from developers aligned with movie and series producers to create something that you can enjoy playing instead of Netflix. my honest opinion.
nice game bruh

The game was kinda fun overall, but it felt too much as a grinding game. Take the following with a grain of salt, since it is mostly subjective:

>> The good:
- The game still looks pretty good.
- Some of the races were pretty entertaining and the vistas are pretty cool, even tho they are not the best in the series. 
- The music is allright and the sound design is actually decent.
- The drifting felt satisfying.

>>The bad:
- TF is that story? Mobs and gangsters and street racing mafia? I mean, it is enough to carry you through the whole game without really questioning it, but it is so cheesy.
- The handling felt allover the place, it lacks consistency. 
- The grinding for cards is unbelievable.
- The cops. Jesus they are so dumb and useless. After a 2 minutes chase, i could just simply accelerate and lose them.
- The lack of cops in freeroam, but this is just a me problem I guess.
- The traffic. What the hell is wrong with it. I feel like this game has the worst traffic AI/spawn in all the NFS games I've played. 

>>The UGLY:
- The damned upgrade system. Really? Cards? With a luck element to it? I get it, it is story related, casino tied and all, but did you guys really needed to place a "Spin the wheel" mechanic to such an important part of the game? I was lucky to get the Deluxe Edition with supply crates so i can get lots of tokens, but if not for that, i feel like it would have been a hell of a grinding game, more than it is already.
- The damn drag races events with time trial/sprints using GODDAMN DRAG CARS. The handling was already weird, the choice of sprint racing using drag cars was a really bad one, just to make the game longer or to troll the players, i suppose.

[b]I recently played payback and I was sort of disappointed. I wont comment on its handling as I played it with the Unite Mod, but I would say play the game with that mod, as it adds a lot in the game, but mind you, that will make sprints in any drag-build impossible as the car will refuse to turn. [/b]
[b]What I liked:[/b]
[b]1. The map is actually pretty cool and way better than Heat's map with its scenic views, dynamicness, and elevation changes.[/b]
[b]2. Outlaw racing was a cool idea and it added some variety in racing.[/b]
[b]3. It has a lot less collectibles, which I like a lot.[/b]
[b]4. Derelicts (FH's Barnfinds) around the map was a nice idea.[/b]
[b]5. Drag racing. I really like that this game had it.[/b]
[b]6. The story. I know its cheesy and all but I still liked it, because at least it had length.[/b]
[b]What I didn't like:[/b]
[b]1. The lack of cop chases in free roam.[/b]
[b]2. Scripted story missions.[/b] The story missions would have been way more interesting if they were dynamic, like we had to actually escape the cops in some missions.
[b]3. Lack of racing at the start of the game. [/b] The presence of story actually hurts this game, as in the start of the game, there are barely any races, and leveling up doesn't help a bit. Would have loved if the game had a bit more racing and the boss missions took place on these tracks.
[b]4. Lack of rewards.[/b] This game doesn't give me a good reward for any of the side missions. Like after collecting everything, or beating all crews in Outruns should have rewarded us with something, but there isn't much.
[b]5. It's nitpicking, but the setup of the story.[/b] They just start the game with Lina betraying the crew. Why, never explained. And that it difficult to connect with the story. 
Overall, the main problem with Payback is that is struggles the basics, especially at the start. And the next installment, trying to correct the problems left out all the good stuff of Payback like derelicts and Outruns and instead gave us more of collectibles. I wish Ghost had been given a bit more time here to add free-roam cop chases and more races at the start...

At first i thought that people were too harsh on this game, but the game is filled with bad decisions.
1. The class and upgrade system, come on, just let me put anything i want on anything i want, and please, dont make me use a character i dont want to (tyler is the less annoying one).
2. No free roaming cops is a problem, i know they said it would be annoying in a map this big, but it was as simple as making it a player decision, as well as you can change difficulty, switch free roaming cops at will, after all the difference with the bait crate system would be that there would be an actual chase, like in older nfs, these ones are a joke.
3. Drift races are very bad designed, at first the points you have to reach is absurd, obviously you can if you memorize the track and make an almost flawless run, but i didnt purchase nfs to get a driving geometry dash. And then, later on the required points are just a joke. Its very weird, it starts hard and then becomes very easy.
4. Drag races, dont know whose idea was to put dragsters in sprints and time attack races, but its the dumbest thing i seen. For context, drag cars just dont turn, if theres something in front of you, you will crash into it.
5. Offroad races, boring and frustrating at the same time, very inconsistent behaviour of the cars.
6. Story is crap, not that i mind that, just stating it.
7. The game scams you quite often, up to the point it appears to be on purpose.
On the other hand, i liked the graphics and the available cars, i would liked to see some others but its a good selection. Soundtrack has a good variety with only one or two tracks i didn't like but its ok overall.
I purchased it on sale, will play it once, complete it and most likely not play it again.
Also, for some reason shipments are not working.

Payback is a special episode of the Need For Speed ​​franchise.
Closer to a modern Fast & Furious than previous games, the game offers epic missions and classic races.

The story takes place in Fortune City, a sort of Las Vegas.
The Clan, a sort of mafia that controls the entire city, steals cars and fixes races, makes a lot of enemies.
They attacked the wrong people, your Crew.
You will have to take revenge for their misdeeds.
To do this, you will have to defeat other Crews to rally them to your cause and to access the Outlaw's Rush.
It's the biggest race in Fortune City!

Several types of races will be offered to you:

- Classic street races, sprints.
- Drift races, quite an art.
- Offroad races, worthy of Rally games.
- Speedcross races, offroad where you have to do stunts, drifts, jumps and destruction.
- Drag races, where gear changes are manual and technical.
- Varied missions: exfiltration, delivery, or theft.

You control three characters who evolve in an open world and each have their own personality and specificity:

- Tyler, specialized in street racing and Drag,
- Mac, the king of Drift, Offroad and Speedcross,
- Jess, the fastest and most efficient driver.

There is large choice of cars, logically divided into several groups: Racing, Drift, Speedcross, Drag, Offroad, Mission...
The customization is endless and the choice of parts is plethoric.
The very nice soundtrack, focused on Rock N'Roll and Rap / Hip-Hop, 
with artists like Queens of The Stone Age and Gorillaz.

Some downsides are to be deplored:
- The strange behavior of vehicles, with bizarre physics, like other NFS games from Ghost Games.
- The "Speedcards" system to improve the performance of your car.

NFS Payback is a very pleasant episode to play, with rich content and a storyline worthy of Hollywood.
Enough to have a good time for around twenty hours.

I love a good heist, no matter the medium.
And that's what always intriqued me about [b]Payback[/b], so with a recent sale, I thought [i]"Hey, why not?"[/i].
That was my second mistake.
The first one was me thinking I would enjoy this after heavily disliking and bailing out of [b]Need for Speed: Heat[/b], its sequel, after about eight hours last year.
My third mistake was playing this for way longer than I should have.
At about ten hours I have had enough.

[b]Need for Speed: Payback[/b] is terrible in my opinion.
The story is boring, brings nothing new to the table and both story sequences and cutscenes seem to lack a ton of polish and heart. Worse, the characters are cardboard cutouts of your basic street racing-/heist-related tropes and barely exist outside of quips and stilted back-and-forths.
The gameplay consists of the usual bullshit brake-to-drift physics (seemingly somehow worse than in the 2015/2016 reboot), making every car an understeer monster, fighting you at almost every corner and taking both the control and the fun out of driving your car, no matter the upgrades.
You know, the basis of what should be good in a racing game.

What should also be good and enjoyable in a racing game are the tracks or in [b]Payback[/b]'s case, its open world, titled Fortune Valley, which is a rather mixed bag. The non-city parts are alright, featuring various serpentines across multiple biomes and even allowing some verticality for a more varied environemnt. The city parts however are difficult to navigate, mostly because of a confusing layout, which is compounded by the fact that the minimap doesn't differentiate between tarmac roads, dirt roads, alleys and shortcuts. Also having absolutely no information about elevation differences doesn't help either.
The open world is also only partially [i]open[/i], because a lot of the country roads are actually corridors and don't allow you to drive through roadside barriers, making it hard to discern what won't and will stop you on a collision. Worse, this also happens in the more urban environments, where some walls, fences or sidewalk objects are destructible, while others are not. That huge steel lamp post? No issues. That tiny tree on the sidewalk? Na, sorry, will completely crash your car.

Visually the game looks okay, but the game world has a really boring color palette during the day and for somehow being a fictional version of Las Vegas, the main city is barely alight during the night.
It also doesn't help that for some reason [b]Payback[/b]'s the only Frostbite [b]Need for Speed[/b] game, that doesn't fully work with an ultrawide aspect ratio? Not like [b]Need for Speed: The Run[/b] in 2011 had that already figured out and all.

But the worst for me is the gambling upgrade system (there's a reason [b]The Crew[/b] dropped that with the sequel) and the unbalanced races/missions (although those aren't helped by everything above either).
After beating any mission or race you get a new upgrade card, which is randomized. This can either be a really good upgrade or not.
If you don't want to equip the card you can either stash it (which makes it only useable for this very specific vehicle!!!), sell it for cash OR trade it in for a card point (which can be used for any car!).
For three card points you can then spin the wheel and get a random upgrade card. Out of the three available attributes of the wheel you can freely lock one (car part, brand or focus type, the last one being, for example, about top speed or acceleration), while the other two are randomized. But again, for the cost of three cards, you can gamble for a new one, one which might also not be good and also isn't useable in any other car.
But as long as you win your races, take on some of the bets during them and not switch/buy too many cars, you should have enough cash to get the upgrades you need, it might just take a bit for the upgrade shops to refresh their inventory after enough real time has passed.

And speaking of the races, as long as you got the right car level, the road and drag races were fine for the large majority. No weird rubberbanding ai drivers, but also not really a true challenge, despite playing on hard.
However the drifting missions and offroad races were annoying for the most part.
Regarding the latter, the camera on offroad segments is way too bouncy and offroad cars are really drifty off the road, which seems kinda counterintuitive, if you ask me.

[i]Short tangent: I really do not get why all these modern sim-cade racing games want you to jump your car so much? Your fucking driving physics aren't made for that. Stop it![/i]

And regarding the former, despite often being several car levels above the requirements and knowing how to drift well in most games, I did not have a lot of fun in a lot of these races, because the whole drift physics just never seem to work out like you'd expect a car to behave. It does give you control over the car, but not in a way that makes sense, to me, which coupled with the weird road and curve designs, it just wasn't fun.
In the end it was a drift race that made me stop playing, so I dunno. Normally I'm all over drifting in games, but maybe not in current Need for Speed games I suppose. I thought it was fine in the reboot, for what it's worth.

Oh and almost forgot, the cops are horrible. They're either wrecked in seconds or can bring you to an instant stop while going 200 kph without taking any damage. But the worst part is that you do not escape police chases and you're never free to chose any route, you're always (!) following a choosen route and when your near the end, the cops will just fall back and you'll escape. Which isn't completely true, because I managed to escape while still being only meters away from three cop cars. It's just all a farce.

And honestly, I could go on and on, there's so much that just isn't good in this. I tried going in with reserved expectations, but I'm still really disappointed.
Maybe it is time to dust off those [b]Carbon[/b] and [b]Most Wanted[/b] discs and finally play some good [b]Need for Speed[/b] once again. Too bad you can't get those anymore.
Just... stay away from [b]Need for Speed: Payback[/b].

[b]Not recommended.[/b]

[b] Graphics: (8/10) [/b] Cars and environment look good. Effects are also in a good spot.
[b] Sound: (8/10) [/b] The soundtracks for NfS games are always pretty good. Car sounds also pretty good.
[b] Gameplay: (6.5/10) [/b] It's fine, the modern NfS arcade-y feeling of sliding around. It's not as bad as it was in Heat but this was probably the beginning of the end.
[b] Characters: (7/10) [/b] There are a few standout characters that are pretty charismatic, too bad its not our protagonist. The voice acting can be laugh out loud bad at times.
[b] Story: (7/10) [/b] The story is fine, what puts it over the edge is the payoff at the end.
[b] Cop Chases: (2/10) [/b] They exist, only in events.
[b] Cars: (5/10) [/b] The selection is what you would expect, not as good as Forza Horizon 4 (which came out only a year later). With the performance system all cars end up feeling pretty same-y. Shout out to the inclusion of the 240DL.
[b] Upgrade System: (6/10) [/b] They opted for a “Card Based” system for upgrades. Luckily not bound to microtransactions. The system is alright once you figure out which brands work the best. 
[b] Overall: 6.4/10 [/b]

NFS payback:

+ it has a good action story (Although too much of it happens in cutscenes) and I like the setting in general
+ the car customization is great
- I didn't really like how the cars control, I don't know why  - physics in arcade racing games are allway subjective though
- The menus are all controller oriented (a non issue for me, but worth pointing out)
- The upgrade system is nonsensical (and features gambling, yay)
-seriously, just watch the story on youtube and buy NFS Heat or something
- I can't feel the speed in this one (no sense of speed, even in the bumber camera it's poor)
So, it's like a 6/10, it works, but why would you buy this one?

I am writing to enthusiastically recommend the "Need for Speed Payback Deluxe Edition" to anyone seeking an exhilarating and immersive racing gaming experience. Having spent significant time with this title, I can confidently attest to its exceptional qualities that make it a standout choice among racing enthusiasts.

Here are some compelling reasons why I wholeheartedly recommend the "Need for Speed Payback Deluxe Edition":

Engaging Storyline: Unlike many racing games, Need for Speed Payback incorporates a captivating narrative that follows a group of protagonists seeking revenge against a nefarious cartel. The storyline adds depth to the gameplay, making it more than just a series of races.

Stunning Visuals: The game boasts breathtaking graphics and attention to detail, ensuring that each race feels like a cinematic experience. From the intricate car models to the dynamic weather and time-of-day system, the visual fidelity is truly impressive.

Diverse Vehicle Selection: The Deluxe Edition offers an array of iconic cars, from classic muscle cars to modern supercars. The extensive customization options allow players to create their dream rides and truly make them unique.

Challenging Races: The game offers a wide range of race types, including exhilarating pursuits, intense off-road adventures, and high-speed highway battles. This diversity keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting, catering to a variety of racing preferences.

Immersive Open World: The game features an expansive open world called Fortune Valley, which provides an open-ended environment for exploration and racing. The vast map offers numerous challenges, collectibles, and hidden secrets to discover.

Online Multiplayer: For those who enjoy competing against other players, Need for Speed Payback Deluxe Edition offers an engaging online multiplayer mode. Race against friends and players from around the world, adding an extra layer of competition and excitement.

Regular Updates and Support: The developers have shown a commitment to the game's community by providing regular updates and patches to enhance the gameplay experience and address any issues.

Great Value with Deluxe Edition: Opting for the Deluxe Edition ensures you get access to additional content, such as exclusive cars, customization items, and in-game currency, enhancing the overall value proposition.

In conclusion, the "Need for Speed Payback Deluxe Edition" is a remarkable racing game that combines thrilling gameplay, an immersive storyline, stunning visuals, and extensive customization options. It offers a comprehensive racing experience that caters to both solo and multiplayer preferences. Whether you're a die-hard racing fan or just looking for an exciting gaming experience, this Deluxe Edition is well worth your investment.

I wholeheartedly recommend "Need for Speed Payback Deluxe Edition" as a must-play title for any gaming enthusiast. It delivers an adrenaline-packed racing adventure that is bound to keep you entertained for hours on end

story can be a little annoying and in your face. it has all the energy of an early 2000s game but coming from a game released in 2019 its not very charming. the game play is amazing though. with the same customization options as heat. (i know this game came out before heat but heat was the game i started this series with) the drifting and car handling feels a lot better than heat to me though especially drifting. maybe i just wasnt doing it right but the customization for your gear in heat could get really confusing for someone really casual like me. this game takes that away with having specific dealerships for each class of car. i gotta say drag is maybe the least fun as its just a normal race with a quick time event but i still appreciate its inclusion in this game anyway. to sum it up all around, solid game play, fun challenges, serviceable story (sometimes engaging sometimes annoying) and a lot of customization. if you like arcade racers and feeling cool youll probably like this a lot ! hope this was helpful :)

Need for Speed Payback tells the story of how the little guy wants to take down the big bad boss. 

The game has many things you can do: You have essentially three different car classes to choose from that are race, offroad, and runner and these are the main elements of the game. You also get additional car classes such as drifters and rally cross cars that are to be used in events dedicated to them. 

Within the forementioned main car classes you have to take on The Roaming Racers, race events where you have to work yourself from the ground up to face the bosses of different car clubs and by defeating them gaining money and popularity. In addition you have small challenges placed throughout the map that you must try to win (speed cameras, drifting events, and such). All of this is to give body to the main story line in which you cannot necessarily proceed without doing those small additional tasks.

The game is good fun and I personally found the drifter and race car classes to be the most enjoyable to play. The story line cutscenes were, in my opinion, quite cringeworthy, but besides that the quests themselves were good.

Good arcade car game, would recommend. Just hit the gas and drive fast!

Since I left my first review on Payback I've had chance to play Forza Horizon 5 and found it quite disappointing. I think I was too harsh on Payback! Its fun, the driving experience is actually a bit more varied than in FH5 (where all terrain feels the same!). I'm the kind of player that uses the search to find pre-made tunes for cars in FH5, so I found the card game feature in Payback quite entertaining too. So yeah, disappointing FH5 experience has changed my mind a bit on Payback.

Original negative review: I bought this for £2.49 on sale. It's barely worth it even for that. I appreciate that 'arcade racer' often means a less-than-realistic driving experience, but this is seriously poor. It's just so boring. I've played for an hour and not found anything so far challenging. The racing is just a case of getting to the front of the pack after two corners and then casually driving in circles. Police (or other) chases are simply frustrating - it feels like GTA Online, where enemy vehicles just rubber-band to you like crazy and catch up to you out of nowhere. Not realistic at all. The free-roam activities feel like cheap-as-dirt Forza Horizon rip-offs.
While the plot is intriguing, the cutscene dialogue is cringey and the voice acting is mostly terrible. Almost vomit-inducing. There are also the silly lines that characters say while in-game: "Let's kick this up a notch!" (My word, I bet the writers all patted each other on the back so hard for the 'cool' lines!) My best guess is that a big share of the lines came out of the bin in the back of the Fast and Furious writer's room. Absolute garbage.

Need for speed in Fast and Furious style.

Gambling is the name of the game. It is reflected in the upgrade system and the pre-race bets, besides resonating deep within the setting. Heck, even one of the caricatures, I mean characters, is frequently addressed as 'The Gambler'. EA, being EA, pivoted the game on it, with the sole intention of maliciously preying on the innate nature of angsty teens, relatively new to the racing genre.

Gambling aside, the game might be a competent arcade racer with decent visuals, featuring a suitable driving system for the map, a formulaic but fun story, and; hold your breath, the best off-road racing of any arcade racer yet; but as it stands now (thanks to the heinous micro-managing by the tyrannical overlords, EA), it is nothing more than a disheartening waste of Ghost's immense potential.

Title: Need for Speed Payback: An Action-Packed Ride with Room for Improvement

Rating: ★★★☆☆

Need for Speed Payback, developed by Ghost Games, offers a high-octane racing experience with an emphasis on intense action and cinematic storytelling. While it delivers on its promise of adrenaline-fueled races and thrilling heist missions, the game falls short in certain areas, preventing it from reaching its full potential.

One of the highlights of Need for Speed Payback is its captivating narrative. Set in the fictional city of Fortune Valley, players follow the story of three protagonists seeking revenge against a nefarious criminal cartel. The story's structure resembles a Hollywood action film, with heists, betrayals, and intense rivalries. However, the execution of the story and character development feels shallow at times, lacking the depth needed to fully engage players.

Controls... LOL... Whoever made the keyboard mapping has never played another PC Game ever. Every control you would expect, is not. ESC is not the menu. WSAD arent the default driving (despite past NFS games doing this). Q/E are menu left/right (WTF). +/- or Up/Down are not zoom in/zoom out for the map, Ctrl/Shift are. And you cant change these, its ridiculous.

In the 4 races I played during my time, the driving mechanics were terrible. Drifting is a joke 'Double tap <left/right> and hard corner' its just a ridiculous thing to try to do when you're also taking the corner. What happened to rip it (handbrake) and crank it. Steering mechanics in general are pretty terrible, Its almost as if there is a large delay in releasing the button press, because the car will lunge in unpredictable ways. The Cop chase in the beginning, also terrible, roadblocks instantly appearing in front of you kind of terrible.

Remember the fun of damage from days past (NFS Undercover, etc), yeah no more... The joys of seeing your and rival cars smashed up as they hit things is gone... theres no 'penalty' to drive better other than you get slowed down.

If you like being handheld through an 'open world' game, sure, go play this, but otherwise, find something else. :sadtrombone:

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him in the online mode. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and I cant wait to make future memories with my son.

[h1]Payback (2017) is, in my opinion, the first enjoyable Need For Speed game since Carbon (2006).[/h1]

One of the main reasons for this is the meticulously crafted open world that features the right balance of dense city spaces, wide open roads, and dirt roads along with verticality in the form of canyon trails and jumps. The map is a perfect playground for the game's different event classes, such as racing, off-roading, drifting, drag, as well as cop chases. The events are well-routed and diverse, but can feel overly scripted at times, especially the cop chases which are sprints along predetermined routes.

Racing gives you an adrenaline rush and offers a great sense of speed. The vehicle roster, performance upgrade system, and visual customisation are mediocre, but the cars look and sound good. Handling is satisfying and accessible, and varies by vehicle class.

The story is bearable for a Need For Speed game and winning events does give you a feeling of accomplishment. The plot is not grounded in reality, but that's alright for an arcade racing game that was inspired by the Fast & Furious movies. Progression is formulaic and straightforward. The dialogue, however, is more often than not, very cringe worthy — unsurprising for a Need For Speed game.

If you enjoy arcade racing, then Need for Speed Payback is worth checking out.

[h1]Overall rating: 7/10[/h1]

A little background before I begin: I was a huge fan of need for Speed growing up, and played Underground and Carbon religiously. Sometime after Undercover, I stopped playing until the past year when i finally gave Heat a shot. Once I completed  the story in Heat, I found myself wanting more of the gameplay, but had absolutely zero interest in the style of Unbound.  So Instead I picked up this game, knowing the reviews are not great... it isn't as bad as I expected! but there are definitely some big flaws. 

Pros: 
- I actually prefer the driving mechanics in this game over Heat, it feels more snappy and realistic, and doesn't seem to force you to only drift everywhere. Muscle cars are somewhat viable!
-While still not at the level of  the games i remember, the soundtrack to this game is a million times better than the dumpster fire of a soundtrack Heat had. 
-I like the fact that there were so many different race options, and the runner jobs were a nice break from constant racing.
-I am always a big fan of barn finds and such, so the derelicts were fun, i wish there was more of them. the derelict super builds were also very cool to get.
-Vehicle customization seemed very robust and  it never felt I had not enough options for fenders, bumpers,  etc. 

Cons:
-The biggest frustration i have with this game is the speed card system. in theory its pretty neat, and If they simply allowed speed cards to be transferred between vehicles it would have made the game much more fun. Instead its a constant grind  of doing the same races and trying to earn lootboxes for trade ins. on this note, having to grind the same lootboxes for smoke and horn customizations was incredibly tiring. 
-I went into the game expecting a cheesy story, its a staple of any racing game. however, this definitely is really cheesy. 
-While almost all of the characters in the game are unlikeable (Except for maybe Jessica and Rav), I hate Tyler Morgan more than any character I have ever played. it is like the game devs decided "Let's make a character whose inspiration is Lightning Mcqueen, but without any of the charm or personality!" Every time he friggin speaks I want to just shut off the game. 
-Game physics are sometimes very annoying, too often i found myself  hitting invisible walls, being reset after ive already landed on my wheels and started driving off,  or being arrested when i had clearly started accelerating away from the cops already. 
-It would have been nice  if there was some sort of tangible reward for completing the jumps, speed traps, drift zones, etc. 

All in all,  i would buy it cheap as a decent time waster as long as you keep your expectations low. Forza Horizon, this is not.

Overall I'd say its a decent game. Nice cars (no Supras of any kind unlike 2015 sadly), isn't online only like 2015, same cosmetic system, nice open world, kind of lacking in action, grab it ONLY when its on sale. 

The one MAJOR drawback is the upgrade system. Holy hell is it miserable. The way the upgrade system works is you get 6 parts you can upgrade. Engine block, headers, exhaust, ECU, turbos, and gearbox. However unlike more traditional games, you get speed cards. So lets say, you have a 2010 Crown Vic Police Interceptor (I'll talk about that in a bit), by default the speed card levels are Level 8 on the CVPI. So to upgrade, you go to a tuning shop and either buy a Level 7 ECU or whatever. Or you can go to the "trade-in" which is essentially a slot machine. Here, you can lock in one category. Part type, brand, or stat type. Locking in one of these means, the other two are random. So if I want an ECU upgrade, I'll get a random brand, plus a random stat upgrade. What does all of this mean? Well the parts upgrade is just parts upgrade as mentioned. The brands, when you combine 3 of the same brand, or 6 of the same brand (or 3+3 of two brands), will give a boost to certain stats (think faction based boosts from RPGs) The stats? Power based (HP, top speed), Acceleration based (0-60, 1/4 mile time), Nitrous based (duration and power), "stunt based" (airtime based stuff), and brakes (Not handling oddly, just brakes). When you get a speed card which is usually (but not always) 1 level up from what you have equipped in that part slot, it could be any of the 5 brands (6 if you include stock but that isn't available), and either 1, 2, or 3 stat boosts (HP, Acceleration, or Brakes, or all three). As far as I'm aware, there is no way to buy speed cards from the shop with all three stat upgrades. I've only ever seen two at most. So if you want the most ideal build, you want either 6 cards of the same brand, or do a 3+3 combo (two diff brands of choice), THEN you need to get a good combination of stat boosts, and all the speed cards NEED to have ALL THREE STATS. This all seems confusing, but when you play, or look up images, you'll see how this can be a PITA. Not only that, but you only get a limited number of spins at the trade-in. You can get more via trading in duplicate/older cards. Point is, upgrading cars can be pretty miserable. You'll be stuck trying to get the perfect combo of speed cards for hours, maybe days. WORST PART. The cards are for THAT car only. You can't transfer them over to another car of the same class, or even the same car but in a different class (say, an Offroad Subie STi to a Racing Subie STi). So you have to do this for EACH INDIVIDUAL CAR YOU OWN. I'm gonna be real with you, just go download or open up Cheat Engine and give yourself infinite tickets to spin at the trade-in shop. Get mods or something. Don't torture yourself trying to build the ideal car.

Customization is nice. My only issue is that you need to play the game to unlock the ability to customize certain parts. Heat solved this by just letting you immediately start slapping on bodykits. Not sure if its because I had a shortcut DLC purchased on Heat. Either way, you're gonna have to get a fair bit into the game in order to unlock all customizable parts. The only other issue is, sometimes its hard to figure out what parts you need on a car in order to use specific parts. Some parts can only be installed if you have certain parts installed. Doesn't say which pieces are compatible, you just gotta install the corresponding parts and check again to see if it can be installed.

Gameplay wise, controls were pretty lacking IMO, you only get like 2 controller schemes for auto and manual mode. Manual Gear shifting layout is kind of weird to me and since that can't be changed, stuck with what they give you, at least Heat has decent control schemes even if its also 2+2 auto/manual like here. Unlike 2015, this game has skippable cutscenes THANK FUCKING GOD. I've said in some other review, I don't really care about the story in any NFS game. Just a personal preference. If its an action game, story is the least of my concerns. BF4? Cringefest, wouldn't want anyone to spectate me playing the SP. BF3? As much as I enjoyed the story and tone of SP, too dark probably for many. NFS 2015? Cringefest. Don't want anyone to suffer those unskippable cutscenes. If I'm watching a friend play a game, don't think I'd want to sit around trying to figure out the story half-way into their playthrough.

The world is a bit lacking IMO. Coming from NFS Rivals being my main NFS for a while, I'm used to cops and racers all roaming around the world at all times. 2015 at least had cops sitting around in random places. Payback? Cops and the House (?) rivals or whatever are only available for Chase type missions. No freeroaming cops. Freeroaming racers is nice, but no cops, no risk, and honestly even the Roaming Racers are kinda meh, still prefer Rivals open world. Great for hooning around and just cruising though.

Overall car list is good I guess, my only issue is with "Abandoned Cars". So when the game was still new and cool, they had these cars that were available as "abandoned cars". Cars scattered around the map, that you can collect, bring back to hideout (while evading cops) and you get the car permanently. Every week(?) they'd rotate out abandoned cars, one week its the BMW M3 GTR, next is something else. Well, here's where the Crown Vic comes into play. the 2010 CVPI was one of these cars. However, this car was only available TWICE. According to all google searches and posts I can find, it only ever appeared twice in the game. Eventually the support for the game was cut, all resources directed to NFS Heat. Abandoned cars are now actually abandoned and unobtainable. You can't get these cars anymore. Well...sorta. The M3 GTR for example, can't get it as is (namesake and all), but you CAN buy all the abandoned cars in stock form, then build them into abandoned cars (E46 M3 + GTR bodykit for example). They aren't the same IMO (M3 GTR is named M3 GTR, E46 M3 with GTR kit is still named E46 M3, so technically separate). All except the Crown Vic. This car only ever made two appearances in the Abandoned Car roster, then disappeared forever, never to be obtained again...unless you use mods. Which I did. Without mods or if you're on console, you'll never get the CVPI. Ever. Bummer.

Speaking of CVPI, for some reason this car is capped at 365 performance rating. Every other car is 399 max. Without mods, the CVPI maxed out at Level 16 speed cards at 365 PR. Mods just allow it to get Level 18 (max level) cards to bring it to 399. Turning the mod off = cap says 365 but performance is actually still 399 (when you pull up to events, it'll display your CVPI's actual PR if you have 399 and your level 18 cards will remain equipped/in your inventory/swappable, however in the tuning shop, Level 16 cards are the only ones that are available to buy/trade-in). Just odd how the CVPI seems very neglected. Sure its not an amazing car, but its certainly cool as fuck. Also I'm particularly biased because I own one myself....also the sound of the car in this game is dogshit. Don't think any game has an accurate sounding CVPI tbh. Wish the CVPI got more love in this game but oh well I guess.

Conclusion, fun game, cool cars, LOTS of offroading to be done in this game, derelict cars, customization. The only big flaw for me was the upgrade system. It allows for more diversity because its essentially RNG based (the stat upgrade combos that is) but having an ideal setup for all your cars, not enjoyable. I'd give it a shot. Also if you REALLY want the Crown Vic Police Interceptor, you'll absolutely need mods. Otherwise, unobtainable. Shame how neglected that car is in this game.
very good but needs more players
The best NFS game on steam. I just wish it didn't have the upgrading system that it has and it would be a 100% perfect game.

[b]Gameplay – 6/10[/b]
Need for Speed Payback’s handling physics are not realistic at all. I don’t really think it’s possible to grip drive in this game, handling is heavily geared towards drifting through corners at high speed. Personally, I enjoy arcade racers; despite the unrealistic handling physics, I still find driving to be fun.

The performance upgrade system in Need for Speed Payback is probably the most controversial component of the game. In other Need for Speed games, performance upgrades can be purchased and equipped from the garage. In Payback it’s a bit different, Speed Cards are earned by winning races, purchasing from tune up shops or rolling on slots. Speed Cards have various different bonuses such as increased acceleration, nitrous, jump airtime and braking. Speed Cards can be equipped, stored, sold for money or sold for slot tokens. Initially, this feels pretty confusing but after playing the game for a few hours, I didn’t really find it to be a problem. I actually quite like the way that the upgrade system rewards the player for frequently using a car and allows for builds with different focuses.

There are several different event types such as circuit/sprint races, drift events, drag races, police escape runs, off-road races and speedcross events. The variety of event types helps keep the gameplay feeling fresh. Cars can only be used for specific event types, a car bought from the Race dealership can only be used in circuit and sprint race events. I like this as it forces the player to use a variety of different cars.

Need for Speed Payback has a huge selection of cars and customization options available for them. Definitely a high point in the game.

The game is set in Fortune Valley, which is a fictionalized version of Las Vegas. Need for Speed Payback probably has the worst open world designs in the franchise so far. I understand why there’s so much desert in the game, but it feels boring and repetitive to drive around in comparison to other Need for Speed titles.

Unfortunately, Need for Speed Payback is very easy, even on the harder difficulty modes. I’d have liked the game to offer a bit more of a challenge.

[b]Story – 7/10[/b]
As with most racing games, the story is not a focal point in Need for Speed Payback. It’s definitely one of the better stories in the franchise though.

The story is focused around three playable characters. Each playable character has their own missions that lead up to main story missions involving all three characters. I liked this approach to storytelling as it helps add some depth to the characters - something which is often missing in racing games.

The main story missions include plenty of cinematics, they’re way over the top and remind me of scenes from The Fast and Furious movie franchise.

[b]Visuals – 8/10[/b]
Need for Speed Payback looks amazing, especially considering that it’s a six year old game. The car models are incredibly detailed.

The visuals are slightly let down by the previously mentioned open world design. The open world is graphically impressive, but unfortunately this doesn’t save the bland design.

[b]Overall – 7/10[/b]
Need for Speed Payback’s bad reputation had put me off playing the game for years. I picked the game up on sale and I’m glad I gave it a try. I think the game gets an unfair wrap and is definitely worth trying for yourself.

[h1]Before playing the sequel (NFS: Heat)[/h1]
It's an alright game with a lot of potential which is sadly held back by its shady practices (i.e. microtransactions) and weak character writing. I feel like I can't give this game a [i]thumbs up[/i] nor a [i]thumbs down[/i], because it's simply a mid-tier game.

[h1]After playing the sequel (NFS: Heat)[/h1]
NFS Heat in certain aspects makes this game look like a masterpiece. I came to appreciate NFS Payback a lot more and I actually think it's a pretty good game. I would much rather play this than NFS Heat, mainly because this one has a better handling system, story, map and event variety. Not to mention that this game's career mode is also much longer. I held myself back from writing a review for Payback, but there is so much good stuff here in comparision to Heat, I had to express my thoughts.

[hr][/hr]
[u]Gameplay:[/u] [b]8/10[/b]
This game is actually very fun. There is A LOT of variety in events and activities. The handling model is very arcade-y but super satisfying. The game is also decently long and it doesn't drag.

[u]Map:[/u] [b]7.5/10[/b]
The map has an unexplainable charm to it. Off-roading is soo good and the streets are also very well designed for all kinds of events. The downtown area is a bit small though and you can tell it wasn't the game's main focus point. There is also a surprising amount of variety, even though the map is mostly a desert.

[u]Progression:[/u] [b]7/10[/b]
The progression has actually been fixed by making the upgrading of cars less loot box based using "Catch-up Packs" which you can buy for in-game story currency. It's a bit slow at the beginning, but later on it's very good.

[u]Story:[/u] [b]7/10[/b]
Very strong theming ruined by weak character writing. Still very enjoyable and definitely keeps you going.

[u]DLC content:[/u] [b]9/10[/b]
MY GOD it is fun, WOW! They could literally make a standalone game with the SpeedCross mode alone, it is that good. Sadly, it's not very long.

[u]Car selection:[/u] [b]7/10[/b]
There is a decent amount of cars for each category. I actually don't mind having to buy a new car for each event type. I think it's a fun gameplay quirk which motivates you to buy more cars.

[u]Car customization:[/u] [b]7.5/10[/b]
Some cars have a lot, some cars don't. It's kind of a gamble but what you get in the worst case is still pretty decent.

[u]Music:[/u] [b]4/10[/b]
There is hardly any music in this game. It feels like 5 tracks are playing on loop all the time and it gets really annoying after a while. I recommend using your own music. This game is not as bad a NFS Heat though in this aspect.

[h1][u]Overall rating:[/u] [b]7/10[/b][/h1]
I can actually recommend this game. :)

Need for Speed™ Payback is a racing game developed by Ghost Games and published by Electronic Arts. The game is the twenty-third installment in the Need for Speed series and was released in 2017. As a language model, I don't have the capability to play games, but I can provide a review based on the available information.

The game is set in the fictional open world of Fortune Valley, where the player takes control of three characters, each with their own set of skills and unique play styles. The story revolves around the three characters seeking revenge on a cartel that has wronged them in the past.

The game features a wide range of vehicles, including cars, trucks, and off-road vehicles, which can be customized and upgraded to suit the player's style of play. The game's graphics and visual effects are impressive, and the open-world environment provides a sense of freedom and exploration.

The game's main campaign can be completed in approximately 20 hours, and there are also side missions and challenges to keep players engaged. The game also features an online multiplayer mode, where players can compete against each other in various races and challenges.

However, some players have criticized the game's reliance on microtransactions to progress in the game. In-game currency can be earned by completing missions and challenges, but it can also be purchased with real money. This has caused some frustration among players who feel that the game is pushing them towards spending more money.

Overall, Need for Speed™ Payback is a solid racing game with a great open-world environment and impressive graphics. However, the game's reliance on microtransactions may put off some players.

Progression sucks, they throw every car in your way hoping you would cargasm all the way through, which I don't get.. nitro was given to you right off the bat instead of earning it. I can't enjoy the story either, maybe I'm having high expectation for decent story in a racing game (they talk about Tyler's rent, why not put it in the game where you race to get money to pay rent? Story-wise, found myself skipping every single cutscene including even the intro or prologue, dialogue is super cringeworthy. 1/10 Refunded and will never play another NFS again.

Very much recommended game from my side. There are many pros and it is a nice experience playing NFS Payback.
- First of all very nice graphics and subjective feeling when driving cars.
- Tough races. I played on Hard, and that difficulty is really good and I think the way that should be played, because finally there is tougher NFS and we should honor that. So that is my recommended setting unless you need to lower it down.
- Many activities to complete. Yes, maybe some are repetitive but interesting to get them all anyway.
- Story is a little cliche but still it was nice to watch cutscenes.
- I liked the system of upgrade with cards and rolling for better ones.

On the negative side:
- Cars are not so much feeling different. Yes, driving experience is good but still I think that other NFS better presented difference in cars strength.
- Drag events are very easy and almost put for presentation, unlike other mods.
- I actually had to buy the DLC to show all activities on map. Some where almost impossible to find and buying DLC for 4.99$ for perfect game, which should always be part of the game. I mean WTF EA ?!

But all this said, I still very much enjoyed this game and will always recommend it. 8//10

Weird card-based performance upgrades aside, the game as a whole is great. Unironically enjoyed this way more than NFS Heat. Gameplay is varied and fun - both on road and offroad races, drift trials, drag races, cop chases that are legit fun, "runner" missions that involve all sorts of activities, and the wildly arcadey speedcross mode. Hunting down derelict parts out in the world was neat. Cars have a decent amount of visual customization, both body parts and paint/wrap. The story was expectedly cheesy, but the missions themselves were a lot of fun. The graphics are *chef's kiss*, except for the character models/animations which fall into uncanny valley, but the voice acting makes up for it. Overall, would recommend.

If you can find it for a really small price it's worth it, otherwise I wouldn't bother.

For me, personally, it's more fun than 2015's Need For Speed. Truthfully, the characters are rather forgettable and the in-game cutscenes are lazy, but first and foremost it's a racing game so I could care less about the characters as it's all about the gameplay, the feel and the sound which all happen to be pretty good. There's also lots to do, both in-terms of required missions and side missions, quite a few collectibles, etc. Graphics-wise, the game does not look like the screenshots and it's misleading as those visuals are only used in the pre-rendered cinematics and not in-game. Despite that... the graphics are pretty good, I'd say they're well-above average for a game released at its time. Though, 2015's Need for Speed style looked more visually appealing to me.

There are tiny or moderate annoyances that sometimes add up though like unskippable screens or ones that have a long delay before you can skip them, the lack of music variety (while the songs included are good and mostly fitting, they get samey and annoying to listen to and don't randomize enough), and sometimes the characters (especially Mac) are just cringe or make small talk that doesn't even have contextual sense. It is nice they react depending on what you're doing though. I'm not sure how I feel about the speed cards which are just these cards you equip on your car to make their stats better and on one hand it makes any car viable to use which is nice but at the same time it's really gimmicky and loot boxish. The respawn system is not good. At least in my experience it often respawned me against rocks, put me at fast speeds towards obstacles or cliffs only for me to wreck again. I ended up turning off the auto reset option for wrecks because it was really starting to trigger me due to the fact it took me less time just backing out rather than being reset two or even three times in a row. I also dislike the checkpoint rings and sometimes I would miss their edge by a tiny fraction and be forced to just restart the entire race because one big mistake is usually enough to make you lose on harder difficulties. I'd be at least okay with them if they were a bit larger.

I do have one major issue with the game though and that's the major stuttering and major FPS drops that happen in certain areas or certain events making it near unplayable. I have this game installed on an SSD paired with an i7-7700k, 32GB of RAM and an 8GB RTX 2070 on 1440p so this shouldn't be happening and it's rather annoying. After checking Task Manager, WMI Provider Host sometimes just ends up using an insane amount of CPU percentage while playing and I've yet to find out how to fix this aside restarting the game.

The most consistently enjoyable Need for Speed I've played since the Undergrounds. Payback is a very polished game with zero stupid problems bogging it down, as opposed to NFS 2015, for instance. Before playing, I was wary of the RNG performance part system and I thought I wouldn't really care for the offroad sections, but the part system's really not all that bad, and offroading is SUPER fun. Physics, controls and handling have vastly improved from its predecessor. Unlimited slots in your garage, great selection of rides, great customisation. To cut the fangirling short, I'm just going to list the few gripes I do have.

Criticisms:
- Anemic selection of vinyls
- Forgettable soundtrack
- Cop cars have Millenium Falcon engines and cannot be simply outrun
- The Speedcross series is fun, but is crippled by the fact you're locked into driving the Countryman on its 1st completion, and the selection of like 10 cars available to buy for speedcross afterwards, making the whole thing feel a bit pointless
- Performance tuning may be a bit too dumbed down for some folks
- ???
- That's all I can think of really
- Pretty much everything else is great, play this!

Loot boxes. This game does not try in the slightest to hide their presence, or in-game influence. The entire casino vibe and "the house always wins" message make it all the more egregious.

All the "vanity" customization items, such as flashy underglow neons and gimmicky car horns, are tied to them. While they are innocently cosmetic, the idea of dropping a few dollars for a [i]chance[/i] at them is utterly ludicrous and inexcusable for any game period, let alone for a primarily [i]single player[/i] game. The DLC cars, meanwhile, offer a tremendously better value for money and should be bought instead if you absolutely must drop extra money for this game.

Oh, here's the fun part. The game actively rewards you for accomplishments such as performing daily challenges and earning stars from activities with the same-said loot boxes. No exclusive decals or special cars from doing them like in previous games, just the same superficial RNG rewards the game regularly throws at you. The entire "level-up" mechanic is also designed wholly around dropping lootboxes for driving around and winning races, which oddly caps at level 50 but resets itself at the beginning of level 50 again perpetually every time the cap is reached so it can continue to dole out loot boxes like AOL CD's.

Okay game, though. So okay it's average.

[b]Update[/b]: All my save data was wiped without warning, likely due to the retirement of the Origin app. Uninstalled the game on the spot, no reason to play it anymore.

Overall the NFS Payback is good. Not as good as the classic NFS games or other arcade racing games (Forza Horizon, Flatout) as it fails to engage the player. Yeah, the graphics are good, the physics are not so good, the story is actually decent if it didn't have that childish vibe. But the game overall just lacks something that makes you want to play it, not even replay but simply play. As a matter of fact, it actually is more interesting to watch someone play NFS Payback than play it yourself. The speed card mechanics were, surprisingly, the ones that made me play the game (aside from the customization, of course), but they didn't last long. I played NFS Payback occasionally and uninstalled after forgetting about it for two weeks. Is it worth your money? Not the full price, that's for sure, but with a decent discount (maybe -80%/-90%), an urge to play something casual and low expectations it's a good game.

After two playthroughs, one on launch day and one with the Unite mod, I have come to some conclusions about this game.
Before anything, I highly, highly recommend playing the game with the Unite mod. Vanilla Payback is abysmal and I don't know how I managed to finish it back in 2017.

1- The game is significantly better with Unite mod. It completely overhauls the god-awful handling and fixes the stupid Gwent-esque economy, giving you lots and lots of opportunities to actually make the ride you want. I cannot express how much I hated this game but Unite guys changed my mind.

2- Story is meh like any other recent NFS games.

3- Multiplayer is surprisingly fun. It's a shame that not many playing are playing it. I suggest finding a group chat on Steam discussions.

4- The game definitely has/had potential and it showed that Ghost Games were stepping in the right direction. Just as I said in my NFS Heat review, please buy this game when it goes on massive sale.

It's a good game. Is it a perfect game... far from it. But it's fun. Quite a decent collection of cars. A pretty fun story (It has some cringe parts, but to me that just makes it even more hilarious). For driving physics, it's fine. Each class of vehicles feels different, and it's fun to play around with. (For anybody that wants a blast, get the vw beetle derelict parts, the beetle handles extremely fun, almost full grip is possible)

For achievement hunters i have bad news atleast at the time of writing this review. All achievements are good, except for 2. They are multiplayer achievements. They aren't hard, but you need a minimum of 4 total people to do them. And as you might expect, the games multiplayer is pretty much dead. Luckily the online achievements are pretty easy and straightforward. You just need to complete a full playlist (speedlist), which is basically 5 events, which takes no time at all if you have the people. And the other one you need to do 10 total ranked events (not full speedlists, just 10 events). So doing 2 speedlists will get you both achievements, which doesn't take long as long as you have the 4 minimum players.

Overall i would say it's a good game to buy if you like nfs. Especially if it's on discount.

[h1]When talking about Need For Speed, you know what this franchise is all about.[/h1][hr][/hr]But for this franchise for some reason, I kinda like it but there are 3 things I hate about. Let's talk about the hate. First, Upgrading car. Instead of buying parts with money, this franchise is using gacha system. Which is you'll use this casino slot machine to get a better parts or you can get it by replaying events or doing activities. The second one, if players want to customize a car, they need to complete some missions like 'Defeat a roaming racer', 'Reach 225mph' or 'Drift for 8 seconds' something like that. And last, Collecting chips.

Now for the good part. Reason why I bought this is the story. But at the end, I felt a bit disappointed with the last chapter but it was quite good overall, I like the cutscenes & the cinematic look. And then, while customizing a car, players can use liveries/decals from community. Driving was intense (especially when car chasing or drifting). Graphics were good & beautiful for photo mode. Just get this on sale in case you want to buy.[hr][/hr]Need For Speed (2015)

NFS: Payback

Well, this is interesting to say the least, here we have Need for Speed: Payback, a 2017 release by Ghost which developed the game, unlike some previous titles this focused a lot of single player story driver campaign... do yourself a favor and skip all cut scenes though, the story is absolute sh*t, very cringy to the point I wish the protagonist would shut the F*ck up.

Forget the story.. how the overall game and racing elements, well.. honestly pretty good, underground was better but i appreciate the overall experience, the cars look/sound good, the races can be challenging and I like the variety in all the events.

A couple things hold it back though, let talk about the card system, very unforgiving in my opinion, you get limited shipment so you are constantly upgrading 1 car at a time and if you unlock something new your grinding to get the car performance short to a level where it can compete, it turn making you buy micro transactions... f*ck that. Performance parts should be interchangeable between cars in your garage like many better titles out there, I am not paying to upgrade a car on your garbage shop EA..

Overall, I feel that EA has killed some great features here and brought about a boring story that your not invested in, given the 3$ price tag I can Over look some of the nonsense and say that for a cheap price it is good racing fun, a solid arcade racer got sure.

A solid 7/10 given you don't take it serious and forget paying extra for Microtransactions.

Tip car in each category for me
Racing - Lotus elige GT or Porsche 911 turbo
Offroad - Ford Raptor or Derelict VW beetle 
Speedcross - Mini countrymen GT
Drift -  Mazda RX7 
Runner - Derelict 1965 Mustang

Update - Nov 2022

[h1]Favourite NFS[/h1]
[b]Payback is easily my favourite NFS.[/b]
Story is very relaxed and doesn't interfere with you. Literally, do whatever! 
Want to complete world activities e.g. drifting, collectibles hunt, speed cameras and alike? Go for it!
Crave for story campaign? Pick up almost any car type and in-it-for-win-it!
Or... spend hours on gambling car parts - tuning is somewhat complex and fun mini-game.

[b]The BEST of Payback:[/b]
[list]
[*]Big semi open world. Huge desert area and 3 cities in the corners
[*]Customization and tuning. Lots of stickers and physical improvements to apply and those will be rendered in the story cinematics!
[*]Different car types and hence, races. There are 5: drag, drift, off-road, race and runner. 
Plus you can complete quests for recovering derelict cars and build your own!
[*]Very simple menu to navigate and ability to replay previous challanges for a better results.
[/list]

[b]More NFS games should be like Payback![/b]
Better story than Heat, Story feels more connected to the races unlike heat, SpeedCross is amazing and fun too! Offroad racing is superb, drifting dirt felt great!

Might be kind of unfair, but I couldn't even get through the prologue.  Drive for 12 seconds, shitty cut scene.  Drive for 10 seconds, repeat.  The characters suck, the cars handle like bricks then suddenly are very agile then go back to being bricks.  Crown Vics keep up with GTRs in chases.  Random shit in the road to make the drive more challenging I guess?  I crashed into a barricade because the car was a brick and the cops crashed into it with me, totaled their vehicles, and I drove off.
They set up the characters with like 2 lines each then you're supposed to care about them - no.  Don't shove narrative into a game artificially like that.  Play a GTA game to see how to set up characters and stories.
I get it's supposed to be an arcade game, not Forza.  The dumbass writing and acting is cheap.  I don't care about the story, betrayal, whatever is going on, it sucks.  People like the "started from the bottom" style NFS.  Just some kid on the street with a $3000 Civic Si trying to make some money and get big.  You can have characters like Uncle Lester in Midnight Club but you don't need cut scenes that show a grown man let a car get stolen by a 120lb woman while he's 7ft from the car.

Payback is what you would want from Need For Speed.

The campaign is fine , not too bad. Could've probably made it longer but it's fine. 
The cars are sick .

The main big problem would be the engine upgrades which is really boring where we need to technically gamble and hope for a part without actually having to buy what we want ourselves.
The races aren't a lot but the content is enough for you to keep on playing the game for 50+hours along with multiplayer free roam.

The upgrades are pretty good when it comes to the body kits and stuff.

The game doesn't have cops roaming around though so thats one minus point too but I didnt really miss them tbh.

There are missions that involve cop chases but they are eventually scripted and when there's a couple of miles left , they'll automatically slow down lol which is kinda meh.

Overall the game is great and worth playing but I think unless you have friends too playing here , you are better off playing the newer games unless you want to play that campaign.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I bought this game kind of expecting it to be another let-down, especially with my experience with the last NFS game I played, Rivals. That game lacked anything substantial and was as hollow as games come. Payback on the other hand proved me wrong and made sure I had a damn good time during the 90+ hours that I spent in it. There's a cringeworthy story here but it somehow makes you wanna see it through to the end, and it gives you purpose to upgrade your cars and manage your team throughout different racing disciplines. The opposition gradually becomes stronger and it's up to us to keep up with them.

I love almost everything about this game, the soundtrack, car customization, the intricate and vibrant open world, decent roster of cars to choose from, fast and chaotic racing events that vary from off-roads to street racing, it's a lot of good fun.

But there is one thing I dislike a lot: The Speed Card system

Speed cards is a terrible slot machine-esque performance upgrade system which utilizes RNG and gives you random ass parts. They should've just stuck with the classic way of upgrading cars through in-game currency. It worked for over a decade in multiple NFS games, but of course, EA needed to push for the lootbox/microtransations but luckily Ghost Games went out of their way to make it as useless and irrelevant as possible. Having to rely on RNG to get the upgrades we want is horrible but at least there is little to no grind for them. I'm glad that this system was removed for NFS Heat in favor of the more grounded and straightforward system of earning money to buy the exact parts you want.

The complete vehicle customization is back again from NFS 2015, (Thank god, I don't know what the fuck Criterion and Ghost Games were thinking with Most Wanted 2012 and Rivals) The visual ways one can boost their ride are plenty. From bumpers to neons lights, there's quite a selection of things you can customize, and there really were times when Payback reminded me of the Underground era. It's also got the amazing wrap editor where you can use all kinds of decals to basically create paintings on your ride. I love it. 

The handling is very arcadey but it felt much more down-to-earth than, say, Most Wanted 2012, especially at lower levels with slower cars. The cars are no longer rockets, they won't automatically start pre-scripted drifting whenever you make a turn, The driving actually feels really nice and intuitive. Of course, it's less so when you reach McLarens, Lambos and Koenigseggs, but even those feel good to drive.

Overall, I thought Payback was gonna be another mediocre NFS game but I had a hell of a time. A really well done arcade racer.

I'm tired of political pandering making it's way into games. Why is a BLM banner in the main menu of the game?  I get it, EA is "woke," and they think somehow pandering in a video game to a racist organization that is embezzling money at best and  a cowardly terrorist group at worse will somehow sell more games for them.  As if there's people that are holding up EA games side by side with other games and then going, you know, I like that EA (of all companies, given their shitty anti-consumer track record) supports BLM, I'm going to choose this one over the competition.

Extremely average at best. Almost every single game mode revolves around hitting checkpoints, so if you were a big fan of Superman 64 - this is the game. 

I hate the upgrading system which is presented as "speed cards". Tailored of course to fit the lootbox system which is as boring as it gets. On top of that, they give you fair amount of those for free, so that at the very beginning of the game I could afford almost every available car, fully upgraded. This of course makes the whole experience rather easy and shallow. Even without free lootbox cards, the game is fairly easy, even for a semi-advanced racing player.

Drag/drift races are boring, the "feeling of excessive speed" which the series was most famous of is severly lacking here.

If your expectations are low and you consider yourself as a very casual arcade driver - get it for like 3$ tops.

Bugs, problemas, carros com poderes mágicos, uma cidade que parece fantasma, uma sensação de estar sempre faltando algo, física que desliga pra ia inimiga, árvores voadoras (tem mesmo e você vai bater nelas), pistas que parecem cobertas de graxa e molhadas, história vergonhosa, roteiro previsível e bobo, falas e personagens que parecem ter saído do pior ano de malhação e assim temos um jogo completamente desperdiçado em potencial, roteiro, possibilidades e diversão. Tem momentos que você vai querer apenas terminar logo por ter gasto dinheiro neste jogo. Não compre se não estiver em promoção e mesmo assim ainda vai parecer que foi tudo teste para lançarem HEAT. A decent NFS, but is basically a lesser version than "NFS: Heat" ended up being. There is also some very odd choice.

The visuals are good, and the cars mostly handle fine. The sound is also pretty good, but i'd suggest rising the Cop chatter sound just so you know what they have in store next corner.
Talking of cops, they are kinda underwhelming? They are scripted, only appearing when the script tell them to be there. And they are not as aggressive as some other NFS. They are not too surprising or anything.

The visual customization is pretty good (And will end up the same in Heat too), changing body parts and a pretty good decals engine, allowing to make the car as you want. Or just go to the community tab and find a cool one you like.
The performance customization though, is the opposite and pretty terrible. You get "Cards" that will improve your car's performance and have some random stats and brand added to it, forcing you to (literally) spin the wheel to have a chance to get something you might want. It's just bad (and made to sell lootboxes)
It's like they swapped cars performance with some kind of RPG spreadsheets.

The story is... it can be fun, with ridiculous stunt and such, but it's overall kinda bland and end in a quite odd way. Probably because the devs didn't knew how to end a story like this in a proper way.

And the driving in itself is pretty much as expected for a NFS. Arcade but not "Mario Kart" arcade.
Though, the cars are very "light" in this version and have a tendency to fly off at the first bump. Not helped by the "Jumping" performance stats.

In the end, it's fine. But Heat is technically better in this kind of open world racing NFS.
But if you can get it for cheap, and are curious of the "Fast & Furious"-like story,  you can still have some fun with it.

imho after the original NFS: Most Wanted (2005, not the remake) the NFS franchise basically became worse and only a cashgrab series (like most stuff that EA throws out)...which is also the reason why i only bought the deluxe edition for 3€ instead of 30€ as i basically knew before that it will never be worth the full price for me.

to the game itself...
graphics are okay, but that was never really an issue in the NFS series.
the story is a boring revenge act, as already done in earlier titles and not being good.
the chases with the cops and "house" baddies are okay, but not that great (but better than in NFS Heat).
car customization seems okay, but not great in terms of available parts and is artificially locked behind stupid events like
"you wanna change the hood? do 3 jump events with x stars" (just as an example, as that goes on for kinda all parts).

while it made partially sense that you needed to buy different cars for different race categories due to it being realistically being a pain to re-configure every time, it was kinda boring that not all cars were available in all shops to make hilarious builds and the upgrade cards (not actual parts) can't even be used for the same car in a different category (like an Impreca Race car to Impreza Drag) or a different car in the same category (Impreza Race to RX-7 Race).
e.g i had a Subaru Impreza in most categories where available and also a few others for shitz and giggles and each car had to get it's own upgrades...no passing down between them and due to the handful of cards being changed only every 10min and being shared across all tuning shops it was annoying. you also always start from the bottom with a new car (until you unlock & buy upgrade kits and start from level x) it's somewhat of a pain if you want to play around with different cars.

I haven't bothered with the multiplayer, as i don't care about that in such games.
so all in all it's just a EA usual mediocre cashgrab title that may be okay to buy on such a huge sale (3€ instead of 30€) but otherwise not really worth it.

Need for Speed Payback is fun, challenging, and enjoyable. An open world car game with lots of fun new cars really works well -- as it did in NFS Carbon and Undercover. A diverse set of challenges and no reliance on a player finishing one hard one makes the experience really smooth. I lost a lot and was frustrated with some of the races where the crashes were really weird, but once I got a good handle of control, it became easier. The derelict challenge is difficult and the reward is really strange, but it does provide some extra challenge in finding out how to get to weird spots.
You may notice that I leave out the story. As far as story goes, this one has a lot and I really enjoy the variety of characters. It surpasses Carbon and Undercover, which are my points of reference. The story missions are fun, but they aren't the focus. It is cool how they tried to tie everything in. The runner missions felt like they were forced, but without some help from the player, a story-based racing game just isn't going to work.

I like the fact that they let the player play as each of the three drivers. It's weird for the player to not have a single character, but it's the only way for the player to be offroad, drift, runner, and racer at the same time.

The AI is still a little off -- like a lot of NFS games. Perhaps it's just my high standard for racing AI to expect good movement. I tried a few times to get them to slow down to make it easier for me and realized that they won't do that. That's an improvement for racers who want stiff competition. Along those lines, giving yourself a weak car is a huge disadvantage, which can truly challenge a racer who feels like the competition is too easy.
That's one thing this game has in quantity: there are a ton of weak cars to drive. My first experience was noticing the high race level of the Infinity. I tried it on a race with a lot of curves and couldn't get it to turn for anything. The player is not given any feedback except losing and crashing into the guard rails. This is the sort of thing that I like to see in a racing game.
The upgrade system is slow and every new car feels like a minor improvement. This sort of slow progress is how to teach people to play better.
Lastly, the game plays well on Linux using Proton. With my video card it really goes well.
