I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Looks like some real incompetent amateurs designed this game.  They apparently do not know that computers have a full keyboard, plus a mouse.  Also, they do not seem to understand that real games have the ability to re-bind keys to the players liking.  So these amateurs chose some very odd key bindings, & also they don't seem to understand that many would like an option to reduce or turn off the garbage music that the game keeps blaring.

When you first start the game you are restricted to the stupid key bindings they have, & there is no options to change them.  Later after you finally complete 1st chapter, then it finally gives you a chance to re-bind some of the keys.  But even more stupid is the controller binding.  It clearly shows the triggers for gas & brakes, but when in the game the left joystick controls those options, along with steering, which makes it nearly impossible to steer without messing up your speed.

And EA's requirement for Origin is another layer of crap on top of this disaster.  Origin doesn't add anything to the game, but probably makes it real easy for them to sell all kinds of information about you.

In-game controls are very, very clunky, requiring you to constantly look for their displayed bindings, since they decided it would be better to NOT use standard controls, & apparently make up random keys for doing things.

Also, so far I have not found a way to exit the game, so am always forced to use Ctrl, Alt, Delete to exit the game with Task Manager.  But at least in there I can also force close Origin, since I don't care for it being always on.

Another issue, is that the game has its own in-game voice chat, but we have not yet been able to find a way to disable it.  So we now get echos when using chat for gaming.  If we shut off our own voice chat program, then this games chat is to low for us to hear what we are saying.
Saddly they stripped off every single part of what I used to love from this series. And Its a good game, its just not a good Need for Speed game.

Janky but fun core gameplay with terrible loot system.

This is a racing game not a mobile gacha game, get out with those random speed cards!

Also the drift tracks and offroad races have very janky layouts. For instance a checkpoint might have a tiny rock right in the middle of it. It looks like it's should get bumped out of the way but nope it weighs a ton and stops your car completely. Or arrows that point you all the way down a hairpin but there's no checkpoint there, so you can actually skip the hairpin altogether. Finally, the story is so dumb and cheesy that it's actually good in a B-movie way.

I don't usually buy driving games, but when I saw Deluxe edition of NFS: Payback for 3$ I got greedy and bought it. The last NFS game I played was NFS: Underground over 10 years ago, so I was eager to see how the game evolved from then.
After playing for a couple of hours, I could see that it didn't evolve at all. Like its predecessors, NFS: Payback is an arcade open-world driving simulation. Realism doesn't have anything to do with this game - there is no car damage, all cars behave the same way and the physics are really bad. Most of the time, you'll get better results just crashing into the opponent than trying to outdrive them. The same goes for difficult curves - just touch the handbrake and hit the railing, the car magically goes through the curve.
The game consist of a bunch of story-driven races divided into several categories. The story is so lame and meaningless that I won't even mention the details. The car upgrade mechanics are terrible. The music soundtrack is even worse than terrible... I actually don't remember ever playing a game with such a lousy soundrack. I had to lower the music volume to 0 because I couldn't listen to that garbage, and played through the whole game like that.
Still, not everything in the game is bad. The graphics are decent and the game is relatively fun. The feeling of speed and acceleration you'll experience while playing was also done pretty well. For 3$, I guess that's enough.

Need for Speed: Payback is good for a bit of mindless fun, but nothing more than that.

My score: 6/10

Some things do not change, just like the NFS series.
 
[h1]Pros[/h1] 
+ Gameplay
+ Car customization
+ Graphics
+ “Story”
+ Multiplayer?
 
[h1]Cons[/h1] 
- Origin
 
[h1]Summary[/h1] 
It's a NFS alright? It feels pretty much identical to any previous one. Which is not a bad thing if it's what you are looking for.
 
The driving model is far from perfect, cars feel slow and heavy. It is very arcade racing.
I was also not a huge fan of drifting.
 
Car customization is decent for the number of cars available.
 
Pretty underwhelming story, but NFS was never about a story anyway.
 
Multiplayer feels a bit forced since there is not much to do and only 3 modes are available if I am not mistaken. It would not surprise me if it got shutdown anytime soon.
 
To be fair, I had not a single issue with the Origin launcher, the only minor annoyance was that the game appeared to launch twice if I did not have Origin open. But I know that launchers are make or break situation for some people.
 
There are a lot of better racing games, but if you are looking for some silly fun arcade racing game and manage to grab this in 80-90% sale I am sure it will be worth it. 
[h2][i]If it was not clear, the game is not worth the full price[/i][/h2]
 
[b]Playtime:[/b] 10 - 20+ hours
 
[b]Achievements:[/b] Easy (2 multiplayer achievements with 4 players required to start, I recommend doing them while you can)
 
[b]Overall:[/b] Recommended (if in sale 80%+)

Bought this for 3€ at sale. Only few hours in, but have enjoyed it so far. It's not perfect by any measurements. So far the soundtrack is forgettable. Driving on controller has felt smooth. It's not exactly realistic but as someone who enjoyed NFSU, 2 and MW back in the days, this feels pretty solid when it comes to just driving and racing.

The customization aspects, all of it, feels clumsy, and it's damn unfortunate because I was looking forward to that. But for the driving and story that seems okay, 3 bucks was perfectly fine to scratch that itch.

There's DLC, one is a car-pack (no idea if they're anything interesting) and one is simple marker unlock, which is simply a convenience thing, because you can unlock all of them by just playing.

EDIT: The game does have some technical difficulties with certain CPUs. Basically alt-tabbing over play session of some hours will ultimately lead to WMI Provider Host use all of the CPU available, forcing you to reboot. Found couple of tips for it, with one being playing in Windowed mode, and another creating an user.cfg file. While the video is for Heat, it seems to work for Payback as well. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YuPL-tVYCSI

EDIT2: Just have finished the story. This playtime is 95% just for story and the failed instances, didn't focus much on collecting things or maxing out challenges. No grind either. For the story, I'd say it's pretty good for what to expect in game like this. I would've hoped more epilogue of what happened after beating it, but ah.

ONLY redeeming feature is the fact that it looks incredible on my computer and runs at a staggeringly high framerate. Right. Nfs Payback. I basically finished it like... an hour ago, more or less. I want to get my thoughts out so, here we go. A heads up: I played this AFTER playing nfs heat and I have to say this: if you ever get into a situation where you gotta choose between this and Heat, 100% no doubt pick heat. It's just better at, like, ALMOST EVERYTHING.

With that said, let's officially get started with the review.

So NFS Payback came out in 2017 to... mixed opinions. And mixed opinions I do have, because whew, this is not a simple game to review.
Let me start with the positives: it's... fun, actually! Yes ladies, gentlemen, and everything in between: it's a fun game. It drives fun, the map is cool, it looks good, and it has all the things you love: insane visual and body customization, decent enough collectibles, good music (for the most part)... 

And a decent story. Yeah, I like the story in NFS Payback. I see it for what it is; an interesting idea, that is crippled and beat up beyond recognition by a bunch of shitty characters. This game's tone's real problem is the CHARACTERS. Because, like, a story about a crew that get used by a dar underground organization that rigs every race in the city and controls basically all the industry and politics and money of the place, and then they decide to bring it down to the ground by smashing their rigged races and beating their bought crews? Sign me the FUCK up, dude. It's a fun concept, and you can't tell me otherwise. The problem here is that it's played in the worst most cringe inducing way possible by a cast of characters that DO NOT BEHAVE LIKE THEY SHOULD FOR THE TONE OF THE STORY. [spoiler] But I love Mac. Mac is a cutie, he has a couple of embarrasing lines here and there but he is BY FAR the best character out of the entire story. [/spoiler]. Jess is a maniac at the wheel, she's edgy, constantly angry and acts like she's mentally insane, but she isn't. She isn't awful but she definitely isn't great, either. And she's the worst proliferator of what I'm gonna call "MCU Humor". You probably know what I mean. Tyler is just generally embarrasing. He has it all: stupid one-liners, dialogue that makes you wonder if he was written by a fourteen year old or an extremely disconnected forty year old in a suit. Rav is just kinda stereotypical: "Oh I have a background with the army so I know everything about tech" which... doesn't really make a lot of sense. (But I might be missing details, so feel free to call me out on anything). And Lina Navarro... Man. She's just so nonsensical. She starts as this lady who literally just hits you up for a job that backfires on you and then she becomes the main antagonist for a while until then you learn that there's another even worse, even evil-er guy that controls her from the shadows... and who has an awful fake asian accent. And then they tell you, AT THE END, that Lina was like, Tyler and Jess' childhood friend??????? And they raced together?????? But they don't tell you why or how they split up, they don't go in depth about anything when it could have actually been cool. It's just kinda there. It feels shoehorned, like a last attempt at making some dramatic revelation???? But it really isn't, it's just kinda lame, and it made me feel nothing. Hell, the curator is more interesting! The Broker is more interesting and you never even see her face!!!!! I truly believe they fundamentally messed up Lina's character and they just made her the big bad because they needed a big bad. Very sad. 
The last character with relevance that I wanna talk about is the Gambler. Marcus Weir is... fine, I guess. He's fun from time to time. But that's it. Just like Lina, he's kinda more plot device than character. And yes, I know what you're gonna say, "are you looking for coherent and well thought out plot in a driving game", to which I say YES, YES I AM, because I may not have had to pay 60 dollars for this, but other people did and I am sure their disappointment must have been IMMENSELY BIGGER than mine. 
The rest of characters are more secondary and they are kinda just there to fill up space. Funnily enough, I believe they are decent. The accomplish their purpose: giving the bosses you race a personality so you can feel like you are taking down an actual person. It's a shame then that like half of them are just ridiculous and, worst of all, so INSANELY BAD at what they do that, when they talk smack at you during a race, it feels like a joke because here's this guy telling you about how you actually are an awful racer and they are going to grind you to dust and like, you are a whole two kilometers ahead of them. It kinda sucks. It doesn't make me feel like I'm beating a cool race against an interesting rival, it makes me feel like I'm listening to the most unfunny comedy routine in recent memory. And it's made even worse by the fact that both Tyler and Mac ALWAYS have a response prepared in the form of a one liner, a weird joke that doesn't land that well, or worse: Tyler just going "They were SO good jess they had me agains the wall back there wowzers" after you beat them and sometimes even lapped them. 

But I have talked enough about the narrative side of the game. It is now time for us to take a look at the other, [b] OBJECTIVELY WORSE [/b] part of the game, and the main complaint that everyone has (and for good reason):

[h1] THE UPGRADE SYSTEM. [/h1] 

So I don't really know what was going through the developer's heads when they thought that it was a good Idea to leave the upgrades (you know, the main thing that lets you win the game?) COMPLETELY UP TO RNG. I am completely baffled at the fact that in order to upgrade your rides you have to PICK A RANDOM CARD AFTER A RACE and PLAY SLOTS IF YOU WANT MORE. Or you could also try your luck at the shop, and pray that they have what you need and not something that [b] resembles [/b] what you need but also terribly cripples some other aspect of your ride. I absolutely positively no doubt about it HATE THIS THING WITH A PASSION. It's so unintuitive, so unnecessary, so generally BAD. And, the worst part in my opinion is the disconnect that it creates between you and your ride. An integral part of the fun of customising rides in these games is that you upgrade them the way you want. But not in this game! in this game, you upgrade based on what the game feels like. And if you don't, [b] wait eight minutes until the shop refreshes. [/b] 

Oh, and did I mention that upgrades are not only individual and untransferrable to other cars, but also, untransferrable between CAR CLASSES????

[h1] THE CAR CLASS SYSTEM. [/h1] 

Let me say that I do have mixed feelings about this. Well, mostly negative feelings, but I guess it has some redeeming factors to it. So, in this game, your cars are divided in classes. Race, Drift, Offroad, Runner, Speedcross and Drag. By this I don't mean that there's a pool of cars from which you can choose the one's you like and then use them in any category, oh goodness no, that would make this a non-issue. Instead, SOME cars are available in each category. You cannot IMAGINE my sadness when the game told me I had unlocked the Corvette Grand Sport and I thought "Oh I'm gonna get one of these for the Runner class. Running away from cops in a corvette sounds fun" only to face the harsh reality that [b] the Corvette isn't in the Runner class. [/b] It is in the Drift class though, which makes NO sense, in my opinion. I ended up getting it for the Race class and just got a Mustang for my getaway duties. Add to this nonsense the fact that speed cars cannot be transferred between cars or classes and you have a recipee for disaster. At least let me use ALL my speed cards in ALL my cars... But no, that would make too much sense. 

In conclussion... I had fun. But I that doesn't mean that it's good. Get Heat instead, or, if you really want this one, wait until it has like a 90% discount. At least the music selection is better than Heat's. Lol.

Nutshell review:
Game is fun with mods that greatly fixes it foockin issues, it's completely enjoyable for real!!!

But without mods?? Holy foock goodluck having fun without them🤣

Here's some things that mods defnitely helped me out with:
-- The DLC cars bundle, you can unlock that with a mod.
-- the foockin Fortune Valley map shortcut DLC, unlockable with mod also.
-- The "Slot Machine" car upgrade system, mods fix that nonsense crap.
-- The car "ride height" where you just wanna lower the car but not with the ugly stance that the game does everytime you adjust ride height. mod fixes that shittness.
-- The foockin car parts where you have to do certain task so you can customize that part, fixed with mods as well.
-- The cash grind!!! I dunno about you but I always want to finish the main story first before doing side quest and shiitt to every game with a story I play. mod fixes this too.
--No space allowed in license plate??? I used a mod and fixed this shiitt.
-- limited slot in car wraps, fixed by a mod.

Those are just some things that I didn't like about the game and with the help of mods they are easily fixed. The mods honestly makes you enjoy the game to what it literally suppose to be.

So yeah, go buy it while it's down to 2 dollars, install Frostbite Mod Manager, sign up for NexusMods or whatever nfs modding site you prefer. Download and install mods! That's it, enjoy the foockin game bruhh👍

I paid £3 for this game on sale, for that price I would say its definitely worth it.
The story is god awful, and the voice acting is cringey as hell (mainly for the writing). The singleplayer isnt very long and theres only as many race events as the story lasts, theres nothing afterwards, no more events to do, the game saves giving you the best cars and then theres no single player content to do with them besides pretty uninspired freeroam events.
That said, at its core its still a pretty fun arcadey racing game that will give you a few hours of drifting rounds corners for your money.
That said, if you can get Criterion's entries into the nfs series (Most Wanted, Hot Pursuit) I'd go for those first, they're alot more content rich for the singleplayer side of things and just better games.

Multiplayer does seem to still have some people playing (I dont know if thats just a result of the games current low price or if people do actually play generally), and its pretty fun for what it is. Though some people have no chill and seem to have just chosen violence. Thats not the games fault though.

Bought a bunch of old obsolete games for real cheap including this one. 
Spent the day installing them and trying them out, having fun even. 
I had some pretty old obscure stuff, that ended up being great little hidden gems - so I was happy at this point.  Saved this one for last because I figured it would be the best one of the bunch - always loved the NFS series.
Then I came to this garbage title that keeps crashing with my gx card.
And this is suppose to be a quality EA AAA title and franchise ?!?!
My 'crappy' old indie games I just bought were better than this one !!!

Finally figured out the DirectX problem was due to some stupid setting on my page file that never bothered any of the other 350+ games I have - that was a tough one to figure out!
Got the game going and was then bombarded with loud rap music...I really, really hate rap 'music'.
Fought with the terrible menu system to turn off the music, mouse is disabled in these games now, it seems.  Had to task kill the game several times to get it to stabilize, settings just right and to load quickly.
Got the story going at last...but the characters and story is terribly stupid, shallow and just annoying as hell, plus I was forced to listen to rap music, so by now I'm really pissed off.
But at least I can drive a straight line now....yay, now I know for sure its not my computer or me!
 
I used to like the Need for Speed franchise, I've owned several older titles that were much better and I even liked the music enough to put them on my personal music player for rl driving.  But in Hot Pursuit Remastered version I had problems with just driving straight - I was all over the road, can't get anywhere. I thought it was either me or my controller, so I bought  a new controller...no difference, never figured it out - it's still totally unplayable to this day.  
Now I find my controller works just fine in Heat, so it wasn't me, it was the game.  Unfortunately, Heat is not an improvement for me - I just want the fun I used to have with the old series running from the cops while trying to win a race with expensive sport cars.

But...I guess this is the crap kids like now days...deep sigh.

Glad it was only $3 because this is the LAST of the NFS  franchise I ever buy and EA even for a while - nothing else they have looks even a bit interesting and I'm STILL pissed at them for canceling Earth & Beyond MMO years ago....and oh, did I mention I really hate rap music ?!?!

OK: Good driving, but where's the RACING?

I never thought I'd say this, but - this game has good driving. The car control is much more balanced and intuitive than most modern NFS games. You still have to do dumb stuff to go fast, like use boost and drift on every corner, but it's less obnoxious than most NFS. You can actually win by knowing a car's handling, rather than just being stupid aggressive.

My biggest gripe with this game is it locks every activity behind a car/event class system. You wanna use your WRX to haul ass in a street Race or smash a Drift record? Too bad, your WRX is classified as "Offroad" only. Hey, that's a bitchin 69' Charger you have! I bet that beast pulls a nice 1/4 mile time - But you wouldn't know, because you can't use it in "Drag" events. 

You cannot convert car class. However, you're welcome to buy the exact same car again in another class. What?! This confusing system is ultimately meaningless because you can't tune or mod anything exactly the way you want, anyways - there's no actual car tuning, and all upgrades revolve around a wack-ass card based system. The game takes place in Vegas, but come on! 

If you want to beat the game and unlock everything, well then strap in for some tedious stuff. A lot of event types don't feel like actual racing. Instead of a free-flowing driving experience, they are short-sighted trial-and-error runs where you have to micro-manage every move you make in order to meet some minimum score requirement. I'd rather be in an event where crossing the finish line first is what matters, and drive how the **** I want. 

The best "mission" moments in this game are where you are racing wheel-to-wheel at high speeds on the open road - Evading and ramming police and thugs into oblivion, triggering real-time cinematic cutscenes. That may sound dumber than the stuff I'm complaining about having to do, but it's 1000 times more satisfying than jumping through repetitive checkpoint hoops in an attempt to rack up points on a clock.

Anyways, this game feels great when it lets you onto the open road - but it's a rare opportunity among race/mission classes that are a total grind, and basically nonexistent performance customization/tuning. 

Recommended, as long as it only costs three dollars and you have nothing better to do.

[h1]Great gameplay inside a cringefest! (Don't worry, it's a solid game!)[/h1]

Okay, i will start this by mentioning, i played NFS series since the first one, obviously, i got old and boomery so after Most Wanted (2005) came out i got disappointed, and ever since, NFS games stopped being one of my favourite franchises.
Anyhow, few days ago i caught this on a -90% sale, for 3$ i couldn't turn it down, i gave it a try thinkig "Ey, what the hell, let's see what's new".

And that's when i became a junkie.

In just few days i managed to play like 53 hours almost. I got hooked up on it like crazy.

My complaints are related mostly to the extra challenges (speedruns, drift challenges, jumps), if you want to get all the achievements/completely finish the game you have to do those, they're hell on earth. I would gladly spend 3 days in a jail instead of doing them. I am not a very good player (in my recent years i becamme a filthy casual), but still, they're just badly designed with big requirements.
I am almost certain the devs haven't done them themselves to see if they're even remotely feasible. And i read that previously, devs that worked on NFS series said that they were kinda forced into just releasing the games, and not polish them accordingly, i don't know if that's the case but i think it's likely.

Now, most people don't care about achievements or extra completion bullshit, i like to call them 'the happy ones'.

Another thing that kinda bugs me is that, it's a street racing game, right? Then why the hell do we have to go through so many checkpoints, it kinda beats the "street racing" vibe when you have to do things accordingly, there are just few shortcuts that aren't really shortcuts, you can easily miss these checkpoints, and you have to go back to them, which obviously, is as stupid as it sounds.

Story is a cringefest to say the least, i swear to God, it's like 2002 called and wanted Vin Diesel from XXX back. 
All the dialogues and pseudo-machoism you'd expect from that movie, or from the Fast and Furious series. 

It didn't bother me, though, it was so bad it was funny as hell.
Luckily, it's NFS. Nobody in this damn world that plays it gives a quarter of a fuck about the story.

Overall, the game is really solid, graphics are good, it just feels right playing it, cars don't have that sluggish wanna-be racing sim feeling.
I would definitely recommend people to play it, especially old-farts (I am not even that old, but sometimes i feel like it..) like me that got to the point they're too boomery to enjoy "modern" games anymore.

Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 7/10
Story: Vin Diesel/10

For the people that don't feel like reading an entire review, i will make few short points:

The bad:
- The extra challenges for achievements are awfully bad, tiring and too much
- Multiplayer is almost dead, at least on Ranked, not sure about the casual
- Checkpoints in races, and no "real" shortcuts
- Sometimes, slow loading screens even on a good computer where the game is also installed on the SSD

The good:
- If you pay attention to dialogues and cutscenes, you will feel the power of Great Van Diesel the 1st flow through you, you will hear Britney Spears in your head and a Nokia 3310 will spawn in your hand.
- I think there are lots of cars, that will appeal to every sort of category of people. You can even make Ted Bundy's beetle, or if you didn't have luck trading crypto or stocks the last few years, you can at least get a lambo in NFS.
- Lots of customizations (I wish there were more options when placing decals, to alter their shape only horizontally for example)
- Solid handling and feel when driving. It feels like NFS again, it's almost perfect.
- Plenty of stuff to do in free-roam
- It has a pretty easy learning/getting-used-to curve

I really enjoyed my time with this game, and i hope you will too!
Have a great day and thanks for reading my ramblings.

A small edit: I forgot to mention, Payback really brought back my love for racing games, so now i am installing a bunch of racing games i already own for when i have time to play.

its awesome

I was honestly going to skip this game due to the upgrading system, but after I heard about Project UNITE, I decided to wait for the sale and here we are, $3 well spent and so far, I am having too much fun! The map is Forza Horizon inspired especially because you can do offroad races or combined and the events are very fun to drive in, especially the offroad races. 

My biggest gripe is having to buy duplicate cars for 4 different events: Offroad, Racing, Drifting, and Runner. You could modify the cars in NFS HEAT to be any of those and not have to buy duplicates, but then again this game was before heat and luckily they fixed that. 

Now the upgrading system is wack and the game makes you grind for both "speedcards" and money and that feels like a chore (screw you EA), but with the UNITE mod, you only have to grind for the money and then go to a tune up shop to buy the parts because they are all unlocked so you could even make your starter car a beast if you wanted to!  

The campaign, or singleplayer part, is basically Fast and Furious meets The Italian Job. Story is nothing special or original but it is better than Heat and NFS 2015. It's action packed, exciting moments, and not a dull moment, at least for the most part. Characters are alright, but the voice acting is terrible as if they are reading off the script without emotion so do not expect oscar worthy level of VA, although I keep hearing Ian Mcshane iwhenever the character "Rav" speaks and even sorta resembles him. 

One of the coolest parts of the game is you can race with your friends in alldrive multiplayer and set custom Starting/ Finish lines to race all around the map. So get your friends to try it with you after all, the game is 3 bucks until September 15th, or wait for the next sale.

Overall, solid racing game, cars are customizable so you can make them look however you like, but get the UNITE mod in order to enjoy the game the way it was meant to be (although the car tuning should have been as deep like NFS HEAT's).

I couldn't find the menu first, but issue was just dumb. Esc does nothing, because who in their right mind would try that for getting to the menus or exiting the game?? No sirree, thats' Tab you want for that. 

However the sound issue is worse than I expected. Not only do I get no sound in the game, I need to restart my PC to get the sound back after running NFS PB, most likely because it messes with the sound drivers and makes sound go somewhere else, and what's worse it seems to have messed with my app-specific sound settings in Windows unless that's an incredible coincidence. 

Also, even if I hadn't had these bugs, I can run the game pretty smooth on all ultra settings 1440p, however cutscenes are choppy and laggy. What's that about? 

And even if everything worked, I really really don't like being forced into several on-rails prologue missions like I've never played a racing game before. 

And even if I could just race, why are they talking as if I must take care not to damage the vehicle, but if I hit a wall I just bounce around? It's like my car is an indestructible object with a plow up front for any poor sod that thinks to front-collide with me.

And finally, why on earth are the default M&KB keybindings that you drive and steer with the arrow keys? Do nobody at EA play computer games? WASD people. WASD.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.


Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

It's okay.
 
Payback is yet another rather "mid" Need For Speed game, which is pretty common for a lot of 'em, really. There's a few things it does well, like good GFX that actually runs decently at 60fps on any decent & current mid-range PC, and car handling is also pretty alright...
 
...on the "Racing" discipline. You see, the game separates races through several categories, denoting the environment and mechanics. Racing is your usual road fare, Drifting is the sliding your car around mode, and Undercover is the mode where you evade the cops. I'd say those are pretty alright.
Then there's Drag racing. On it's own, it's pretty similar to how it worked in NFS:Underground (at least as I faintly remember)...but for some reason, the game insists on some of the "Drag" races being...well, actual races, and the cars absolutely suuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuck at turning. And there are turns in those races.
And then there's Off-Road. It handles how'd you expect of off-road racing, except it ain't great when the game LOVES to litter the track with pebbles that can crash your car on a narrow rocky track, and you're sliding all over the place.
 
And then there's the cars themselves. Most of the cars can be used across multiple disciplines...if you're willing to re-buy them per discipline. The upgrade system is also, basically, lootboxes. Yeeeap. At least they give you parts at the end of each race, but the races start outpacing your rank the further you progress through the game, which they expect you to close that gap by grinding out events. No thanks, easy mode set, complete the races.
I'm also not super impressed by the car lineup. A Car game without a McLarenF1 at this point is like...ooof.
 
Well, I rant all that, but they're not insurmountable dealbreaker issues, I think. The rest of the game is...alright. The story is the usual "NFS RYCER" inoffensive shlock, the soundtrack is your usual racing lineup stuff... and I guess unlike that other Need For Speed I had to refund, the controller actually works!
 
Anyways, if you can get it on super cheap like I did, it's not a bad buy, but it's pretty much nowhere near the quality of Hot Pursuit. If you're willing to splurge more and don't have it, get that one, otherwise, this is...a pretty ok get too.
 
(Also, don't ask me about multiplayer. Game didn't throw me ever into a lobby as it separates SP & MP. I consider that a point in it's favor.)

有氪金。而且是pay to win，不是pay for fun。即使使用修改器也不能完全挽救这个状况。
游戏模式单一、重复。任务无聊。
车辆购买以及改装繁琐。同一种型号的要买四辆，配件还不能通用，要重新刷。非要区分什么公路车逃逸车越野车甩尾车。越野车单独拆分出来也就算了，我理解，但是另外三种不能通用还要重复购买，就离谱。 
改装车：如果你要改装零件获得性能上的提升，只能使用卡片，有两种办法获得：一，在商店购买，买空了就等补货；二，在商店抽奖。卡片最高有18个等级，最多能提升三项能力。但是卡片是不通用的，如果你买了公路车的保时捷911，你的卡片不能使用在甩尾车的保时捷911上，只能单独另买。这点非常坑人而且无聊，丝毫没有乐趣。
另一种改装是单纯外表的改装，你可以改轮胎，改尾翼，改刹车盘，但是这些都只能带来外观的改变，丝毫不影响性能。非常离谱。不明白为啥非要拆分成这两个部分，弄得两个部分都没有乐趣。抽卡没有乐趣。改装外观本来应当带来性能的提升，但是也没有，很失望。以前的作品明明不是这样的。
故事俗套陈旧。一个复仇的故事，妹子不能泡，最后通关只得到一辆车，惨。
引导也不咋样。我一开始都不知道怎么调出主菜单，还是搜攻略查到的。而且似乎没有拍照模式。
驾驶的体验倒还不错。
我更喜欢卡本谷和热力追踪

First. I'm recommending this game only because its 3 bucks and it's NFS. If you've ever played one you know whast this game is. Unrealistic driving, slow feel no mater how fast you go, unlimited nitrous boost and no car damage. Story? Pppfft. Who cares. But its a guilty fun i enjoy. 

This game however in particular is especially problematic because EA.... You suck EA... And Origin game launcher makes other launchers whos names i won't mention but they start with a *pic and a ***soft, look like really great fleshed out feature rich launchers with no bugs or lag whatsoever. Having said that.
This game will occasionally not work. Like at all. Like i spent an hour going over fixes for a game released late 2017. Wanna know what the issue was? EA launcher didn't know where the game was located! So for those of you who bought this at 3 dollars or are thinking about it but heard there are issues my fix was simple. Go into EA launcher, go to game properties and add -datapath "C:\WHEREVER YOU HAVE STEAM INSTALLED\steamapps\common\Need for Speed Payback" to the command line. Now the game works. Buy it for 3 dollars. Spend nothing extra. EA deserves nothing. This game does get a thumbs up however for being a guilty pleasure.

[h1]Anti-White Developer[/h1]

Let me just start by saying that I played the first hour of the game vanilla. The story is a joke that could be overlooked because stories in racing games are just background noise but they actively force you to bear the cringe. Characters are all cliché and are all there to make you feel special, you're "the best driver in town", you're just awesome, please continue to play our game. They actually tried to play the anti-hero "not my fight" thing with the Main Character, when he basically had no other option and the suggestion made was what he wanted anyway??? it's ridiculous. And they keep calling you while you're driving saying the most horrid things imaginable, worse than Guantanamo bay sound torture.

The handling is atrocious. The game actively helps you steer to the point where you barely have to do anything. The handbrake makes the car extra grippy and allows you to make 90degree corners at 120mph, usually faster than how you were going in a straight line. The action is all scripted, so your opponents will go past you at 200mph but then slow to a crawl once you're close to the finish line, cops will disappear once you're close to the designated area. A joke. Then I got to the drifting part and I couldn't even make one drift, the car was just too grippy. I couldn't understand what I was supposed to do because the car doesn't behave anything like it should. I quit and installed UNITE mod. Day and night difference. Improvement in graphic details and sounds but the handling is miles better: wheelspin on acceleration, I was actually able to drift and beat the "score" by 5x times, then I got to the normal grip racing style, no more handbraking shenanigans, car would do what I was actually trying to do. Offroad racing seemed a little bit off, and cop chases still have the cop cars going insanely fast just to be ahead of you. The car customization seemed good from the little I've seen and there are very cool community liveries. In the end this feels like trying to be Forza Horizon and failing or underachieving at everything, there's nothing that it does better than FH and nothing really revolutionary either. 

What made me uninstall and refund the game was entering the game on a second time and seeing a black lives matter ad in the main menu. This bigotry and anti-White hatred cannot be allowed in video games.
Awful characters and storyline. I just wanna race some cars.

Above all else, There is very, very little sense of speed.

I was hoping the combat would make up for this, but it didn't. Cars feel off, floaty/ not even in their environment. Better music than a few games after it. VERY poorly optimized. I'd say, YES of course its worth 3 bucks, but its not worth your time. There are far older racing games that are better in every way.
 If you want a "hidden gem", and are running our of racing/arcades games, get NFS shift 2 on Orgin, not steam. Its broken on steam. its got a great feel to it, AND has cockpit view,a rare feature in NFS entries.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Without even going into the insidious Origin launcher, that takes it upon itself when to cooperate and work as it should, the gameplay is fun for some light-hearted arcade racing. The thing most annoying and frustrating is the navigation system whereby you can see a spot you need to get to, but there is no clear way on the map as to how to get there. It places a marker but, unlike race events, garages, etc., it does not give you a line on the road to follow.

It is such an obvious console port that no time and thought has been given to incorporating mouse control, especially on the map and options screens.

Enjoyable enough if you don't want a full-on simulation, but not easy to get around and free-roam isn't really that, there are too many roadside barriers and obstacles to allow you to go across country.

It excels at the arcade racing, but not so much the story & characters... but I don't think many people play racing games for a quality story-line & characters. So if you're just looking for a fun casual arcade racer with a dedicated drift button and all -- then Payback, and really any N4S game, is a great option.

The game was good and epic, but not everything is good, there are some that didn't satisfy my fun in this game:
- I do like the cars you can drive. There are a wide variety of vehicles you can choose from.
- The vast car customization are really epic and amazing .
- Tune up cards are quite good but sometimes, they're a bit of a let down.
- I really love the map size, since I'm a guy who really gets amazed on big and huge maps.
- Interesting story but I wish is was more longer.
- I like the driving mechanics, but it does really need some skill to drive well, especially offroad, which is not a hassle for me, I can get used to this.
- AI racers and police has never been forgiving in this game, they really need to chill.

Now the main part of this review:

One thing that really pisses me off is that they never let the abandoned cars stay in the game after like 2 and a half years and it's most likely rigged and unfair for late and new players like me who are really astonished to those cars (such as the M3 GTR, Underground 2 350z, etc). So why still bother selling this game when in the end, you'll just disappoint and piss off your new players all because you removed something really that matters the most in the game. Well you're EA afterall so I'm getting used to all of your bullshit. Istg please bring back the abandoned cars, idc if this game is really old enough for you but you're still selling this so be much more responsible what your new game buyers want on your game.

Need for Speed: Payback is a racing game, where you and your crew pulling of a steal, but the one who gave you the job betray you and you want to take revenge, meanwhile the city full of gambling starts to hit the streets and racing is not what it used to be.

A lot of people hate the soundtrack in this game, however in my opinion, it's pretty all right. I'm not saying it's better than the OG "I'm Rock" or more OG "Black Betty", but there are a few decent tracks in this game. Also the sound design is not bad, however there are times, when engine sounds for certain cars sounds exactly same or some moaning or shouting sounds ridiculous, but still it's all right.

About the story, it's not the most deepest thing ever, there are few black holes in it, where the plot either not makes any sense or just the characters do something stupid, but still better than the 2015 NFS's story by a mile. There are a few smaller twist, but in general it's pretty simple. Characters are not deep at all, some of them pretty annoying, because of their "cool" lines, but at the end, I was all right with them. Probably my favorite characters from the game is the Curator and Marcus Weir. If you want to play a NFS game because of it's story, except a really simple and most of the time weak story from this game, but for a NFS, it's okay.

Graphics in this game is okay. There are lot of graphical bugs, either textures don't want to load in at all, bushes goes into the air or the camera goes through the level, it's all in the game, but these are not that common. I was okay with it throughout the game.

The controls of this game is... not the most pleasant thing in the universe. You can control your car decently, but my biggest issue was with the turning and drifting. The game has the break-drift mechanic from 2015 NFS game, which I wasn't the biggest fan of, but here drifting is essential for taking some corners, however at the beginning, it was a pain to get use to and I had a really hard time to even race properly. Also, every damn car is under steering in this game, it's impossible to take corners without drifting or owning a decent car. However, I around mid game, I started to get use to it and it was okay, however it's a really weird to control these cars in this game, comparing to other racing games.

My (and a lot of other people's) only complaint is the upgrade system. You can't convert your car from say, grip to drift, and you have to buy *cards* as your upgrades. You don't have your in-garage menu for making upgrades and buying parts like you did in NFS 2015; in fact, your garage isn't even used for making upgrades anymore. It's all just for applying cosmetics and playing with the wrap editor. Don't get me wrong, customization and everything else is fantastic. It's just the upgrades that are the worst part of Payback and aside from customizing, your garage is only used to manage cars. Unless you're prepared for modding the game to be comfortable, I suggest you just upgrade your computer and move on to NFS Heat, or if you REALLY don't want to mess with this kind of upgrade system and don't want to upgrade your computer, go back to NFS 2015.

Before you read this, i need to tell you that i have no experience on playing the previous Need for Speed games that came before Payback. The last Need for Speed game that i played was Need for Speed Most Wanted (2012), and the game that felt (almost) similar to Payback for me was the trio of the most famous Need for Speed (Underground 2, Most Wanted 2005, and Carbon).

This game sets on Fortune Valley, a fictional place based from Las Vegas. As someone who grew up playing some of the famous Need for Speed games (such as NFSMW 2005, NFS Underground 2, NFS Carbon), the world in this game is pretty huge. Aside from the fact that most of the place is winding roads and deserts, i have to admit that the world in this game is amazing, with day and night cycles, something you don't get in previous NFS installments.
The handling of the car is pretty good, but kinda hard if you're on keyboard and don't have enough experience with it. Still, i spent 20 hours in game playing with keyboard and it's more than enough for me. Probably because i have played previous NFS with keyboard as well. (Controller is recommended). 
The cars that available in game, well, not that bad, but can be better. The customization is pretty decent. The wrap editor is pretty cool in my opinion, just like what we had back then with NFS Carbon but much more complete. However, there is lack of choice for parts. Yes you can modify different parts of the car, but with lack of options in each parts felt disappointing.  Another disappointing thing is that there are 5 type of cars (Drag, Drift, Runner, Race, Offroad), and every car is locked in its own type. Like, why can't i bring my Porsche for runner or drift?
One big problem with this game is the Speed Card (if you ever played Need for Speed No Limits, you'll be familiar with this).  Speed Card is annoying. It's like "hey i wanna upgrade my car" and the game will be like "yes but now i can only downgrade it or wait for like 8 minutes maybe i will give upgrade options lmao"
The story felt a bit short, as well. I'm in chapter 3 and the character development of the antagonist felt a bit off, like the dev could do better with it even if it increases the amount of time to finish it.

Overall, 6.5/10 from me for this game. Why i recommended it? because if you wanna enjoy modifying the visual parts of your car, enjoying the scenery, or just cruising around, this game can do the stuff. But in other things, mehh, no. 
Oh ya, i don't recommended it in full price, but i do recommend it when it's on sale with more than 50% discount.
(last edit : minor grammatical correction and some additional info)

Prior to Payback, I played NFS 2015 and Heat and originally skipped Payback because I didn't realize it was released between the two. After I realized that, I was hesitant to play because of negative feedback I heard about it, but I'm glad I gave it a try. There are differences between the 3 but they're not so radical that you feel like it's a completely different game. 
The good:
- the story of Payback. I like the story of both Payback and Heat better than 2015
- Mechanics of driving are basically the same between the 3, with a few changes in certain controls, for instance shifting gears I think 2015 had it as up and down on the d-pad, Payback is Y and B, and Heat had RB and LB (using Xbox controller)

The Different (not necessarily good or bad):
- parts are levelled 1-18, while 2015 and Heat both have fewer tiers per part
- partscan be "stock" or they can be one of 6 different brands, and if 3 parts of the same brand are equipped, there's an extra bonus for the car that varies by brand, and if you have all 6 parts there's an even greater bonus
- parts are completely random, both in what spawns in the shop's inventory and the rewards at the end of a won race 

The bad:
- Cars are locked into one of 5 driving styles and can't be changed. If you want the same car to be able to be a racer, it can't also be a dragster or a runner or a drifter even though the differences between the 3 classes are fairly minimal, or you can't decide to take a car you had for off-roading and change out parts to make it into a street racer. Off-road wasn't a thing in 2015 but does carry over into Heat which does allow you to take any car and change out parts to make it better suited to any other class as desired. 
- Races don't include distance between the next racer ahead of you, behind you, and in first place if that's not you, like I know it is in Heat but can't remember if 2015 was that way. 
-parts are locked to cars, not at all interchangable
- "cinematic" cutscenes - can't say much without spoiling anything so I'll leave it at this: 
--there's several missions where you basically have to get your car close enough to a given point and then the cutscene takes over and does a lot of driving for you and then returns controls to you where it's already driving
--when you take out cops pursuing you, if the cop in frame gets wrecked, it goes into slow-mo footage of the car wrecking/flipping and interrupts your driving, so if you're driving on a curving road it can mess with your steering angle and force you to try and correct while you're still trying to evade other cops chasing you. It might not happen too often, but it's definitely caused me to drive into a wall or let the other cops intercept me a few times, forcing me to restart a mission.
- story ends on a cliffhanger. Hope it gets resolved, but given the general reception to the game that I've seen, I'm kinda doubtful

[b]It's really really hard for me to rate an NFS with thumbs down, really.[/b]

But I decided to do it this way and give the game a few more stars because I found it thumbs up and just a star or two more silly.

[b]Personally, I would like to have the option of a neutral rating.[/b]

That would simply be more meaningful for me and since the opinions about the NFS games are totally different for years. 
I can understand the different opinions and sometimes I just don't feel any different. It's not an easy thing with NFS. Unfortunately.
Sure, the games are always kind of good, but sometimes I find the games just as bad, and like many other games, there are people who like it and people who don't.

So good or not so good game? 

[b]The next weak performance with a bit of Fast and the Furious feeling, stuff from other games and microtransactions …[/b]

The campaign with the [b]lame and superficial story[/b] lasts about 15-20 hours. 
The scripted cutscenes give you the feeling that the game is based on the successes of Fast and the Furious. This influence can also be found throughout the game. Fetch helicopters from the sky, support or take over trucks, and so on. [b]But it's not like you do it yourself in any way[/b]. The cutscenes do that as soon as you have reached the target speed or the point next to the truck, for example.

Due to all the "collective stuff" such as billboards, drift zones or speed cameras, [b]the game looks more like a game patched together from Burnout Paradise, The Crew or Forza Horizon without a concept of its own[/b]. You can't really complain about the abundance of side missions, but some of them are simply unnecessary and unimportant.

The story is about taking down "the house", a cartel and its gangs. Each of these gangs has a special area, so to speak, such as drift, drag, off-road or street racing. [b]What you show in terms of driving skills is not even that relevant. The performance classes that can be bought in the tuning shop with credits or real money are more decisive.[/b] 
This quickly develops into a grind because you are often behind the required performance classes. The whole thing is made even more difficult by the many cars required or the whole game is simply unnecessarily lengthened. 
[b]For every different event you need the right car.[/b] It doesn't matter if your car, e.g. tuned for drifts, has better acceleration or top speed than e.g. your getaway car. You simply cannot use it for escape trips. The relatively good selection of cars doesn't help either.

Btw, Lina Navarro kinda reminds me of Naomi Nagata and that doesn't add up at all...

[b]I don't want to put anyone down on the game, I really don't. But personally I can't really recommend the game.[/b]
It's kind of boring and only marginally fun. [b]It's just along the lines of "we had to do something and, without any ideas of our own, simply helped ourselves everywhere and then somehow mixed it together into a game".[/b] 
[u]For me, that makes it one of the worst NFS ever[/u], [b]but that's subjective, as we all know, and everyone sees it differently.[/b]

Personally, [b]I wouldn't pay more than $5 for the game[/b], and I recommend anyone looking to play Payback or any other NFS consider EA Play. There are some NFS titles (and of course other games) included, the costs are manageable and you can easily cancel it.

❌ too much grind
❌ Miserable tuning system (a matter of luck)
❌ weak story
❌ boring races
❌ occasional bugs (collision detection)
❌ Microtransactions

Good storyline, aesthetic customization of cars, road and offroad racing, this what attracted me to playing this game. the only downside for me is the RNG in performance upgrade which hinders the process of upgrading a car faster. Even though multiplayer is dead, still one of the best nfs game to immerse yourself in single player.

My first NFS since the "Underground" golden days, I've only played "The Run' since then, which was fantastic but it got taken down.

I must say, the driving experience is on point, everything feels right, for Speed/Drifting/Drag racing/etc. And that's coming from a Mouse/KB user.
Did I mention it has a story ? A truck load of challenges ? A diverse variety of races and environment ? Great car visual customisation ? Free driving ? Puzzles for unlocking [spoilers] ? Plenty of cars to satisfy everyone's taste, from the Nissan Skyline to the Lamborghini Huracan, a Beetle perhaps  ?        -  Well, now it it said.

The only downsides I could come up with is:
1. The performance upgrades mechanic, once bought/acquired, they are tied to a single car and modify multiple elements, it's just weird and unnecessary.
2. The multiplayer is pretty dead, and if you come across any people, chances are they will mop the floor with you, go wonder why ? Over-tuned cars ? Upgrades i'm not aware of ? Cheat ? Who knows.

But let's stick to the single player side shall we ! 
Overall, an amazing game, that I would totally re-play if I could wipe my memory. 9/10

I've been playing this on my Steam Deck and it runs just as well as my desktop with a 3070. The only thing that doesn't work on the Deck is online community stuff, so for single player you can't see community skins (cloud sync works fine, though, so if you select/apply a community skin on the PC then it'll still work on the Deck). Otherwise, everything works as it should despite it not being an "officially" supported on the Deck.

As far as the game itself goes, the story is uninteresting to me. I always skip the dialogue scenes before races. I just like to drive, which is a lot of fun in this game. The cars are fun, the upgrade system could be better (as others have mentioned) but to me the most fun part of upgrades is feeling the difference in the driving. Thankfully, the upgrades are not weak and you can feel noticable increments in performance after visiting the parts shop.

The exploration in this game is also pretty fun. Normally I don't care about all the little extra collectibles, but I think this game has a nice balance of making the collectibles achievable and rewarding as you go. It doesn't require you to focus so hard on them to get them.

I'd say the worst part of the game is that some of the races are annoyingly designed. I'll have a car spec'd way over the recommended spec and I still can't win. This is mostly true for the off road races. It's not very many that this happens, but when it does it's annoying. Also, the cop chases are pretty bland, imo. Most Wanted 2005 still by far holds the crown when it comes to police chases. This game's chases are very linear and you're just trying to follow a path to an escape point while the cops are slamming into you. Pro tip: if you're in the mountains just drive off a cliff. The cops will follow you but the game resets your car and then you're free to continue on your way.

Overall, whether you're a NFS fan or just looking for a fun casual racing game, I think this is an enjoyable choice and I would recommend it on sale.

[note: I am going to compare this game to NFS Heat, since that's the closest NFS game i can compare it to]

When I bought this game, I expected it to be like Heat, but worse. I've seen the reviews, but I didn't look too deep into them because I wanted to form my own opinion and I wanted to see as few spoilers as possible. Therefore I expected every aspect of the game to be worse than in Heat.
Now, obviously Heat is better in so many ways, but honestly, I prefer Payback. Maybe it's because of the novelty, since I played this after Heat, maybe it's because my expectations were way too low. This is quite obviously a subjective rating, but Payback is objectively better in some ways.
Firstly, I would like to address the physics. I prefer Payback's physics,  simply because Heat's physics feels too arcadey to me. Payback still isn't perfect, it's still arcadey af, but I feel like it fits the map pretty well. The cars don't have as much toy car feel. 
Next thing that is definitely missing from Heat are the derelicts. It's such a cool idea and it fits the atmosphere of the game. Collecting the derelict parts felt sort of tedious, but I'm glad it was in the game. The rusty, worn parts look really good on some cars. It allows you to build elaborate sleepers, which is a cool thing to do. 
The soundtrack is another thing that fits the atmosphere of the game. This is the most prominent thing that Payback handled way better than Heat. The grungy rock is a perfect genre for a game set mostly in a desert. The rest of the genres included in the soundtrack were quite enjoyable as well. Heat's soundtrack, on the other hand, feels absolutely soulless.
As I've come to think about it, that's probably the thing that really sets Payback and Heat apart. Payback, even though it's not perfect, has soul. Heat has... Identity crisis I guess?
Now to the customization - I'll start with the trading cards, just so I get that out of the way. It's... an interesting concept? Nah, let's be real, it's awful. Probably the worst thing about Payback. Basing performance upgrades on RNG is utterly idiotic. 
Visual customization, on the other hand, is fantastic. Well, kind of. In the Heat review, I mentioned that I feel like something is missing in terms of customization. I think that might be the autosculpt feature. And also almost all the spoilers/wing look very similar, they're all too racecar-like. But other than that I have to say that the visual customization is fantastic. And the specialized builds are a cool addition as well.
With the car list, it's basically the same as in Heat. It should be enough for the majority of players, I'm just spoiled by Gran Turismo :D
The map is great, I love the vibe. Sometimes it might get a bit restrictive though.
The story is okay for a NFS title. Again, I choose Payback's story over the one in Heat. 
I don't have much else to say, so in conclusion, I surprisingly prefer Payback over Heat.

Plot/Story
Interesting idea,execution is absolutely terrible.Dialogue is peak cringe and the "banter" is like AI wrote it.Only interesting character is Jess and tbh a game with her as the main character would be interesting.

Gameplay
Racing is the only mode i found fun,drifting is just to beat a target score,no 1v1's no drift trains like ???.Drag is as always botched.Offroad was a good concept but in practice most times your car decides to drive itself,its like having the chopper above you just its invisible.
Car variety is good but locked classes is a stupid idea,the worst part however is the fact you have to grind speed cards or alternatively pray to RNG,a recipe for disaster.
Rubberbanding is prevalent,more so than in Most Wanted (2005) and Carbon which is an accomplishment considering this game came out in 2017.

Soundtrack
Actually decent,unlike previous installments (exceptions being Underground and original Most Wanted) it's actually fitting to listen to.

Map
Rivals,2015 and older installments put together with 2-3 circuits at times it felt like I was playing Rivals especially in the mountains.Only plus is that there is a day/night cycle.

Final thoughts
There is a reason EA bought Codemasters,we might one day see a proper off road/drift implemented.Until then I hope against hope that they will actually bring in the Original Underground 2,MW,Carbon and The Run.

Payback is taking a page out of GTAV's book with you swapping between 3 different characters during the game that all have their own driving skill, so one is good at offroad driving, another is good at normal racing and the third is best at escaping cops.

This does have a lot more racing variety than 2015's game with normal racing, drifting, off roading, drag racing and speed racing, and you can swap between them at anytime if you get bored of one of the storylines.

This game is great if you can get over the fact that it's not that hard until the final race, if you didn't upgrade your car completely. The graphics are good (not photo realistic, but lets be honest, if you want that, go play Forza or a sim racing game). The story is actually a story and makes sense. The driving mechanics are better than 2015 (not super fidgety and require perfect tuning). There's plenty to do, and the cops don't bother you unless you're in a runner race (one of my biggest pet peeves with NFS was that cops would always chase you when you're just trying to drive around and have fun). It's a open world map (lots of room to drive and have fun (not as big as the Crew, but big enough to take 5 mins to get across the map). It works with an Xbox controller, and if you're tech savvy, will work with PS controllers (I am simply dumbfounded how someone can't figure out how to use a Xbox controller on a Windows computer, in a Need For Speed game).


I give the game a 10/10 and honestly think its one of NFS's best recent games. Obviously not everyone thinks the same, but if you like NFS, give it a try, and don't try basing your experience on previous NFS games. Most games I play, I like, because I don't try to compare it to other games. 99% of the games out there, are their own thing, and should'nt be judged by the previous experiences.

Give the game a try, and if you don't like it, refund it before the 2 hours, or just find a friend that has it, and try it first.

Need for Speed: Payback turned out to be a big surprise for me. This is in several respects. I expected it to be a terrible production mostly focused on the plot, but it is not. What's more, it turned out that the gameplay model borrowed from other arcade games open-world solutions with a car power index indicating the progress in the game. Although there is no atmosphere or the spirit of Need for Speed in it, the whole thing is surprisingly good, and the final effect is spoiled mainly by the forced microtransaction system, tedious gringing, infantile scenario and Polish dubbing. Additionally, the game lacks a multiplayer mode. In other words, despite the fact that the driving itself is quite nice and the game is very nice visually, I recommend other racing arcade productions - I would use Payback only when you pass them, feeling the lack of arcade racing.

[h1]This game is surely a disgrace to the NFS series, but don't skip it. Trust me.[/h1]
I have 100%ed the game twice on Ps4 and PC. Should be enough to help with my credibility.
[b]Car Physics[/b]
[list]
    [*]This game has the best 'Brake to Drift' handling style of all NFS games. I can feel weight of the car fighting back while drifting but the steering is really responsive. It's like NFS2015 with lesser random swerving (Good).
    [*]In comparison, drifting does not fell as heavy as Rivals and Hot Pursuit. Very similar to MW2012, but Payback is better in terms of adjustability.
    [*]This game doesn't have a detailed handling settings like 2015, but it has introduced live tuning instead. Basically you can adjust your car's behavior to your driving style mid driving and IMO it is broad enough for every type of player's driving style and not too much to break the game, but I'd still prefer 2015's since its more detailed and based on real life. This is a great introduction to Payback's live tuning. [url=https://steamcommunity.com:/linkfilter/?url=https://www.reddit.com/r/needforspeed/comments/8t92oj/guide_for_live_tuningtuning_vehicles/]Reddit[/url]
    [*]Nitrous system is unique. Not saying its good or bad. Feels like I'm in F&F movie.
    [*]Offroading feels like driving on a bumpy tarmac and the car tends to drift more. Some people hate it, but I like it even more than Heat.
[/list]
[b]Gameplay & Story[/b]
[list]
    [*]There are 5 car classes. Street, off-road, drag, drift, and runner.
    [*]The first 4 classes are straight forward. For runner class cars, they are reinforced sports cars made for getaway.
    [*]Street and off-road races are mediocre. There are some good tracks but not that remarkable.
    [*]Drag race is ok. Really hard to win if you don't know the trick. Here is a memorable moment: There is a track where I had to race the non-steering drag car around a block. It was surprising and frustrating at the same time.
    [*]Drift trails is the best part of this game. Driving on mountain pass has the same feeling as doing touge on an American-sized roads. The physics of drift cars class made it really easy to oversteer by just steering left/right.
    [*]Runner getaway missions are fun, but the bad thing is there is no real pursuit in this game. If you get close enough to the destination the cops/guards will automatically stop chasing you. Chauffeur missions are boring. I spent more time planning my route than driving in those missions.
    [*]Heists/Team Getaway missions are really good. If you see an orange icon showing up on the map, prepare for the fun.
    [*]There are derelics(barnfinds) to be collected. You have to jump from land to higher grounds that cannot be reached from lower ground. Fun & unique.
    [*]AI Racers car designs are lit. Art team did a really great job.
    [*]The story is decent at most. There are so much conversation going on throughout the story making this game the NFS that has the most dialogues
FYI: This is the first NFS that we can hear protagonists talking to each other and themselves.
[/list]
[b]The cons[/b]
[list]
    [*]No Alldrive in this game(Online story mode that was introduced in Rivals).
    [*]No rain(bruh). At least this game has a proper day/night cycle unlike 2015.
    [*]The map didn't specify which part of the road is tarmac or dirt, it's just gray lines placed on a map. So it is a little bit of a guessing game of the terrain you are driving to.
    [*]There clearly is a massive airport runway on the map(bottom right), but it's unreachable. Probably because the devs didn't have enough time to finish the game. Such a shame for EA.
    [*]There are a lot of void in the map protected by barriers made of vibranium. If you try to jump down the cliff or jump over the barrier, the game will either respawn you at the top or your car will hit the invisible wall head-on. It's really annoying when driving in freeroam because some parts you can actually drive straight through the mountains, but forced to drive around instead.
    [*]Cars cannot be transferred to other class one it have been bought. You can't even have the same car for 5 different classes because it might be only available for street class(90% of Hypercars).
    [*]There are a lot of cars that could make it as a hero car as the legendary M3 such as [spoiler]the silver Mustang in the Regera heist mission[/spoiler]. The car was introduced once and never again in the story. It just perished after the mission. This is a waste of potential.
[/list]
[b]The disgrace[/b]
[list]
    [*]Vanity items like air suspension, nitrous & tire smoke colors can only be earned by opening loot boxes disguised as "Shipments." Classic EA move.
    [*]The Crew-like car upgrade system. Every time you complete an event, you will get one speed cards. They can have up to 3 perks and vary from 6 parts and 5 brands. It is basically the Crew and the Crew 2 upgrade system mixed together with a little more gimmick(Yes, the Crew upgrade system sucks. If you like this loot box rewarding system then you haven't have your hands on enough good games. Things like this should never be introduced in any type of games. My opinion on this will never change). Another way to earn those cards is to spin the slot(parts) machine and pray that you get the good ones. I tried spinning the wheel for 300+ times in a hacked client and still cannot even max out a single car. Just check this out its all you need to know. [url=https://steamcommunity.com:/linkfilter/?url=https://www.reddit.com/r/needforspeed/comments/7j8sqi/an_explaination_of_nfs_paybacks_brandsperks_and/]Reddit[/url]
[/list]
[b]TL;DR:[/b] Don't skip this game. Even though it's as bad as people says. Bad game ≠ not fun.

It's an enjoyable game. The graphics are good, I would say even better than Heat, the map is interesting and the driving is very fun. They try to keep the missions diverse and of course they are full of cheese and over the top action, but it's what you expect from a game in the series. It’s mostly a very good racing game with some minor annoyances. The cars handle great, the graphics are good minus the offensive pop-in - even on the highest settings. It can be a bit distracting. In general, I am not a big fan of open-worlds in racing games, because they add a lot of busywork like driving from A to B to get events started. It’s well solved here with lots of easy to unlock fast travel points. Sometimes you still have to drive a few kilometres before you can start the event, but it’s not as bad as in something like - let’s say Forza Horizon. 

The main events in the campaign are divided into five different types of races: Race, Drag (Quarter-Mile Races), Runner (mostly police chase missions), Drift and Off-Road. There was another very fun mode added through DLC - which is included in this edition of the game. Stunt races, where you have to get the highest score possible by doing all kinds of jumps, drifts, speeding and destruction on special courses. Most of these events are fun with a good difficulty curve. As usual the rubber band AI can be a bit frustrating at times. Definitively frustrating are some Runner missions where you have to reach several targets in a certain time frame in any order. These often end in trial and error because there are only one or two effective routes. I also wasn’t a fan of the Drag Races because those just felt like you had to tune your car enough to outclass the other driver by pure horsepower.

Besides the main events, there is your typical open-world blunder like collectables, hidden car parts that can be assembled to whole cars and tons of challenges like speed traps, drift events, jumps and so on. The Autolog is also back to always remind you how good/bad you compare to your friend list. So, lots of content for completionists.

With the main races, you need to unlock cars for every class. You can buy the same car for two different types, but you can’t just buy it once and use it at different events. It’s always separated which can be a bit confusing in the beginning. It doesn’t get better with the upgrade system the game provides. Cars can be upgraded with up to six racing cards. Yes, cards. Because every game nowadays needs freakin’ collectable cards! And of course, you get those cards through what? Hm? Yes! Loot Boxes! And yes, you can buy those for real money. But wait! It seriously isn’t a problem at all. At least the Deluxe Edition - which is the only version you can buy on Steam - comes with more than enough resources so that you hardly have to grind for better gear to get your cars in line with the other drivers. And while confusing and probably unnecessarily complicated, the upgrade system can provide some fun if you are into min-/maxing your stuff.

The presentation of the story is effortful for a racing game. There are lots of cutscenes with dialogue and story and even during the races the three main protagonists hardly shut up. Of course, all of this is on the level of your average Fast & Furious movie and while it isn’t complete cringe, it can be annoying. That money would have been better spent in just more actual “game” because most players will probably just skip those cutscenes. If you like some stupid action-racing movie type of story then it’s at least serviceable - I guess.

Need for Speed: Payback is another part of the racing simulator series Need for Speed, which takes the player to Fortune Valley, an analogue of Las Vegas. Players will have to intervene in the illegal activities of the huge House Cartel, which has crushed the entire city, and avenge the offense inflicted on the main character.

Gameplay in NfS: Payback revolves around street racing, crime missions, and police chases. Passing various tests, tracks and races, players can unlock new cars, tuning parts, and also move up the career ladder, increasing their rating. Payback gives the player the opportunity to ride around a large open world, unlocking new race tracks, looking for rare vintage cars, and more.

Great game. One of the most fun NFS games I've played yet. The customization is great among the cars, lots of vanity items and stancing, and customization options. The storyline is so-so, it's can get pretty boring sometimes but can also be the exact opposite other times. Among the storyline, there are some very good custscenes. I have noticed a problem with some of the cutscenes dropping to 30 fps for unknown reasons. The mechanics of this game are good and fairly easy to learn, drifting actually feels fun and is easy to learn. Game feels awkward and stiff at first however. One MAJOR complaint I have about this game are the cops or enemy vehicles in general. Cops in this game are EXTREMELY overpowered, not to the point where it's impossible to beat the mission but they can make the game quite unenjoyable.
Pros: 
 - Lots of customization options
 - 3 different characters to play as, makes the game more fun
 - Good cutscenes
 - Drifting is very fun in this game

Cons: 
- Laggy cutscenes at time
- Crashing system in this game is horrible (if you care about that stuff)
- Cops make the game unenjoyable a lot.
- The cutscene when you take down an enemy can mess you up while racing heavily.
Ratings:
Customization - 10/10
Mechanics - 8/10
Storyline - 6/10
Tuning- 7/10
Gameplay time- 10/10
Overall - 7/10. Would recommend but not worth the full price, would buy when it's on sale.
