This game is a HUUUGEE improvement over the previos "No name NFS".
First of all - steering. Now the cars are predictable and fun to drive, regardles of perfomance level. The feeling varies highly between classes (I mean, drift car handles different than a street racing, runner machines feel realy heavy).
Of course the driving, physics, grip level are all veery arcade, but thats the point of NFS, right? To feel on the virtual road like a reincarnation of Colin McRae fused with Aerton Senna.
The overall mood of the game is something like a mix of NFS Carbon (story wise) & NFS ProStreet (form of races and setting) with some Holywood-F&F-style stunt flare.
A very nice lineup of cars divided into several categories. Some cars are availible for more then one discipline (i.ex. '69 Charger can be Race, Drag, Runner), while some are eglible for ony one discipline (i.ex Merc G-Class is only for OffRoad).
The visual tuning is almost identical to that from previous instalment - pretty good with lot's of real-life brands of body kits, rims etc.
I will criticise the part of mechanical tuning - it's LAME! Let me explain - after every race You recive a "Speed Card". They can also be bouth at tune shops, drawn at a sort of slot machine that gives random cards in exchange for in-game tokens or recived after escaping the pursuit with "Bait Crates" randomly found in the world.
The idea behind tuning a car with those cards is beonde me. A card car upgrade one of six elements of car: block, head, exaust, ecu, turbo, gearbox. In the same time a card can have 0 to 3 additinal "perks" to upgrade NoS capacity, jump abilites, top speed, brake response, acceleration. It looks totally odd when a card that upgrades engine's head also upgrades breaking performance. So generally the most important factor is car level raging from 0 to 399. If you equip your car with 6 cards of level 18 your machine will be 399lvl, and loosing will become dificult ;)
Another thing to blame are cop chases. They are all scripted, start and end at predefined moments, and take place on a predefined route with minimal freedom. You can't loose the tail on your own. They will just give up about 700 m before finish line. There is also no penalty, nor prize for wrecking patrol cars. I really miss Sgt. Cross... At least the Rhino's ramming You head-on are back.
But overall i car recomend this title if You like racing games, but You'r not a hardcore sim-racer. The story is good for, no offence, 8 YO kids, but gules this somehow toghether, cars drive well, there is lot's of them, visually is OK, better then the previous, without this softing blur effect, lot's of activities beside the mian storyline (jumps, drift zone's, speed traps, collectibles).

TLDR: I do not recommend this game. While it was enjoyable to play, I have to believe there is a better Need For Speed experience available on Steam.

Good:
-Racing and pursuits, the reason you play a NFS game, are very fun
-Driving feels familiar and intuitive
-Different classes of races keep gameplay fresh and allow customizing more cars to use
-Opt in challenges provide decent difficulty in not super annoying ways
-Catalog of cars isn't super deep, but provides most iconic cars
-Community design sharing was a very cool feature. Anyone can upload their paint and decal design for other players to see and use on their own cars. 

Meh:
-Open world challenges and collectibles are nice ways to engage while driving to different events, but are not rewarding enough to seek out
-Derelict cars (built from parts found in the open world) are a decent concept, but not worth the time
-Card system of upgrading cars was annoying at first, but is super easy to manipulate once you get used to it
-Soundtrack was passable, but felt super repetitive since only a few songs stand out
-No real reason to upgrade to higher tier cars. You can take any car up to Max, which is great for people that want to main a low-grade car, but I wanted a reason to want the exotic cars besides fulfilling a "racing fantasy"

Bad:
-I have never played a game that made me cringe as much as this game's writing.
-No reason to ever do side races. Main quests and opt in challenges gave me enough resources to buy whatever I wanted.
-Story missions were the worst part of this game
-Too much RNG with upgrade cards
-Stats do not matter on your car's level, only the tier of upgrade card, forcing me to use cards with worse stats to increase my car's level and unlock higher tier cards.
-Visual customization of cars is very lacking
-Visual customization areas (bumpers, rims, spoilers, etc) are locked behind open world challenges. Even after completing the game I could not fully customize cars.
-Control for certain events were frustrating, mostly the off road events and when they forced you to use your drag racing cars for street races.
-Some stats felt inconsequential. Brakes and Jump felt completely pointless in all activities.

Grind, grind, grind. This is the least expansive, exploratory racing game I've ever played. Do one mission over and over and over until you get it right, then move onto the next. Then keep plugging away at that one till you complete it. You can't opt out to practise; you're locked into a railroaded story which, so far, seems to be written by a 12-year-old who's watched five minutes of Fast and Furious.

It's got console-to-PC badness all over it; a handful of controller moves - brake, nitrous, accelerate and handbrake; yep ... that's it. I've played about 75 minutes of this thing and I'm done.

Gone are the days of Underground.

I have been playing NFS since NFS 2 SE (1990's ) and been a fan of this franchise for 20+ years but after NFS Carbon there have been nothing new in any of the NFS game ( Except the NFS RUN ) . 

NFS Payback trailer looks promising but I personally  didn't like the game ( Will explain it below) 

If you are looking for a Racing Game and you donot own any NFS game then this is a steel deal but the graphics and quality that forza is offering NFS need to step up . NFS Payback is indeed Mediocre 

So what this game does right and what it doesn't goes as following:-

PROS

- Beautiful Visuals with attention to detail like rain drops appearing on car when it rains. Every car looks amazing!
- In depth customization, body, paints, wraps, under-light neon, tons of body parts hoods, side skirts, rims, sound-system, nitrous colors, smoke colors, even horns etc.
- Great open world map with tons of events across, off-road, sprint, drift, time trials.
- 100's of cars to buy and many to unlock through completing achievements and gathering all collectibles.
- AI is pretty good and challenging.
- Cops are pretty great too.
- Great night and day system. In day you earn cash by doing events and at night you get reputation which helps in unlocking more performance parts.
- Performance was pretty great for my PC which is 7-8 years old by now.
- The car feels great and controls good too.
- Eargasmic engine sounds and you can even customize them. Engine swaps alter the sound too.

CONS

- Half baked online multiplayer system where you can't easily match-make with other players. You need to invite your real life friends or get lucky with some random person who is willing to race with you. Crew system is not fleshed out either.

- Music track is kinda boring and leans heavily on pop genre more than rock or metal music like in past entries. (my own personal taste)

- Story is pretty mediocre and story-related missions are very few.

I bought this game expecting it to be another let-down, especially since my previous NFS experiences were Most Wanted (2012) and Rivals, both of which lacked anything substantial and were as hollow as games come. Payback on the other hand proved me wrong and made sure I had a damn good time during the 60 hours that I spent in it. There's a cringeworthy story here but it somehow makes you wanna see it through to the end, and it gives you purpose to upgrade your cars and manage your team throughout different racing disciplines. The opposition gradually becomes stronger and it's up to us to keep up with them.

Performance upgrades aside, the visual ways one can boost their ride are plenty. From bumpers to neons, there's quite a selection of things you can customize, and there really were times when Payback reminded me of the Underground era. It's also got that amazing livery editor where you can use all kinda pictures and shapes to basically paint paintings on your ride. Really loved it.

The handling is very arcadey but it felt much more down-to-earth than, say, NFSMW:2012, especially at lower levels with slower cars. The cars are no longer rockets, they won't automatically start pre-scripted drifting whenever you make a turn, and with a wheel and a sequential shifter the driving actually feels really nice and intuitive. Of course, it's less so when you reach McLarens, Lambos and Koenigseggs, but even they feel good to drive.

Overall, I thought Payback was gonna be a flop NFS game but I had a ball once I started playing. A really well done arcade racer.

This is one of the more pure fun, arcade-style NFS games, probably most similar to NFS: Heat in all major respects, including the graphics, customization options and game mechanics, with a few of its own unique quirks.

[b]PROS:[/b]

- This isn't a simulator, and you don't have to be a hardcore racing game player. The focus is on fun, not realism. There are plenty of options for people who want sim racing, but this is for more for people who enjoy car culture, the thrill of the race and the cars themselves.

- Drifting is a hell of a lot of fun in this game

- Each car is acquired for a specific type of race/event, and you can acquire "doubles" (or triples, if you want) and kit them out differently for different tasks. For example, you can use the Porsche 911 to drift, race or as a runner, which is essentially a combination of getaway driver, high-stakes delivery and police outrunner.

- Each of the characters has their own specialty, and the characters and voice acting are vastly superior to NFS Heat, along with the story. (Although, like all these games, the story isn't what you're here for and it isn't great. It does, however, hold everything together and give it purpose.) David Ajala (Star Trek Discovery, Nightflyers, Kill Command) is the best of the bunch as Mac, while Jessica Madsen is amusing as the foul-mouthed, irritable getaway driver Jessica Miller.

- Derelicts are classic cars that you assemble from pieces you find out in the game world, starting with the chassis. Each derelict consists of 5 parts. Once you collect them, you can upgrade them like any other car, then take them a step further with "super builds" offering visuals you can't get on other vehicles. They're also some of the best cars in the game. The Nissan Fairlady 240ZG '71, for example, is an absolute beast when it's drift-tuned, allowing you to pull off drifts that are near impossible in other cars, while the Mustang 1965 is a very good race car and a spectacular off-road option.

- The visual customization options are deep and allow for serious creativity. This system worked so well, it was brought back exactly as-is for Heat. As an added bonus, you can grab paint/wrap schemes made by other players in the "Community" tab. They're displayed by popularity, giving you easy access to the best of the best. You can also get ideas and figure out how other players achieved certain looks and designs by downloading their wraps and taking a closer look.

- The game isn't overly punishing when it comes to visual damage. You can disable visual damage if you'd like, but unlike Heat, cars don't automatically accumulate wear if you don't hit anything, and you won't see damage from small collisions or bumps.


[b]CONS:[/b]

- The soundtrack is terrible. I don't know why the developers feel bound to use only current music, because the atmosphere and visuals would lend themselves to songs from all eras. Like the Heat soundtrack, it's jarring at times. Where Heat could have benefited from synthwave, 80s, retro-80s, metal, Latin and rock (reflecting the real Miami and its pop culture image), Payback could do a lot better than trap and mumble rap, especially when your character is tearing up the desert at night or cruising down the highway in sun-drenches Las Vegas.

- Like every NFS game, and virtually every driving game, the cars are gated. Whereas in Heat and some other games you're required to reach certain rep, in Payback the cars are unlocked via mission completion, chapter by chapter. The downside is that it may take you quite a while, even until late game, to get the car you really want most, and the choices in the early going are generally not great.

- The rubber banding everyone keeps talking about isn't bad in offroad, and is a nonfactor in drift and drag for obvious reasons, but in race it's obvious and very annoying. 

- Likewise, certain styles are more difficult than others. Offroad felt a lot easier to me than race. Drag was ridiculously easy. Drift takes some getting used to, but once you've found the groove and rhythm, it's awesome. And runner ranges from incredibly easy to somewhat difficult, with the timed delivery missions on the harder end of the spectrum.

- The upgrade system is based on random cars rather than buying from a choice of specific parts. That puts you at the mercy of RNG in every way: The card drops from races are random, the cards sold in tune-up shops are random, and just in case you haven't had enough RNG, you can "roll" for cards using a special currency, with no control over the "brand" you get or the attributes of the card. For example, one card may have an upgrade to Jump ability, while another may upgrade Acceleration, Speed and Nitrous. 

[b]OVERALL:[/b]

If you like more arcade-style racing games and enjoy killing time tweaking the look of your cars, you should get a few dozen hours of fun out of NFS Payback. It's a well-made game.

The game looks pretty good, but that optimization is terrible, just like in Mafia III.

Pros:
+Campaign.
+Cars.
+Optional side quests like: drifting, speeding test, speed camera.
+Searching wrecked cars after beating bosses.
+RX-7 and Nissan are fastests cars in this game.
+Pursuit doesn't look so bad when i noticed really brutal & aggressive cops behavior.
+Leveling up in this game is so easy.
+Searching tokens is just another minigame to farm some money and XP points.

Cons:
-Optimization is really terrible, just like at Mafia III.
-Performance is not so good, because even on lowest graphics settings this game works pretty bad and here's a reason why. Because the game has DRM protection called itself: DENUVO The PC Killer.
-Disturbing reflections of lights on the car when you play on lowest graphic settings, it can kill your eyes.
-Disappearing textures after playing 3-4 hours.
-Trading cards loot tuning upgrades system is really terrible, you have to spent about 2.5k trade cards or more to ace your car with same 3 card tiers.
-AI could be a bit more aggressive even on hard difficulty.
-No CO-OP mode.

Conclusion: 2/10. This game had a chance to be really good game, but EA didn't listened and decided to disappoint me. Do not buy this game if you're not ready to face disturbing reflections of lights on a cars, disappearing textures, bad optimization and etc.

It's an alright game nothing more nothing less.

Pros - graphics are good, voice acting is good, has a decent story, collectables are cool, the derelict assemble cars gameplay mechanic is really cool (you find parts and u build a car out of them), there are different types of races the best are normal ones, drags and drifting ones, soundtrack and SFX are really good, the game has a  welcome photo mode, huge free roam map with cool locations, the main character isn't that bad, there are also cops and crashing them is fun, car Visual costumization is mostly good. 

Cons - handling is kinda stiff not gonna lie and it feels like it fights you, writing is silly and laughable at times, bugs and glitches, there are car classes and it isn't fun (sounds good but it's terrible, you end up having to buy way to much sh*t), races are tied to the story some are fun and few in numbers and others are NOT and you are forced to do them (ruins the experience), car costumization isn't bad but lacks a little bit still, the way we unlock Visual costumization parts is annoying, the 2 side characters are kinda cringe and annoying some times, THERE IS NO RESET BUTTON and the auto reset is f*cking dog Sh*t, gps some times fails to point the way, bets before the races suck (both the money we get as well as the money we lose and what we have to do), there are 5 race types off road racing (feels like you are on ICE at all times) and runner events (time trials or lazy version of the toolboth events from NFS MW 2005) are lame as f*ck, performance upgrades are done through CARDS actual f*cking CARDS and there is fixed time before you can buy more (10 mins per shipment), there is also a slot machine for them (wtf EA Games, you f*cked up hard here), vanity items (items like horns, tire smoke or nitrous colour) are trash and can be bought through shipments AKA LOOTBOXES, game performance issues (Cpu usage Problems).  

Final Realistic Verdict is a 60%. (Final Verdict varies from 10% to 100%)

Final Bias/Blind to the issues Verdict is a 70%. (Final Verdict varies from 10% to 100%)

Blur+Burnout Paradise+The Wheelman= Need for Speed Payback.

I wasn't expecting much, but this game is a ton of fun! I haven't had this much fun with an NFS game since Most Wanted 2005. That game is still my top NFS game but this one is up there with it. But the best part? No need to worry about microtransactions at all!!!! They're in there, but there's absolutely no reason to pay extra money for "speed points" for upgrades, and this is an EA game!!!! Holy shit I know!!!!

The racing is fun, the graphics look gorgeous, and it runs great, (after disabling vsync in game and using Nvidia vysnc plus a 60fps frame limiter). There's 3 difficulty settings and you can change it at any time. I started on medium but switched to easy a few hours in to ease the rubber banding. Tons of things to do, and the trademark NFS story cheesiness is in full force as usual...which is something I always look forward to in this series. 

The main character, Tyler,(he does races) has the personality of a bagel. He's the most generic, uninteresting white guy they could find. Mac (he does off-road) is silly and doesn't seem to take things too seriously, probably my favorite. Jessica (she does runner missions from the cops, reminded me a lot of The Wheelman game) were the most exciting to me. She has an annoying, monotone voice, but after a while it grew on me and now it's kinda hot at the same time so I don't know what's happening there. And the main villian reminds me of a llama so there's that.

The speed cards are fine as they upgrade performance. Cool, no problem. You earn them through events and can buy them with in game currency. You'll also get item and cash packs (called shipments) as you play too which is cool. One problem I do have (well at first) was cosmetics. In order to unlock them you need to do certain tasks in the world, (destroy 3 billboards to unlock the ability to purchase rims with in game currency for example). So this kinda made me not want to even bother with the cosmetics portion of the game. However, at the same time, the more you play you're most likely going to be doing some of these things anyway and probably without even knowing it, so it's best to not worry about it until a few hours into your game. There's also a really cool feature called derrilct in that there's special car parts scattered throughout the world and if you find all 5 for each vehicle (I think there's 4 or 5 total) you get to build it and get it souped up. Drive around, get the notification on your mini map it's close by and go get it. My favorite was the speedcross(?) tournament missions as these are arenas where you get to drift, go fast, destroy stuff and do huge jumps. There were only 20 of those events but I had a blast doing them all. 

There's also fast travel points (gas stations) which are very welcome. Drive around close to one and it adds it to your map. Same thing with billboards and other collectibles and side activities. World map is great and has filters so you can narrow down to what you're looking for easily. You can set a pin and route it to your mini map, same thing with any activity, although I usually just fast traveled as close as possible.

These games have always had not great soundtracks in my opinion and this game is no different. You can't create your own playlist and remove tracks you don't like. You either get hip hop or "rock", but it's more like hipster alternative music. So the volume slider on music got turned down to about 30% just so there's something else going on besides engine noises and the bagel talking the while time.

Need for Speed: Payback is a racing game, where you and your crew pulling of a steal, but the one who gave you the job betray you and you want to take revenge, meanwhile the city full of gambling starts to hit the streets and racing is not what it used to be.

A lot of people hate the soundtrack in this game, however in my opinion, it's pretty all right. I'm not saying it's better than the OG "I'm Rock" or more OG "Black Betty", but there are a few decent tracks in this game. Also the sound design is not bad, however there are times, when engine sounds for certain cars sounds exactly same or some moaning or shouting sounds ridiculous, but still it's all right.

About the story, it's not the most deepest thing ever, there are few black holes in it, where the plot either not makes any sense or just the characters do something stupid, but still better than the 2015 NFS's story by a mile. There are a few smaller twist, but in general it's pretty simple. Characters are not deep at all, some of them pretty annoying, because of their "cool" lines, but at the end, I was all right with them. Probably my favorite characters from the game is the Curator and Marcus Weir. If you want to play a NFS game because of it's story, except a really simple and most of the time weak story from this game, but for a NFS, it's okay.

Graphics in this game is okay. There are lot of graphical bugs, either textures don't want to load in at all, bushes goes into the air or the camera goes through the level, it's all in the game, but these are not that common. I was okay with it throughout the game.

The controls of this game is... not the most pleasant thing in the universe. You can control your car decently, but my biggest issue was with the turning and drifting. The game has the break-drift mechanic from 2015 NFS game, which I wasn't the biggest fan of, but here drifting is essential for taking some corners, however at the beginning, it was a pain to get use to and I had a really hard time to even race properly. Also, every damn car is under steering in this game, it's impossible to take corners without drifting or owning a decent car. However, I around mid game, I started to get use to it and it was okay, however it's a really weird to control these cars in this game, comparing to other racing games. 

Now, let's talk about the gameplay. In general, it's working and somewhat fun. You can play through the Campaign, doing story missions, challenges, beating roaming racers, finding collectables, getting into chases, buy and tune your cars, these are all working. You can also play multiplayer, where you can use your cars from the story mode, racing with others in different playlists, which is all right and you can get lot of reward for it too. However, the devil is in the details. First thing which gave me literal cancer and you probably know it too, is the tuning. If you want to get better parts in your car, it's not about having lot of money, unlocking the better parts, no... it's RNG based. At the end of the races, you can choose cards, which are the car parts for that specific car, which you used in that race. The car part has a level, brand and additional bonuses for certain attributes, like nitro, speed, acceleration or... air... which makes your car jump higher and lose less speed when reaching ground. You can also get parts with a slot machine game, where you need to use 3 car parts in order to get one POSSIBLY all right... and of course, you can buy higher level, but no attribute cards for money. But wait... what happens if you don't have enough money for upgrading and you don't have a decent car for the races? Well, you can replay races and doing side bets, which are challenges for the race for extra money, which is pretty good. You can grind this no problem, even you can sell your car parts, if don't want it... ooorrrr you can open loot boxes for more money and car parts tickets or even getting extra custom parts for your car... and don't think these loot boxes are for free... you can get them free, but you can only buy them for real money. I don't know who was that genius, who thought this is a good idea, but this is probably the most re****** thing I ever saw in a game. Also, I don't get it why the player needs 5 different car for 5 different event type... and what is even more weirder, different event types cars has different handling, even if we are talking about the same car, but in a different class. There is one race type which I didn't get it, this was Rallycross. The race type is similar to Gymkhana, however in Payback, this race type is complete optional, and there is no reason to play it after completing the quest line. The game not even using it properly, and there is only 2 cars for this race type to use and tuning it... what's the point having it? About the gameplay, I need to mention the difficulty. I played through the game on Hard, which was a great idea, because the game wasn't easy at all to beat, but not frustratingly difficulty or rubberband heavy... but there is Chapter 5, where the game and the story missions start to get ridiculously difficult. AI has way better car than you and upgrading is still a pain, thanks to the RNG slot machine and card system, you can't acquire good enough cars at the beginning of the chapter. My only chance was to complete courier storyline and unlock better cars at the end, but it was pretty difficult. When you get decent cars in this Chapter, the game will be much easier at that point, but this difficulty spike got me real good. Last thing which I didn't liked in the game, is the cop chases. There are even problem with the basics, because destroying cop cars are not easy sometimes, because there is no pursuit breaker to help you, only ramming the police which has inconsistent damage system. But this would be not that big of a deal, but the police rubberbanding hard... and even this wouldn't be a thing, but all of the pursuits are script heavy and it's only mission based. Literally, in free roam I never encountered a police or house car. Most useless thing in the game. All of this has a mixed feeling in the gameplay, but it still holds a decent gameplay feeling to the game.

Need for Speed: Payback is not without bugs or bad development traits, but I had all right, casual time with the game. I recommend to give it a shot, but get the game on sale for around 8€, considering the play time.

After enough hours to beat the main story as I wasn't really interested in getting all collectibles or doing any side missions. I can say that as far as NFS game goes Payback is ok. The storyline is very basic leaning more towards bland and boring at times, characters aren't really relatable  or standout in any way but at least this time around for once our character has a name and a face so that's good I guess. As far as mechanics go the game is very smooth truthfully, the upgrade system via tune-shop cards is really simple and easy to get a grip on early on so that you don't really have to pay crazy attention to detail later to how you're tuning your cars. Graphics are good nothing to drool about but certainly they're not subpar, the car collection is very generous and assorted which is also great. The 3 racing classes that you have access to them being Offroad, Runner or Racer spice up the game enough to give you extra playtime if you are a completionist or really want to squeeze the most out of the game before being done for good. Overall the game to me is a solid 6/10 : entertaining enough to kill time and scratch that racing itch but nothing that will keep you hooked for any extended period of time, nothing is innovative enough for you to want to bother exploring or taking time to find out more about any given feature so in the end if you can purchase this game and it'll be your money's worth 100% as long as you get it heavily discounted.

TL;DR: game is ok, huge open world, racing mechanics are good and huge car collection. If you're looking for a lot of replayability and a decent storyline you're not getting that here. Overall get it on a massive sale then it'll be worth it.

I have beat the game and am currently working to 100% it so here is my view on it.

I love the story. It has to be one of the best in the entire need for speed franchise and my favorite. It has twists and turns and a very good villan. I also like how much fun this game is to grind. The tokens and billboards and even just the speed cameras are fun to 3 star. Getting all your cars to 399 and unlocking all the customization options feels very rewarding. 

On the other hand, the handling and physics of the game are ok. I hate how you can crash into a telephone pole going 200 mph in a ford raptor and bounce off. That is probably the most frusturating thing in the game. The fact that you have to have 2 seprate cars for different races are a little bit annoying. I don't want to have to buy 2 McLaren P1s. The shipments suck. The in game purchases are horrible. 

In conclusion, if you are looking for a more layed back need for speed game with a nice story to get sucked into, this is the one. If you are looking for a high octance racing game like need for speed heat or need for speed rivals, this is not the game you are looking for.

After having a blast replaying Hot Pursuit (2010) in its Remastered version, I’ve decided to check what the series have actually been up to in the latest entries. First one up was Need for Speed Payback and I gotta say, the first impressions were very poor. Yet, I did get through the entire game, having played most of the events, so there is something good to it as well. Not much, but it’s not an entirely unfun experience.

Need for Speed Payback is a rather bizarre desire to combine elements from The Run and Most Wanted, but also add in distinctly different classes of cars for different types of events. As such, it has a (terrible) story with (boring) characters that explains every racing event that happens, though at least it lacks QTEs. On top of it, it focuses way too much on the open world, and by that I mean busywork and pointless driving to where the actual race is. And every racing event belongs to a certain class that requires a separate car, so you can’t off-road in a car made for drifting, or do races in a car made for drag racing. Oh and because it’s EA from 2017, almost every aspect of the game is designed for microtransactions and loot boxes, to the point that the setting of the game is a city full of casinos and gambling.

The plot is sadly unavoidable, but at least it has a few decent characters in it. And to be fair, while I still don’t understand the desire to put any storyline in an NFS game, this might be one of the better ones in the series. And luckily, unlike The Run, most of the really heavily scripted sequences happen during situations, where you’re not meant to believe like you’re actually racing instead of going through a scripted sequence. The real events are real and don’t force the “cinematic moments” in just for the sake of it.

The world in the game is, frankly, boring. And despite the technologically advanced visuals, there’s nothing exciting about how the game looks. It doesn’t help that all of the open world busywork is there literally to be busywork and aren’t even remotely fun to do. Apart from a rather curious concept of treasure hunting for unlocking several special cars. You can’t just start a race, you must ride to where it begins and stop. And the amount of fast travel points in the game is far more limited than you might want. So a lot of the time will be spent just driving to where you need to be to play the game.

Not that the game itself is that exciting. Frankly, I was seriously considering dropping it altogether after a few hours, and it wasn’t until I decided to play a separate event sequence about Speedcross on a whim that I got more invested in the game. That whole event bundle is, shockingly, a DLC for the game (available as part of the Deluxe edition), despite being the highlight of the entire game and being far superior to what you get during the mainline. Races range from being boring to being somewhat okay. Off-road races are usually mediocre and sometimes frustrating. Drifting is great and works rather well with the handling in this game. Drag races are some of the worst races I’ve experienced in any racing game. While the special Runner missions sound exciting at first, being focused on escapes and battles against police cars, but in reality turn out to be either boring or just plain frustrating.

Possibly, the biggest thing I could say about the way racing feels in this one, especially after Hot Pursuit Remastered, is that it’s plain, boring and uneventful. Crashing the car still exists, but it’s hard to tell why – you can bump a wall, back up, start riding as if nothing happened and then have a car reset, because apparently that was a crash. There’s no sense of speed or spectacle. Rubber banding doesn’t exist in a conventional sense, as everything seems to be tied directly to, essentially, “level scaling” which in itself is tied to the microtransaction fueled system. So if you are overpowered, you just ride seconds if not minutes in front of everyone else until the finish line. And if you’re underpowered, you might not even have a chance to win (in Drag races it’s literally impossible to win underpowered, no matter how good you are). And handling is just… weird. No class of car feels right, the way drifting is handled is unconventional and sometimes your inputs seem to be just dropped entirely as the car might refuse to turn when you attempt to.

So yes, the gambling stuff. Basically, you have several kinds of “currency”, as in any microtransaction fueled game, and upgrading your car’s performance is tied to special “cards”. Those cards drop randomly, just like your typical lootboxes, after each event. And can be purchased at tune shops. All of them have random attributes and are always just slightly above in level than what you already have. All of the cards are tied just to the car you’re driving and cannot be used by other cars. Oh and also if you don’t see a card in the store that you want, you can try a literal slot machine to win one, that takes another kind of currency. All of these kinds of fake money can be bought with real money, of course. And this entire design sucks and makes the game completely uninteresting. Because, as I said, you must keep up with these upgrades to actually win, but if you spec your car too high (and why wouldn’t you), then no opponent can keep up with you.

Up until the very end, which was super uneventful and uninteresting, I expected this game to have something. Like the surprising fun discovery of Speedcross events. But no. The most fun and well designed events are a few and the game mostly consists of really tedious races and escapes and cutscenes and boredom. There are cool things to be found in Need for Speed Payback, but it’s simply not worth the time and effort it takes to get the best out of this title.

Overall, it's okay. It's not a game with life-changing story. For a NFS story, it's pretty good. Considering most NFS games don't have great stories. It's better than The Last of Us 2, you get my point. The upgrading system with speed cards is awful. You gotta look at the perks, numbers and brands of cards to make your car faster. Controls and physics are drifty and they're okay once you master them. Also you gotta buy different car builds for each type of race, if you have Deluxe Edition, it won't be much of an issue tho.

In conclusion: if you want an arcade racing game for a change, it's alright. Wait for a discount tho, At least myself, I wouldn't pay full price for a 4 year old NFS game

Disclaimer: I played NFS: Heat before this, so there is strong bias in here. 

The story is alright, feels like an unfinished movie really. Not terrible, but not brilliant either. However this is Need For Speed, and we're not here for the story really. The selection of cars are alright, but the card system to modify your car's performance is extremely irritating. Graphics are alright and the handling of the cars too. Speaking of cars, the "class" system i.e. drag, drift, runner, etc is interesting, but annoying at the same time. Personally I didn't like it, but I can how someone would be interested in it. 

You can definitely tell where NFS:Heat took inspiration from, and how it's gotten much better. That said, this is FAR better than Undercover and NFS 2015. 

Get it on sale, it'll be worth it then. Otherwise...honestly, you're not missing out on much.

--What is it?--
A really good looking racer. Beautiful cars, a long drawn out story to keep things moving along, and a open world consisting of a city and backwoods areas with plenty of races and race types to choose from. There are key points in the plot that gives very much a feeling of driving in a action movie. For most of the time it's a relatively casual driving game, and that's pretty fun all around. You need to upgrade your cars to be competitive as the races progress, and you can pretty much determine your own difficulty setting by how your car compares to the recommended level car that you need to bring to a race.

There are a lot of cars that you can unlock to buy, and a variety of places to drive. There's also motor car parts that you can buy, to upgrade your vehicles as well as customise your ride in different ways to add a personal touch. You can change the colour, add art to it, or even change the bodywork of segments of the cars.

I played Payback for a straight 11 hours, now I should be half way there, know what to expect and I decide not to keep playing. 

I started to play NFS 2, NFS 3 in the 90s. It used to be a circuit asks player to run in day time/night, with other racers or hot pursuit, then reverse the map or mirror it. Now the NFS games have main stories, a big map to roam, a protagonist and crew and a city. It's okay but seems Payback forget an important element: FUN CIRCUITS.

It is not fun when drive mostly on a wild straight road. 
Also, the background seems monotonous, the circuits are too simple, opponents are weak, challenges are too repetitive. Uninteresting plot, uninteresting police chase, non stop dialogue. Why even bother add a Volkswagen Golf to the dealer I am playing NFS not Test Driver.

Disappointing.

[h1]EDIT: Correction[/h1]
Totally my bad. In my rush to put up a review, i overlooked a crucial feature; graphics quality.
There 6 main options; auto, low, med, high, ultra and custom. Custom is where you can do the tweaking. All the options you could possibly want is there.

[b]Main review here - prior to the above correction[/b]

Recommended spec is RX-480 4GB, i have RX-580 8GB, yet it still lags horribly; fps sometimes drop below 30 and this is at 720p with the lowest graphics settings. Very disappointing, it kinda kills my enthusiasm to play this; feels more like a chore than fun.

Even when fps reads 60 in the cutscenes or gameplay, it appears more like 30. At times it even appears like 25, very choppy, yet shows 60 fps. Even someone with an RTX couldn't impress me; i can still see stuttering and lag. Should've taken that as a red-flag. Instead, i was curious because my card handled F1 2020 very well at settings other than lowest.

Graphics options are minimal, so there's not much you can tweak. There's;
[olist]
[*]resolution of course, 
[*]fullscreen or windowed
[*]v-sync on or off
[*]blur on or off
[/olist]

[b]AND,[/b] get this, the most underwhelming option of all: graphics quality; auto, low, medium or high. WUT?? Nothing to see here, move on. So there, all you can eat buffet for tweakers; not much to choose from.

I bought this primarily for the cinematic cutscenes, not for the cars nor world nor upgrades nor customizations, although, those are nicely done. The cutscenes is a whole lot better than earlier NFS titles; they are epic IMO.

So here's the breakdown scores:
[list]
[*]Cutscenes - 8
[*]Story - 7
[*]Graphics - 8
[*]Music - 7 
[*]Sound Effects - 8
[*]Voice acting - 8
[*]Driving mechanics - 6
[*]Slow Motion Car Kill cams - 7 (framing and FOV a bit disappointing at times)
[*]Performance is erratic - 5 (stuttering and lags) I think you need faster RAM and SSD storage. 
[/list]

Overall score - [b]7.1/10[/b]
Reluctantly a yes recommendation because maybe with faster RAM clocking and SSD you might get better results. I might migrate this installation to the NVMe SSD drive and overclock the RAM a bit to see if the performance improves.

Oh BTW, i disabled 4 cores and SMT to see if there are any improvements because the system requirements specifically states 4 threads. Unsure if there is any but maybe there is 1 or 2 fps improvements.

Most fun I've had in a NFS game since "Carbon". The game has a short but very nice underdog/revenge story, much better than in NFS Heat in my opinion. The only fault it might have is that it's performance part build of the cars is none existent and is replaced with 6 part cards you can upgrade. This isn't really an issue but it might be if you liked buying individual performance parts like in previous NFS games. On the other hand the performance parts cards setup makes it easy to get your cars as fast as possible really quickly, so there is more time for Racing, Jumps ,Collectables etc. It's a definite must have if you love racing games.

Need for Speed: Payback turned out to be a big surprise for me. This is in several respects. I expected it to be a terrible production mostly focused on the plot, but it is not. What's more, it turned out that the gameplay model borrowed from other arcade games open-world solutions with a car power index indicating the progress in the game. Although there is no atmosphere or the spirit of Need for Speed ​​in it, the whole thing is surprisingly good, and the final effect is spoiled mainly by the forced microtransaction system, tedious gringing, infantile scenario and Polish dubbing. Additionally, the game lacks a multiplayer mode. In other words, despite the fact that the drive itself is quite pleasant and the game is very nice in terms of visuals, I recommend other racing arcade productions - I would use Payback only when you pass them, feeling the lack of arcade racing.

Being a big fan of the Need for Speed series since Hot Pursuit 2, I was heavily disappointed in releases like 2012's Most Wanted and 2013's Rivals, being one of the worst games released in the entire franchise to date in my opinion. 2015 was a step in the right direction but felt lacking when it came to the driving model. Having come off that, how does Need for Speed: Payback fare?

For those who want the short version - do I recommend it? Keeping in mind the horrible requirement of Origin & possibly bad optimization of the game, despite that I had a very enjoyable time with the game. So if you want a fun racing game you can spend, give or take, 10-ish hours as a first playthrough beating, I'd say go for it.

For those who want something a little extra - read on!

[h1]Story:[/h1]
NFS Payback's story isn't anywhere near as bad as some have made it out to be. Granted I don't think the pacing or writing of it was good but that doesn't mean I think it was bad. Rather I'd say it's underdeveloped instead. You go from being pals with Lina Navarro at the start to suddenly having her be your mortal enemy all within 20 minutes of the game and that just felt weird. They didn't give us enough time to invest into her character and give us a motive for hating her, it just felt like "lina do bad, you must go hate lina and take her down now" and that's about it.

I also think the main antagonists - The House - were left way too ambiguous. Not in a good way - they just didn't feel super significant in the grand scheme of things which is odd. Instead, what I end up remembering more about the story of Payback is probably the main trio you play as - Tyler, Mac and Jess - and the crews you take down along the way. But The House? I couldn't give two hoots about them as I played through and even after finishing them off in the last race I'm left wondering "who were they anyway?"

Where the game picks up the slack though I think is in the minor interactions & references. There were moments throughout the story where I had a giggle at some of the references to past games. I won't spoil them if you haven't seen them already yet but Payback likes to make callbacks to older NFS games and I thought that was a nice touch, even going on to answer some things about the older games. And the interactions your characters have with some of the crews you end up taking down are also entertaining, some just being smug, others feeling like the characters have a broken marriage among them where they hate each other one race and the next one they're all buddy-buddy reminiscing about their past. I found that really endearing.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Coming off of 2015's poorly-received driving model, Payback had a lot of shoes to fill. I'm very happy to report that the driving model is vastly improved over its predecessor's, making you feel like you have full control over your car...for the most part. Brake-to-drift is, once again, one of the main ways to get your car around corners, meaning it's still got that bootleg Burnout feeling to it. Admittedly it stopped bothering me after the first chapter of the game though I'm still not a huge fan of the way Need for Speed's been for the last 11+ years and sadly Payback is here to continue that trend. Despite that - the game feels great to play. Cars are fast, responsive and, baring in mind a few exceptions, I felt like I was actually in total control over my car. Getting from place to place, unlike in 2015, didn't feel like a chore and I greatly appreciate the improvements.

The one problem I have with the driving model in Payback is one of its core new introductions - off-roading. Off-roading honestly sometimes feels like the game has gone back to 2015 with cars being slippery and unresponsive. I get that it's the whole point - it's intended to be a challenge, but more often than not driving off-road meant it was time to wrestle with the game instead of actually playing it. The off-road races are going to be the closest thing to the "Tandem Drift" event from 2015 if you ever found that fun.

Improved driving model aside, there is one thing about the gameplay that I genuinely disliked and was a very common complaint throughout my playthrough - the progression system. Why oh WHY did they make the progression system based on GAMBLING?! I get it - it fits thematically with the game's lore. But is it fun to play? Hell no. GAMBLING for car upgrades is STUPID. Not being able to buy the parts you want for your build is STUPID. Having the upgrade shop be based on a timer is STUPID. The way you progress in this game is just STUPID. It is easily the worst part about the game and sours the experience for me. Sure you can earn Speed Cards by winning events, but if your car is underpowered for a specific part of the game and you wanna make it better - that's when you have to engage with this game's gambling & loot box system and it's DUMB. I genuinely hate it.

One minor comment I'm not sure whether I like or not is the lack of free roam cops. One the one hand - it makes traversing the open world to get to your next destination a lot smoother since you don't have to worry about getting randomly chased out of nowhere and the game has more than enough free roam activities to keep you busy & wandering around otherwise. On the other hand - for how involved the police is in the game's story it feels incredibly weird to leave them out of being able to chase you in free roam? Gotta take the good with the bad on this one I suppose. Personally despite how weird it is to not have them in free roam I didn't really mind all that much. The game filled in the cops' shoes well enough by giving you a huge variety of activities to partake in anyway.

[h1]Graphics, Sound & Optimization[/h1]
Despite playing the game entirely on low settings, I think NFS Payback looks great. It's visually distinct, vivid and disregarding the desert setting the game generally looks colorful, lively and full of detail. Cars get realistically dirty & damaged the more you drive & beat them and provides you with plenty of customization options for stuff like tire smoke & nitrous.

The music I can't comment on despite having finished the game as I had the entire soundtrack disabled throughout my entire playthrough and listened to other songs while playing instead. The sound is a different story. First of all - the voice acting. Despite Jess sounding like she's bored 24/7 and Mac getting insanely annoying with how much he just can't shut up about himself, I think the voice acting in this game is pretty good. Characters under their roles sound convincing and there were definitely some moments that had me give the game a chuckle or two.

Optimization wise...well, to preface this - I streamed my entire playthrough of the game on Twitch. And let's just say that my PC isn't the most powerful thing on the planet. So I frequently encountered plenty of stutters, plenty of framedrops and even a few times when the game just unloaded & reloaded everything directly in front of my eyes. Sometimes just not loading ANYTHING at all, causing me to fall through the map! However I'm willing to chalk all that up to just the game struggling to juggle resources on my PC rather than the game itself being very poorly optimized. For the curious - my PC is an i5-4460 with a GTX 1650 and 16GB of RAM.

Also this game REQUIRES Origin. Take that as a warning - [b][u]you will be forced to download and make an Origin account just to play this game.[/u][/b] For some - this might as well be a dealbreaker.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Do I recommend NFS Payback? If you want a 10+ hour racing game with callbacks to previous games and a fun handling model, I'd say go for it. At $30 you get your money's worth. If you disliked 2015 like a lot of people did, Payback will make you appreciate the amount of improvements made to basically everything.

However if you don't like engaging with gambling to progress, I'd advise to stay away.

I really tried liking this game. It has some great and genuinely enjoyable parts. A bit over the top and like you're in an action movie, but hey, that's fine in an arcade racer. There are 2 things that make me want to give up on this game for good every time I play it. The first being the upgrade system using CARDS instead of just being able to buy upgrades like every other game that has worked so well for years. To be honest, I could even get over the cards, even though I think it is one of the worst things NFS has ever tried. The one thing that makes me want to claw my eyes out with a spoon is the OFF-ROAD RACING. HOW DID THIS MAKE IT PAST TESTING?! Seriously, you'd be better off racing them with your eyes closed because no matter what you do on the controller the vehicle is going to do whatever it wants off-road. You try to correct a slide you think is going pretty well and you end up slamming into rocks the opposite direction because the controls off-road are so terrible. Skip this game and get literally any other NFS title and Dirt Rally if you want to do some off-road racing.

I have love hate relationship with this game

Overall the cars feels good, drifting is real fun oh and i think this is the first nfs with rally, which is also fun. The map is pretty diverse and fun to explore. The photomode is nice too

The story is okay, i expect nothing less, i just wish there is more cutscene and story driven mission.

Now the hate part, first rally handling need more tweaking, rally is fun until the car decide to slides on dirt and oversteer like crazy even on supposedly awd car. Then some BS mission than force you to drive outside car class comfort zone (this one maybe because i suck)

Then the whole progression system, Payback using card system stolen from The Crew (well many thing stolen from The Crew) so if you play The Crew you already familiar. With this system no matter how crap your car, you can level it up until you can beat exotics easily. 

The problem when you want to buy another car, even for same class, you need to get the card again by random. Luckily steam version has some money boost, so you dont really have to grind as long as you stick to one car for each class.

Oh yeah, for the car customization part, its good enough for me. Except some part customization is locked until specific condition fulfiled which is terrible. Also tyre customization is so ugly, is just brand logo painted to the tire wall, 

If you dont mind sticking one car each class for the whole game, or grind the heck out of it. i still recommend it when on sale, its still fun game overall

Initially I reviewed this game negatively because it was the first NFS title I played since the days of Underground 2 and Most Wanted many many years ago. Compared to my memories of those titles, this game is not so good.

HOWEVER I am changing my review relative to the newer NFS titles, namely Hot Pursuit remastered and NFS 2015. Relative to those, this game is AMAZING. 
Let's be honest, the only reason you're thinking about getting this game in 2021+ is because your PC is too much of a potato (like mine) to run the latest NFS game. 

This game has a huuuge (mostly empty but still) map to explore if you enjoy doing that, and many many different events to beat, as well as challenges to complete. The car customization is a bit lacking in terms of part availability. I also don't know why the devs decided not to include roaming cops? They're literally the most fun part of the NFS series, you can sink hours into the game just by messing around with police. Well not in this game.

Music library in this game seems a bit small, cause the same few songs keep playing over and over.

NFS Payback starts off painfully slow, the slowest to start racing game I think I've ever played and I've played a LOT. The majority of the games I own on Steam/PC and consoles are racing games.

Payback looks great, performance could be better but it's not a deal breaker, the car models are very nice looking, the city is a breath of fresh air as not many games have ever really used fake Las Vegas as it's basis. The world is very nicely done and rather interesting but there are so many shortcuts taken during development, in my 5+ hours I found so many unfinished areas with literal gaps in the ground and objects. Constantly hitting invisible objects or gliding through rocks with no hit boxes.

Pro's:
+Responsive controls. A lot of Ghost/Criterion's other games like Most Wanted and Hot Pursuit were absolutely PLAGUED by awful responsiveness that was programmed in as "steering delay" a fix was created for Most Wanted by a community member but Hot Pursuit was left untouched and to me is borderline unplayable because of this.
+Everything looks really good aside from the character models.
+Selection of cars.
+Customization is pretty in-depth, you have nearly as much control creativity wise as the later Forza games.
+Tuning, that's a good thing but it's hampered by the card system.

Cons:
-The handling model doesn't feel all that great, played with my Xbox One S pad and with my Logitech G29, wheel support is an absolute joke, there are literally NO wheel options at all, on my G29 which is one of the few supported wheels for this game my steering didn't work properly at all. out of 900 degrees of turning radius the car would maybe turn 200 of that, no clutch option, no H shifter option, just nothing. Controller felt the best unsuprisingly, car drifts just by turning too much leading to too much oversteer constantly or the car won't turn hardly at all and will lead to massive understeer, this makes it very annoying to drive depending on the vehicle.
-Feeling of speed is horrible, probably one of the worst I've seen. 150MPH feels like 60MPH. Vehicles take forever to get up to speed unless fully modded. My modified '06 Subaru OBXT in real life can do 0-60 in about 3-4 seconds on average and with no heat soak at sea level I can pull 3's all day, an Audi S5 in this game takes about 5 seconds to get up to 60MPH and then it's painfully slow after that point as well. I feel like the crippling slow upgrades and the weak feeling of speed were designed to get people to drop money on this game.
-Rubber banding is atrocious and extremely easy to spot. There's also some weird hoodoo with police and enemy vehicles when they're chasing you. Multiple times when a cop has gotten close to me, without touching, my steering goes bonkers and the game starts auto steering me
-Little to no damage model.
-Tuning is stupidly limited to the card system they put in place so you're limited to only what upgrades you randomly unlock or purchase as they become available after every so minutes randomly.
-Story is weak. Characters are all extremely forgettable, models for them look awful as well. I could feel the need for tokenism pandering almost immediately. Literally every single character is awful, there is NOTHING redeeming about any of them.

I went back to The Crew 1 after this and had MUCH more fun with full proper wheel support. You can tell they were trying to make Payback as a Horizon clone but it falls short in every single aspect. I just wanna race, make money, upgrade my car, race, progress the story, make money, unlock shit and race and upgrade some more and buy and upgrade more cars along the way. Payback hinders you in almost every single way and the little activities you come across aren't even very fun. The Crew did a much better job with being able to restart immediately and even a mostly base vehicle could at least get the job done, maybe not a gold but a bronze at least. In Payback, there's some speed traps where the base vehicles or even modified can't even reach that speed yet or during the Speed Runs there are so many fucking pedestrian cars and blind turns you can't do them properly period or if you bump one of the pedestrian vehicles as a base model vehicle you'll slow down to such a point you won't make up the difference. I don't think I've ever played a game that HINDERS a vehicle's performance in the game compared to it's real life counter part. They're usually either on-par or way faster.

Just play The Crew or play Forza Horizon 4. Way way way more worth your time than this game.

This is the first NFS game I've played in quite a while and it's actually pretty decent. It's not perfect by any stretch, but as far as arcade racers go, it's worth a look if that's what you're after.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Great graphics and it holds frames well.
[*] Once you figure out the vehicle handling it becomes pretty easy to control and drift around.
[*] There's a fair amount to do in single-player if you want to complete everything. Probably 50-60 hours if you go for all activities and collectables.
[*] In the arcade spirit, tuning and upgrades are pretty simple to grasp.
[*] Vehicles sound pretty good and seem to be based on their actual engine notes, at least in some cases.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Dead multi-player.
[*] You expect a NFS story-mode to be cringe, but the story and acting is truly awful
[*] Kind of a weird and somewhat unscrupulous vehicle upgrade system that allows you to buy upgrade cards/points if you want to. It's not necessary and you can go along just fine without it, but it's just a bit sad that it's even a thing as some people may fall for it. You can acquire and fully upgrade any vehicles you want just by playing the game, but if you wanted to buy and upgrade every single vehicle, you'll either spend hundreds of hours to grind in-game currency or end up paying for these upgrades packs.
[*] It's very obvious this is a straight up console game that got a bare-bones PC port. No ability to customize gamepad controls, no manual save system, etc.
[/list]
All in all, not bad for a single-player, arcade racer. 7.5/10

So I just beat the game, and was very surprised at my experience. I went in expecting a standard NFS game. But damn the controls for this game are absolutely solid, id say its better than NFS heat. I had so much fun just driving about the city doing drifts and stuff like the controls are very responsive, if you crash its one of two reasons someone smashed into you or your own fault. 

The story flows pretty well, its abit cliche but the missions are insane, there are 3 main characters part of your crew, and in the main story missions you get to play as all 3 which is pretty cool and how it flows from character to character in these missions is so smooth that it actually enhances your experience by alot. The action in these missions are paced very well also.

You have main event types - race/Speedcross/drag/drift/offroad/runner with each event being assigned to a single character, these mini storylines tie in with the main story giving behind details of whats happening. 

The characters you come across are voiced pretty well, all having their own quirks and personality which adds to them enjoyment of the game.

Now heres the main reason why i love this game. Your car customization is absolutely amazing, being able to literally change any part of your car and add cool effects, like you can make your exhaust smoke red which made me drift more than i should just to see that sexy smoke arghhhhh.

I think this game is underappreciated, more people should definitely play it. As the reviews for this game are actually pretty good, but not many have tried it.

If its on a sale its an insta buy - I only wish i could forget everything i experienced in this game just so i can experience it all again for the first time.

NFS Payback - это своеобразная смесь GTA 5, серии фильмов Форсаж и духа NFS Underground. Разнообразные гонки, большой автопарк, большой открытый мир и куча активностей + кинематографичный сюжет. В целом, заслуживает внимания и потраченного времени.

A really fun arcade racer. It's like playing a Fast & Furious movie. It even has a paper thin plot and characters who have no chemistry whatsoever. However, that's more than enough reason to keep racing around this little town. Cars are excellent and the upgrade system is quite clever. If I were a completionist I'd still be collecting cars and upgrades. Can't wait to play to the next one.

Mechanically repugnant, with it's use of speed card and it's handling of in-game currency meaning you will be spending more time grinding cars up to stack up to races that pretty easily outpace your vehicle. Moreover, these cards are stuck on the vehicle that earns them, meaning that when you buy a new car you must start this process over. The selection is a bit small for vehicles , made more noticeable as you see some familiar grills pop up in different car categories. The best cars don't even unlock until the plot is over, or a matter of few hours from over. A decent amount of things to do in the game, but again, it's held back by the mechanics surrounding cars. In regards to the plot, it's a standard revenge tale that could have used more turns, especially since the last cutscene hinted at a character being put into a position where they may have been a greater overarching villain pulling the strings, but then the credits just roll before the major ramifications of your revenge are even really considered. I understand it's a car game and doesn't need to be War and Peace, but it wouldn't hurt for the plot to be interesting or fulfilling, especially as two of the main characters get sidelined in the finale. Finally, there is the major performance issue of stuttering  when the game is launched, lasting approximately 10-20 minutes, which is just unacceptable as it makes the game unplayable for that duration. For reference, I was using a 2070, not that I think using a better card will help as it has been identified as an optimization issue. Rather than buy this, buy NFS Heat for an arcade racer more in line with this style as it lacks most of these issues outside of a significantly weaker plot. Alternatively, you could play Absolute Drift, an excellent arcadier title that is more of high score drift focused title. NFS Hot Pursuit is great, Most Wanted is also fine. I'd rate this game about 5/10, as the experience with the vehicles themselves feel as fluent and snappy as other, and outside of an interesting, albeit wasted,  premise, really carry this game.

The Fast and Furious game we deserve, lol. I'm not usually a fan of racing games. I only ever really loved Burnout Revenge. But I played NFS Most Wanted and really enjoyed that so I figured I'd give this one a shot, especially since it was on sale. Man, I do not regret it at all. There's a story, which drives me to keep playing beyond just short and fun races. The characters are a bit 2-dimensional, but still fun. It literally feels like a Fast and Furious plot to me, but it's NFS. Arcade style handling, which I very much prefer over realistic/sim racers. Action-packed and just an all around good time. You definitely won't regret getting this even if you're a casual racing gamer like myself.

It is a good game, but it does things its predecessors did worse than they did. In particular I'm talking about pursuits and drag races.

Pursuits: They are basically just races. You have a timelimit and a set course even though the game plays in an open world. The Police just rubberband after you until you get 600m from the escape point at which point they suddenly magically can't catch up anymore. The predecessor that did this better was the highly praised NFS Most Wanted where you'd use your environment to take out cops and had to actually escape.

Drag Races: They are not bad, but a bit boring. In NFS Underground, you had fixed lanes and fully designed drag races, with which I mean every environmental car was put there for with purpose. In Payback they just let the regular traffic algorithm do its thing and hope it'll "just work", but most of the time you barely get any traffic and just go a straight line from start to finish.

Also I didn't quite like the HotWheels optic for the cars of the other contestants. Overall I still had fun though, which is good I guess

The driving in Need for Speed: Payback is both functional and solid however the controls are skewed towards drifting around corners rather than your standard turns.

The vehicle selection varies from the usual cars seen in need for speed games and customisation is expansive, even going so far as offering "super build" cosmetic adjustments for derelict cars.

The game offers multiple game types from Street races, off-road, drag, drift, stunt, police chase and more. Each of these gametypes have their own vehicle storefront allowing whilst restricting the player to owning cars for each specific mode.

A MASSIVE problem with Payback is that of its upgrade system. The developers opted to move away from your usual selection of upgrades from manufacturers and chose to implement a car part card upgrade system that locks your desired upgrades behind lots of RNG and time spent spinning the wheel. It feels awful spending most of my time with a new vehicle in a menu spinning a wheel rather than upgrading with earnt money or through races.

The story is better than the latest installment (heat) in that it has a beginning, middle and end.

Sadly, a huge turn off or frustration for some Is the dialogue and delivery from the voice actors, rivaling the cringe that was Need For Speed 2015's narrative. 

You will have to suffer through a campaign of awful one liners just to enjoy the near perfect driving and world that Need for Speed: Payback offers.

Between pretty decent graphics, to good storylines - I dont recommend this game. The main reason for my negative review is due to the neglection of not adding proper controller support for anything besides Xbox One, and thats it (You are forever stuck with Keyboard and Mouse.) and drifting using W+A or W+S and handbreak is one of the most frustrating things to attempt in this game without a controller to adjust your wheels for a cleaner drift experience without spinning out. The other reason why I dont find this game appealing is I originally bought it to enjoy the typical Need For Speed experience of being chased by police, and racing - however with the flashy title and wonderful cover art, the only police chasing you'll ever see is in the campaign since no police officers roam the open world you cause havoc in. This means you can crash and ruin traffic, destroy street signs, and disobey as you please with no threat. If you bought this game to also share that experience, I feel sorry for you, and hopefully you can refund it before its too late.

I found this game to be a ton of fun. I personally prefer games which have some sort of story line and character progression. That is hard to find in racing games. 

This game does a pretty good job of it. There is a basic story line, and while you can see the story coming from a mile away, it is nice that it is there. You actually have to earn your cars' abilities, and the grinding needed was the right mix of fun without being burdensome. 

I didn't have any graphics issues, and I'm using a 4 year old laptop (it was a pretty powerful gaming laptop at that point though). 

There are a ton of different races to try out, and I quite enjoyed the different experiences. 

Definitely one of the best NFS games out there.

It does feel a bit better than NFS 2015 given that the track is no completely "locked in" and the 'world" is more open. It is a plus and also a downside depending on where I am viewing it from.

I am not a fan of the casino/lootbox mechanic but it is workable at least and a change of "mechanic", though quite a leap/departure to how you'd expect upgrading your vehicle to be done in racing games.

If it is on sale, go for it. At regular price, I'd say wait. No point in rushing the purchase since it is not a current game anyway, so you can wait for it to go on sale, which seems to be frequently already.

Oh, and at least the "story videos" are not recorded live action actors doing a cheezy skit I guess. So a breath of fresh air coming from NFS 2015.
like it

This game is such a weird one for me that I'm writing this review solely to put my thoughts into writing. 

I will also say though I clicked the No on recommending this game, it was a surprisingly tough decision and I will now go into the why. 

I bought this game because I wanted a racing game with a stupid, cheesy story to remind me of the excellent Need For Speed Most Wanted (2005) that you can't buy on steam. With that in mind the story starring Naomi Nagata (Dominique Tipper)  from The Expanse (seriously watch this show) definitely fits the bill, unfolding like a cheesy Fast & Furious knock off where the actors play their characters so straight you have to believe they're being satirical fit exactly what I was after. The rest of the game however.... Read on. 

The open world is nicely put together with varied environments and plenty to do, borrowing heavily from Burnout Paradise and Forza Horizon. Graphics are lovely although it is annoying seeing the internals of your car fully rendered through the rear window but there being no cockpit camera, however this is an arcade racer so I wasn't expecting a cockpit cam going in, 

Race types are varied enough with Drag, Street Race, Drift, Off-Road and the always awesome Police Chases. 
The upgrade system is via cards which is a little derivative and basically resembles loot shooters in that you just replace one numbered card with a higher number to upgrade your vehicle. 

But it's the actual racing that made this a no from me. It has by far the worst handling of any racing game I have ever played. I'm being deadly serious, I own a hell of a lot of racing games both on PC and Console and this is the worst, no question. Driving is incredibly dull with most cars not knowing how to corner unless you enable the over the top drift mode which ends up being just as terrible but in the other direction. For instance don't bother using the standard brake button just use the handbrake instead assuming you want your car to behave remotely like an actual car and not understeer into the wall regardless of if you're driving a Ford Mustang or a Nissan Skyline. I know it's an arcade racer and not a sim but you expect arcade racers to simplify the act of driving a car not feel like you're driving the speedboat in a GTA game. 

So yeah, if like me you're after a racer with a fast and furious/most wanted esque story to kill some time then pick it up on sale otherwise steer clear. Also police chases are always fun!

I bought this game from sale, I felt i had some fun with it and it had many good things on it. On the second many things were rushed and done very poorly and this is the reason for not being recommended from me

For starters, this game has a serious technical flaw; controller support is very poorly done. I couldn't get my Logitech G27 wheel controller to work at all. Then I tried to use my Logitech F310 - gamepad, that worked somehow but you can't even re-map the buttons on controller, forcing me to stick with pre-made layout. You also can't adjust sensitivity at all, making controlling car very twitchy. There are barely any options to set up your controller. Game seems to support only couple wheels and only xbox gamepads. I've played many other driving games, Grid series, Dirt series, other NFS games, Forza Horizon and Motorsport, Wreckfest and the list goes on... literally all other games get it right and you can get your wheel to work at least decently. Just plain lazyness from the devs and ignoring other people with different controllers.

Driving in this game is very fast paced and full of action with races having jumps, drifting, dodging traffic and trying not to crash into that traffic. Indeed kind of fun. Driving physics are very arcadey, you rarely have to touch the brakes and you can drift even the tightest corners. For drifting events this works but for normal races I'd liked to have a bit more realistic approach. To me cars felt like hoverboards on asphalt, I enjoyed driving straighter roads with more space but driving in tight canyon roads became quickly frustrating. They really nailed arcade-racing back in the days of old NFS Underground, Most Wanted & Carbon era, its bit sad to see where things have evolved. After many hours i got bit used to handling model but it's far from good imo.

On the good side game had lots of variety with races. You got normal Races with completing laps, offroad races, some sprint racing, drifting, drag races, and courier / cop chasing missions. I especially enjoyed Offroading, its a really nice addition and it makes this game stand out from older NFS games. Most of the Career were interesting. You get a nice backstory with characters, acting is bit cheesy but that is more of a NFS trademark than a con. Gambling theme is present in story but also in upgrades and race bets. Making money is quite easy in career if you want to collect cars, that's a huge plus. Also now you will get enough space for all of your cars at garages. Thumbs up for that. Drifting were fun, drag felt quickly boring. Cop chases are really dumbed down. Instead the way where you freely escape the cops you have to drive into escape points what add you some time. It's like sprint racing where you have to stay in one fixed route and cops are chasing you. Police is overly aggressive and cop cars try to constantly push you and go absolutely berserk. And eventually cops just magically get behind and lose you every time. Not very fun and it made cop chases boring and repetetive. Same can be said from car performance upgrading what is another idiotic thing; only way to upgrade car perfomance is the cards. You can buy them from tuning shop, randomly get them from slot machine or as reward from races. You randomly get good or bad card. Whole system is dumbed down and uninspiring. Performance upgrading was never difficult or too clumsy in NFS before so I can't understand what are the real benefits with this?

And now more positive things; Car selection is diverse, I was happy to see a bit more rarer vehicles in PC games such as Volvo 242, Buick GNX, Mustang Foxbody etc. Also it was great fun to try find all old derelict cars from the map. There is plenty of visual customization options and a great livery editor full with decals. These things are where NFS Payback shines.   Graphics are good and visuals are impressive, not the best on the market but all good to my eye. There are plenty of different roads and activities in the open world, hot deserts, tight canyon roads, busy neon-lit city and even mountains filled with forests. I even had to stop my car to see some of those beautiful landscapes :) For the first time in NFS series I felt the open world is really huge and interesting. I liked how car engines sounded and they felt realistic. There is also neat sound echoing on the world when you drive into tunnel or drive close to the walls. 

In summary NFS Payback is a car game with many good bits but also with many flaws. It's a shame how bad controller support is, it really affects the driving. It also has many odd design choices such as uninspiring cop chases, and the performance card-system. It had potential to be a really good game but now it feels its a bit rushed average product. I can't fully recommend it, if it's on sale and you have Xbox or some other gamepad you could go for it.
