First off - I bought this on sale. If that wasn't the case, I would have a harder time recommending it. It has it's flaws, of course, but if you can live with the following:

- you will crash and take wrong turns every once in a while because you cannot spot the correct course in time (can restart/replay all events, though)
- the upgrade system is like a collectible card game for each car in contrast to common unlock-and-purchase- mechanics
- traffic will randomly ruin your attempts in driftzones, speedtraps and the like more often than not

then it is worth checking out!

In fact, there are a lot of things that I enjoy more than in NFS Heat.

- drifting is still not great, but a lot better than the abysmal NFS Heat variant
- you have a crew of 3 characters, each with their own specialties and cars for specific events
- 6 chapters of story with a good amount of races to them that require you play each of the characters
- story is good enough, and your characters actually have dialog and make comments in races
- opposing crews and their bossed try so hard to be mean and badass, it's already funny
- treasure hunting for 5 different wrecks that you can upgrade to very cool, outrageous builds
- a diverse landscape, from high speed desert roads and dusty offroad trails over serpentine mountain roads and villages to a city with bridges and tunnels - it is all there!
- lots of skill activities, collectibles and side duels against cops and street racers that you can do to earn resources but are not required since they don't contain unique rewards - you can earn all the stuff by doing the things you like.

If you like NFS in general and can get this on sale, you can't go wrong. The DLC cars are not that interesting and surely not required, purchse only if you have money to burn.
The map is pure robbery, don't support EA's moneygrubbing tactics. Unless you are an obsessive completionist, it is not necessary to find everything. There is no unique car or other unlock to be had that way.

Have fun!

I liked Need For Speed 2015. I really enjoyed the ability to upgrade any car into something worth using, and the world was great to explore.

This game has neither of those. 

Upgrades are random chance. Your choices are either scout out every store on the map for a "speed card" that you need, or take your chance literally gambling with the game's premium currency. The cars feel less like something I've tuned and perfected for the setup I want, and more of a build that I was forced into because some of the stats were higher than my previous, even if it doesn't drive the way I like to drive.

The world is terribly designed. The vast majority is a desert with few alternative paths to take, and bland areas to explore. The world feels much more empty than 2015, there aren't many cars driving around and it feels like there's less to do.

I'd pass on this game and just get a different Need For Speed game. If you have played all of them and want more driving, this is still passable. You can just do better.

This is actually a decent Need for Speed game, I highly recommend it to anyone who loves to play a laid back arcade racing game that has a decent car selection and customization options. The story is interesting and the races are actually fun with some having unique elements thrown in. There are special races that have unique events tied to them that give a more story-like feel to them, they are some of my favorite races. You also need to race against many different leagues, the first time you encounter each league a scene will play with a little background to what they are all about, but honestly, for most of them you'll probably just cringe.

The map is easily my favorite map from any Need for Speed game that I have played. You are in Fortune Valley, the city is full of casinos and gambling, and outside of the city is desert roads, small towns, and even mountain roads surrounded by a more lush landscape. Plenty of off road trails to adventure and plenty of windy roads to drift around. They did a fantastic job on the map for this game.

The car selection isn't super large, but it is decent, I'm sure there will be several vehicles you'll love to see. They have cars, trucks, and SUVs in their list. The driving physics are fun, easy to drift and easy to control. The strangest part about the cars in this game is how the performance upgrading is handled. Instead of purchasing performance parts, you purchase performance perk cards... you'll see what I mean if you just play, there is unfortunately a lot of RNG involved in the way you upgrade your cars in this game.

car categories is another interesting feature/take. you can categorize your car into something like drift, drag, etc. the issue here is each category will make your car handle differently, you can't have single car for multiple category, and you can't reassign it i think. this make things feels really weird and very unrealistic. at times i even feel i can drift better in my race car than in my drift car.

I see NFS Payback as gamechanger on the series. Even though every single game had a sort of a story behind everything connecting the dots, they were usually boring and quite shallow.
The game story is about a crew of 3 guys who got betrayed during a car-heist job. From there, they'll work hard with their skills to get revenge (or payback) from what happened. The only way to that is by getting into this super race but, all the races are rigged, so skills should do the trick.

I really liked that you see the story through the eyes of 3 different characters with totally different driving skills (and personalities). Even the comments they make are very particular. I just missed more of them talking to each other during the game. Sometimes Jess will ask for a burger or the mechanic will ask you to stop by the garage. We should have more of these things!

Don't expect anything close to real world physics as we see on CARS Project for example. But that doesn't mean the game is stupid, it's just focused on another type of gamer. If you like races for fun and relaxing time in front of a screen you found the game for it!

The soundtrack is pretty decent but it gets repetitive after a while. You can change the tracks and that's a HUGE improvement though.

The scenes are simply breathtaking! EA was able to build up a whole city with diverse environments. From this Nevada-like desert to a classic city, but also taking moutains, dirty roads and even a dam into account! If you get tired of racing other cars, a stroll around the map as something funny to do.


And now the CONS

They've come up with this insane idea of "what if we make gamers compete on a race with a car that's not for that?" and that was a huge drawback. There's a moment in which you're driving a drag-racing car, but then you need to free race other cars. Guys, WHAT THE HECK WAS THAT? We spend a lot of time building up cars and then you put us into this messy race-thing? WHY?

Character development is shallow. It was amazing seeing that you follow the whole plot through the eyes of 3 different people. But after a couple of minutes into the gameplay, it seems that changing the driver doesn't change anything at all. There was little information about their background and the game dialogues could be used more often to provide a greater experience.

Off-road races were a blast but dragging was just painful. We all know that drag races go back into NFS story. Some of us are fed up with them, and some still want them around. But whatever the decision was, the drag races here only shows up at the end of the game plot and they're absolutely annoying.

Speedcross series was awesome, BUT WHY ON EARTH CAN'T I USE SPEEDCROSS CARS ON DIFFERENT SORTS OF RACES??? So, they come up with this ingenious idea of making a multi-purpose car that you can use for everything, from dirty roads to drift and speed. But, can you chosse this car to compete on the other races? NO. Why? Just because.

The police was either over-buffed or underpowered. Police cars are faster than you. It doesn't matter how fast or how high your car build is. In this game, the police vehicles are F18s pretending to be cars. They're fast as missile but stupid as a donkey. Some will hit you at ultrasonic speed and have you crashing around, others will just be around hitting walls. Getting away was never easier in a game before.
Yeah, there's alot wrong with this game, but there's one thing no one else had addressed... How in the world could a Police Dodge Charger keep up with a vehicle thats going 230-240mph?

I've been craving a good ol fashioned arcade racer for some time now. Luckily, I caught NFS:Payback when it was on sale. For the first few hours, I was having the time of my life, loving the gameplay, story, everything. And then I hit a wall, does this formula sound familiar? It sounds like a mobile game....oh dear....

The story of Payback plays out just like a Fast and Furious movie which made me enjoy it instantly. You play as Tyler, Jess, and Mac. They are pulling off a job in the beginning of the game, but get betrayed int he end and get disbanded. A few months later, Tyler gets the will and opportunity to get his revenge on the woman who betrayed him and his crew and sets off to get....payback.

The opening mission and all story missions in general are very well crafted. You avoid cops and drive through checkpoints and then a cutscene plays where you switch to another crew mate. I thought this was freaking awesome and it totally drew me in. I loved the dialogue between Tyler and his crew, you feel like they're real close friends even outside of story missions when they occasionally call each other. There are a lot of regular races and events you'll do to progress the story and defeat crews. You can even drive in the open world to smash billboards, find hidden items, etc. Like other reviews, I was disappointed that you couldn't do pursuit chases in the open world, unless you find crate events.

The gameplay is fun but has it's moments (especially in the later half of the game) of frustration. Sometimes your car will be too drifty, and other times you can't get it to drift at all. It's all about your equipment in your car (which we'll discuss in the gripes section). As frustrating as it was, it's also exhilarating when you hit drifts perfectly, or racing at over 120 MPH. The arcadey racing is really good when done right.

The music soundtrack was really good. This took me back to my days playing ol school Burnout, NFS, and Midnight Club games. My only problem was that your playlist was locked to what "category" of car you were driving (another thing we'll get into once we arrive to the gripe section). Certain songs I wanted to hear, I couldn't listen to because of the car I was driving in, and that sucked. The game looks beautiful on PC though. Loved the look of the cars and how great the crashing takedowns on police vehicles looked.

*deep breath* Okay, let's get into these gripes, because there are many. For starters, the category system. Each car is broken into different categories: DRIFT, RACE, DRAG, RUNNER,and OFFROAD. You need different cars to do different events and races, etc. On paper this is cool, but the problem is, the game doesn't diversify the cars. The game will tell you that you must have a "DRIFT" car for this event, however, the same RACE car you bought from the RACE dealership will also be at DRIFT dealership. And most times, it will drive exactly the same. Sure there may be a different car here and there, but the majority of the cars are exactly the same across all dealerships, what's the point of splitting them up then?
The BIGGEST problem is the lootbox system in this game...wait I'm sorry...Speed Card system in this game. Remember in classic NFS games where you could customize your car and parts in the garage to make them stronger? That's all gone and now replaced with this randomized Speed Card system! You get cards from completing events and from loot crates the game sends you for playing well. At first this isn't a big deal, as long as you drive well you'll do fine. Well....once you reach chapter 2, that all changes. Before you do any event, there's a "recommended" level your car should be at. If you're not at the level, 9.5 times out of 10, you don't stand a chance in the race. The AI will dust you, with no chance of catching up. You have to go to the tune-up shop, which has randomized cards every few minutes and just HOPE that it has the cards you need to get your level up. If not, you gotta grind old races to get those cards. And it gets EVEN WORSE when you get to chapter 3 and better. The recommend level gets ridiculously higher within the same mission list. Instead of enjoying the story, you have to stop and just grind and pray that you get the card you need to make your car better to get past the event you're stuck on. Even your cosmetics are locked behind these loot boxes! They really wanted you to pay to pass events. And if you buy a new car, even if it's in the same category, you can't use the speed cards you had on a previously purchased model. I could understand if this was online, but this is the SINGLE PLAYER CAMPAIGN! Needless to say, I got close to the end of the game, and just gave up. I was tired of pointless grinding and RNG just to finish the story, which is a shame because I was actually enjoying it!

Final verdict? *sigh* I wish I had the ability to not give this a thumbs up or down but more like a neutral. This game is fun when you're just playing it for the arcadey racing. But that paywall and loot box system, it makes you feel like you're playing a mobile game and you already paid for a AAA title. If you;re looking for a fun racing game, you can pick this up. Bur beware, once you get to the later half of the game, be prepared for RNG and frustrating grinding. Thanks for reading!

TL:DR: Great arcadey racing game with a Fast and Furious-like story. However, there is low customization and upgrades are replaced with loot boxes. Be prepared to hit a wall when you get to the later half of the game if you decide to play this.

SPOILER ALERTS AHEAD
the main single player story campaign is an absolute joke. It starts off decent and feels somewhat reasonable, but then the main villian / antagonist blows up the protagonists house nearly killing him. You then find out the casino is corrupt and that a lot of the factions have beef with the casino. So, you have to make allies. But the other factions are all snobs. You have to prove your better than them just to talk to them. You have to prove yourself by beating the leaders crew mates in races, not once, not twice, but usually 3 or 4 times, just to be able to get the main leader to race you. You have to do this repetitive boring process with like 6 factions, meaning you have to do 30+ pointless races Just to be allowed to unlock the next set of story missions. The worst faction by far is the drag racing faction. The game gives you an old shitty car as default, and it is literally impossible to beat the drag racers, so you have to go to a store and buy a better drag race car. by the way of which all the drag racers act like snobs. Why should our characters even give a shit about drag racing? It’s stupid and it has nothing with the driver and everything to do with the car and some of the game dialogue even acknowledges it at some point. Anyways, you beat all of the factions and every single one of them afterwards is just like “yeah what ever your a good racer, your taking down the casino? Cool story we’re rootin for ya.” Then in one of the later missions you steal cars from the casino, and they rigged BOMBS to the cars to kill you I presume. You find out later that the cars were bait cars and were rigged with explosives from the start. Then later in the story, there is a “party” where all the racer factions get together to hang out, and the main villian shows up in front of everyone just to tell the protagonist something like “you don’t stand a chance” and they bicker like petty siblings and then she leaves. It’s like this game was written by a 6 year old. The villian literally tried to kill you on 2 separate occasions, and even when face to face, your character never says anything like “hey you tried to kill me you piece of s****!” Instead your character just acts like a cocky street racer, just like everyone else. Why oh why would you make a story line this ridiculous? Honestly it’s on the same level as watching a cartoon meant for kindergartners.

[h1] Introduction[/h1]
Ghost Games third entry in the series. At the time, hyped during the E3 reveal for its graphics and story missions. Need For Speed: Payback was welcomed at first as one of the series most lackluster games, and is generally branded as an easy pass when it comes to racing games. Yet here am I, giving a postive review. And trust me, I'm not gonna tell you "oh no this game is misunderstood, it's actually a masterpiece!". But allow me to explain some things:

[h1] Cars[/h1]
When it comes to cars, how is Payback's roster? While it certainly isn't as overreaching as Heat's roster, it's actually in a very nice middle ground. Payback is currently the only game in the series which allows you to build a car from derelict parts, and this feature allowed the introduction of some rare, but interesting cars, such as the Chevrolet Bel Air, or the Volkswagen Beetle. Said feature also allowed for an interesting feature - as these cars aren't just for show. You can literally build late game killers from these cars. And while irrealistic, I'll admit it was one of the fun parts ("bye Lambo, eat my '65 Mustang dust"). 

Regarding other cars, the roster is comprised from oldies like Volvo 242, to JDMs such as the Silvia and the RX-7, to a very beautiful selection of hypercars, from the Viper to a wide selection of Lambos and Porsches, and an appearence by the mighty Regera. Beware tho - money doesn't grow in trees in NFS: Payback, so invest your money and time carefully in your rides.

[h1] Gameplay[/h1]
[u] Soundtrack[/u]: soundtracks often come as a winning point in NFS games. Most Wanted and Underground 2 are still games which made certain songs be stuff of legends. Even Hot Pursuit is and was widely aclaimed for its soundtrack. Payback tho... Eh. It's in a weird mixture of trap/hip hop to a certain type of electronic which doesn't sit well with the environment at all. I enjoyed about 50% of the songs, to be gentle.

[u] Race types[/u]: 10 points for Team Payback here. Race types are most fun and varied, and Drag races are incorporated again in the storyline. While pursuit mode is a bit lackluster here, Runner missions are actually some of the most fun I've had, and they're a good mix of "mission" and "pursuit".

[u] Environment/Aesthetic[/u]: not the prettiest in its class. Heat and 2015 are the definitive experience if you play Need For Speed for the aesthetics. However... that doesn't mean Payback is ugly or anything. Snapshot Pro is actually a nice upgrade from 2015, and I've actually taken some nice pics from the game.

[u] Fortune Valley[/u]: not the best map. At all. Underground 2's map is retirement-old as of this time, and the highways, road mountains and side alleys make up for a better ride than Fortune Valley. The redeeming feature is the off-road part, where offtrack you can actually get a fun experience out of cruising.

[u] Performance parts[/u]: ugh. No. No. Never again. Payback is the ONLY entry so far where performance upgrades are done thru "Speed Cards", which you get in a "surprise mechanic", EA-type of lootbox kind of thing. Again - there's a reason why this is the ONLY entry where this happens. The community came down on this game over it.

After all this, why is my review positive?

[u] Gameplay[/u]: Story-wise, it's uninspired (I don't wanna spoil it for anyone, but ugh. Seriously. Wanna play NFS for the story? Skip this one). But the way the game feels? Oof. I've drifted with an offroad-prepped '65 Mustang in the middle of the mountains. I took my RSR to unmatchable speeds through the mountains tunnels. I drifted in the middle of the forests with a BMW M4 GTS like I was DK himself. I damaged police cars doing Neville's move in Need For Speed: Carbon with a monster of a Camaro. While the brake-to-drift configuration was appaling to many, Payback will be worthwile to the casual, day-to-day Need For Speed player.

I'm only going to focus on story here, because that seems to be something that is ignored in many reviews of these games.

I was a big fan of The Crew and how the roughly 65-mission campaign story integrated into the open world.  The Crew 2 removed virtually all of that, making it feel a bit aimless where you just choose random event after random event.  I need more story context in my driving game.  I recently tried Forza Horizon 4 because I thought it might be like The Crew except in Scotland, but while it does have several mini-stories, they are relatively minimal in terms of story content.  Then the Need For Speed 6-game bundle went on sale so I grabbed that and have been playing through them chronologically.  So I've played every game from Burnout Paradise Remastered up through Payback, and only have Heat yet to install.

I've read lots of reviews and discussions from NFS fans talking about the merits of one game's story over another, but the truth that I discovered is that Most Wanted 2012, Rivals, and NFS 2015 have no story whatsoever.  They are just "here's a car and a map, go do stuff."  NFS 2015 has the illusion of a story with the live-action cutscenes and sometimes interesting phone calls you receive from your crew, but it becomes apparent before long that it is mostly just characters telling you "Hey there's an event over here, come do it."  I initially had fun with every one of these games, but before long they started to feel directionless and that sapped my interest.

But NFS Payback is something entirely different!  It has an evolving story that frames many of the events so that there's a lot more to draw you into the world other than "here's a car and a map, go do some stuff" and gives more color to the various locations.  This is exactly what I've been missing in every racing game I've tried since the original Crew, including the much-vaunted Forza Horizon 4.  I'm having a lot of fun in Payback watching the story progress and learning about the various factions.  There's still plenty of open-world content for you to drive around and do as you see fit, but the addition of the campaign story is the vital ingredient that I think has been missing from the NFS series since at least Most Wanted 2012.

If you're a fan of The Crew (the first one), then Payback is the NFS game that you want to pick up.  The three games previous to Payback will feel a bit hollow and aimless in comparison, even though they have merits in other areas--for instance, NFS 2015's night visuals look amazing even 5 years later.  I can't speak for NFS Heat's story yet but I have the impression it might be dialed back a bit from what Payback did, which would be unfortunate.

This is the first Need for Speed game I have played in a long time, so I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought it. Having completed it I can say that it feels far from the night time street racing of the NFS games I grew up playing; it's more akin to an arcade racer like The Crew 2 or one of the Forza Horizon games. However, I can say that Payback is not as good as either of the aforementioned titles.
Payback is not a bad game but it is marred by a terrible upgrading system, where winning parts to improve your car is essentially a gamble. When you win a race or complete another event like picking up one of the bait boxes (which leads to a police chase) you can choose one of three cards, containing an upgrade for your car. Of course if you are seeking a particular part, like turbo, and you end up with something else, you'd have to grind the race again until you get it. The gambling of the post-race cards is abated slightly by the shops in the game world, where you can buy cards; but even this is luck-based, as the shop will stock random parts that refresh every so often. Can't find the part you want? Enjoy waiting for a few minutes.
The story is standard Need for Speed affair, cheesy as all hell and not worth paying much attention to. Tyler Morgan and his crew get betrayed by someone and Tyler, fixated with revenge, seeks to get back at them blah blah blah. The story is progressed by finishing events, and there are some ok events here. Drifting is hard to get used to but fun once you get the hang of it. Races are ok although there should have been more of them. The courier missions are boring. The police chases are ok (but nowhere near as good as Most Wanted 2005.) Off-road racing is cool. Drag racing however is dire, not as good as drag racing in the Underground games. There's also Speedcross races, which are the funnest races in the whole game; however they are added as DLC and thus not part of the main story (although they should have been).
The map is good, pretty big but not too big, and diverse with forests, deserts, canyons and the city. The city is confusing to navigate though at first.
Overall if you're thinking of getting an arcade racer, consider The Crew 2 or Forza Horizon instead, both of those are much better than this. Payback had potential to be better but the bad upgrade system, lame story and the grinding (especially when you finish the game) hold it back from being a truly good game. If only EA looked back at the mid-2000s and once again realised how to make a good racing game.

Right, heads up, this is going to be a harsh review, the game is not [i]that[/i] bad but it's not very good either. I'll mention the most annoying points, and I'll compare with Forza Horizon 4 as both are open-world and share many aspects.

Also, I haven't played the other titles in the series, so I won't compare with other NFSs 

[h1]Tuning[/h1]

Tuning in this game is simply awful. 

- First of all, you have to progress through the story in order to unlock better upgrades, so if you wanted to play with your friends who already finished the game, well too bad, you have to go through the 20+ hours long story first. Forza Horizon 4 on the other hand lets you purchase any upgrade right away and you can participate in the fastest races from the get go.
[i]Note: This is less of an issue if you don't plan to play multiplayer or at least not right away, but it's still annoying[/i]

- Upgrades are "cards", you get random upgrade cards with random perks and a random level as rewards, and while you can also buy them, the shop is also random. [b]There is no way to get the card you want, it's all random and you just have to grind endlessly until you get something that's close enough to what you need[/b]. 
In contrast, in Forza Horizon 4 you can just buy the upgrade you want/need, there is no randomness involved, you don't have to spend 2 hours trying to get the right upgrade.

- I have mixed feelings about this last point: Upgrade cards in this game don't visibly change your car. Visual customization is separate, for example, spoilers are part of the visual customization, so adding one to your car has no effect whatsoever on the performance. In FH4, adding a spoiler would improve handling and decrease speed. 
This means you can make your car look dumb with no performance loss, which is both cool and meh. 

[h1]Police chases[/h1]

Police chases are one of the main things of this game, and as far as I know, of all NFS games. I can only say that they are a bit underwhelming, cops basically have infinite speed and will always catch up to you until you get close to the "escape point", once you're about 1km away from the escape point, the cops will just slow down significantly. 

"Oh no, Control, I've turned off my engine and somehow I cannot catch up to the suspect anymore, we lost them."  - 10/10 immersion

[h1]Drag races[/h1]

This is one of the few things this game mostly does better than FH4, in FH4, drag races are just dumb "press forward until the finish line". 

- In this game, drag races enforce manual shifting, and the better your timing for shifting is, the more nitrous you get. This makes drag races actually require you to play the game, and not just "haha I have the better car I automatically win". 

- However, they still managed to ruin parts of it, (very minor spoilers) [spoiler]the story will force you to do regular races (as in: not a straight line) and even offroad races with your drag car because the devs went like "haha wouldn't it be funny if we took this drag car built specifically to go on straight asphalt roads and forced it to on dirt curved roads hahahaha"[/spoiler] 

[h1]Racing[/h1]

- I'm not going to comment much on the racing style, it's extremely arcade, it makes FH4 look like a simulator despite also being arcade. I really dislike this game's racing style, but I'm sure some people on the contrary prefer this over FH4's style.

- As a small rant however, I'd like to note that the invisible walls in this game are cancerous, there's a lot of ramps in this game for jumps, and every time you jump, you have a good chance of hitting some random ass invisible wall that will throw you of course.

[h1]Micro-transactions[/h1]

There's loot-boxes in this game and they're absolutely worthless. You definitely don't need to pay additional bucks to get through the story, the most grindy part are the upgrade cards and the loot-boxes don't really help you with that, the loot boxes only matter for the visual effects they give you (that you can't get anywhere else). They're not that big of a deal and don't really impact gameplay, but the fact they even exist is a downside in my book. 

[h1]End note[/h1]

All of the aspects I haven't talked about are aspects I didn't think were worth mentioning, such as the graphics and story for example, both are good enough for what it is

I wish I could recommend this game, I really do, but it has so many problems and it's quite sad to see the path it took

Pros:
-Quite a list of cars
-Customisation is nice
-The map is ok/good
-Characters are okay, could be better, but are passable
-Quite aggresive cops
-Songs that play depending on where you are and time of day (desert, downtown, mountain, etc. Morning, Afternoon, Night) Which is pretty creative

Neutral:
-The story could be better but it's nothing horrific in my eyes, It didn't gave me much of a sense to, well, Payback, since the start felt rushed, but at the final race I really got that feeling of bringing down The House

Cons:
-Optimiziation problems, it suffers from Watch Dogs 2 Syndrome where it lags even when in low graphics when there is a lot going on on the screen like cop chases and driving around the city, however it's better than Watch Dogs 2, since you don't get much lag on open areas, different from Watch Dogs 2 which is pretty much everywhere
-No free roaming cops, only for some events
-The AI can be a bit too punishing
-Not having the ability to change your handling settings like the 2015 game did, which can be quite annoying
-Airtime is a mechanic. Too much of it? Good luck getting collectibles cuz you will fly past them, or go way too high during a race and land where you didn't want to
-The way you get upgrades... It's basically The Crew 1's way of getting upgrades, you finish a race, you get a CARD that upgrades your engine/ecu/transmisison/whatever, and it's all very RPG-like, which isn't a good thing, you basically have to wait for the performance shop to restock so you can buy better parts, you can't just go there and buy the best ones in case you have the money
-Lootboxes, of course, why not, it's an EA game after all. Everyone wanted neon lights for their cars but they didn't deliver it on the 2015 game, everyone complained about it, so they added it! IN. MOTHER. F-CKING. LOOT BOXES. You basically have to open shipment crates to get a chance to get neon lights, which include colors and patterns in which they flash, along with nitrous colour, tire smoke, and horn sound, which is all cool and games until you realise you need to open lootboxes for them instead of just buying them. And the best part is? You use one of those items in your car, you can't take them off, to your inventory, you either delete them or replace them, you want to take it out and use in another car? Too bad, open more lootboxes so MAYBE you get the same neon/smoke/nitrous/horn. I bought the Deluxe Edition and I got 5 platinum neons, tire smokes, and nitrouses for free, which seemed pretty good until I realized I couldn't use them as much as I wanted because there are only 5 of each, if I use all of them, they're gone, like, forever. Such bullshit
-The deluxe edition doesn't come with the car pack dlc. Sure, I don't care much about those cars but, seriously? The D E L U X E edition doesn't come with all dlc? What a dissapointment

Conclusion:
6/10 - Need for Speed: Payback is a flawed game, it seemed to have potential, but was ruined by corporate greed. The story was okay, but enjoyable I guess. The songs were enjoyable. The car variety was enjoyable. The customization was enjoyable. Taking down The House was enjoyable. There are a couple of things in this game that make me believe that Ghost Games at least tried to deliver something decent, and it's quite unfortunate that EA had to ruin it all with microtransactions. I'm not gonna put all of the blame on EA however, some things in the game are probably Ghost's own fault, but still, the fact that this game has loot boxes, and when everyone wanted neon, they put neon in said loot boxes, shows what kind of company EA is.

If you want to buy the game, wait for a sale, and try it, if you like it, then that's very good, it's not the best game in the world, and I believe it's deserving of a downvote because of EA's incompetence, but it's worth giving a try at least for me, you might get some fun out of it. I'm glad that the next game, Need for Speed Heat, is better than this one in every aspect, It's too expensive for me to buy it since I live in Brazil, a harsh country with a shitty economy, but I hope I get the chance to play it one day. For now, Payback is the most recent need for speed I have, and although it is far from perfect, I cannot lie, it was a fun ride.

Bad stuff out of the way first...

The offroading is complete garbage. The handling is twitchy, and frusterating. You drift when you want to stop drifting, and when you need to kick the back end out, your car just decides that it doesn't want to turn the front wheels... and then you fall off a cliff or smash into a rocky canyon wall. When you are racing the second and third off road leagues (FEM and HC) the drivers are auful. They will piledrive you into a wall and then be back to 100 mph in about 2 seconds. In both of the second off road leagues, I found myself being 20-30 levels over the recommended level and I still had to turn the difficulty to easy to advance to the next race. (I played through most of the game on medium.) The Rubberbanding is a massive annoyance as well. But the worst thing about this game is the respawn system. It works a bit like the offroading in principle... when you scrape off something lightly and are on your way, it respawns you. but when you go flying off course onto a road and need to get back to the track quickly, good luck. You're on your own. Also, half of the time when it respawns you, it does so about 3 ft in front of a wall with you doing 20-30 mph, which causes you to crash and costing you more time than if you had not been respawned at all. 

with the somewhat angry rant over with...
 I would actually recommend this game. despite the 2 massive issues I have mentioned above, the overall expirence is a good one. The derilect cars for one, was a great addition to the game. The story, while admittedly being a bit on the cheesy side was fun to play through, and kept the game moving along at a nice pace. The customization is really good, and it is just fun to do some absurd car builds. The map is fantastic, with forests, a big city, deserts, canyons, an airfield, and many really nice driving roads. The car class system (Race, Drift, Drag, Offroad, and Runner) inspired me to build some interesting cars, like my Drag speced corvette and my Drift mustang. honestly, I didn't find the loot boxes or whatever they are called to be to annoying, because you can get them from level ups, stars, and you get 10 premium shipments from getting the Deluxe Edition (which is the only one you can get on steam). The upgrade system was all right. on the one hand, It was super cool when you got that perfect part for your car that made all the difference in The way it drove. On the other hand, it was immensely frusterating when you just need one particular part and the game won't give you one. That being said, it does fit with the games whole theme of gambling, so if nothing else, it fits the asthetic that the devs were going for. 

This game is definatly worth a buy. if it's on sale, grab it immediatley. if not, then get it anyway. despite a few glaring issues, Need for Speed: Payback still manages to be an excellent arcade driving experiance with a pretty good car list, graphics, on-road handling model, map features, and most of all, plenty of variety.

Why is there no track width adjustments??? Need for speed 2015 had all kinds of different suspension adjustments but Payback only has height and camber. There is no way to have 0 degree camber either which was also present in NFS 2015, it is only possible to have negative camber. Its annoying that features what were good in the last game are now gone hurting the customization experience.

Overall I think the game is good but this one feature constantly annoys me whenever I look at any car I have with a widebody kit.

While the game looks beautiful, runs smoothly, has decent acting and lip sync etc...it's f**king annoying

1. Forced to install Origin and wait for it to boot up/login etc
2. Extremely long starting times. 30 seconds waiting is no longer acceptable
3. Absolutely no way to remap controller config. Just the choice between 'Badly Mapped V1' and 'Badly Mapped V2'
4. The autosave system is abominable. SERIOUSLY, abominable. I've played this for less than 2 hours, in short bursts. When I finish a driving section and then have a cinematic and then I start another driving section, I expect the autosave (which is the ONLY option. There is NO save option/button) to have saved....well, it doesn't. Quit at the wrong time and you have to play the same section again. And if there are cinematics that can't be skipped, tough luck, you get to watch them again.

Disappointed ;/

Its corona viirus lock-down and i just needed something new to play, so i was playing original need for speed most wanted. However this game isn't pretty on my 2K monitor and i wanted something similar but updated. Looking at prices i decided to go for NFS Payback and i can honestly say I'm glad i did! Drag, Drift, Off road and more! Cop chases, random missions, treasure hunts, woo hoo! Hours of fun, Car customisation, Graphics whole bunch of goodies for cheap price.
It may not be perfect with this randomized card performance poker machine style upgrade, but other than that i'm having fun. 
Open world freedom, awesome graphics, birds and people  (listen carefully for what they say). Awesome job

This game is not recommended on pc if you are planning on using a ps4 controller. It also forces you to install Origin, which is an absolute trash client with an overlay that is in your way (without the option to dissable pop-ups). Took me a full 10 minutes to launch the game after the download. After using the "recommended" program to make the ps4 controller work it didn't let me use half of the controls, including driving. 
Sad to see that this game runs poorly on pc. I enjoyed it a lot on ps4.
This game is superb, definitely grab it.. I know its not real life simulation kinda game, but the arcade element of this franchise made me wanna grab this game.
